story:
Summary

Hi there!

We are 6 Dancers on a Mission: a small group of dancers in NYC looking to make an impact on a cause we care about.  We are using our skills as dancers to promote awareness and raise funds for global girls' education initiatives, beginning with "Do it in a Dress," a One Girl charity initiative providing scholarships to girls in Sierra Leone.   

We believe as dancers that arts have the power to awaken people, to impassion them and help them experience new things.  We hope to do just that with our first dance drama, SPIRIT: A Celebration of Women Everywhere.  Proceeds from both our performances will be donated to Do it in a Dress. Your donations will cover our costs up front so that we can donate more to the organization.  The more costs we cover up front, the more girls we can send to school this year!

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2,500 total to cover our production costs:

  • $1,000 for our first theater rental, $300 for the second.
  • $520 for rehearsal space.
  • $130 for our event insurance.
  • $150 for costumes.
  • $100 for royalties (music).
  • $100 for marketing/media.
  • $100 for promotional materials (programs, posters, etc...)
  • $100 for lighting/sound person/stage manager.

If we don't meet our goal, we are prepared to cover these costs ourselves from ticket sale proceeds.  However, our hope is to be able to donate most if not all of that money to Do it in a Dress.  

The Impact

“You educate a man; you educate a man. You educate a woman; you educate a generation.” -Brigham Young

  • It only takes $300 to give a girl in Sierra Leone access to education for an entire year.  
  • Last year, Laura (our choreographer) raised $350 simply by putting a donation jar out after one of her dance performances with Vissi Dance Theater.  
  • This year, we want to send as many girls to school as possible.  Your donations will help us do that!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes you can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can't help!

  • Like us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/pages/6-Dancers-on-a-Mission
  • Come to one of  our shows! Performance dates are all on Facebook.
  • Please help us spread the word! Share our posts or use Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for your consideration!

story:
WHAT UP?

Not much, how are you? So what's the deal with the play Rock? Well, first and foremost, it's for you. And us. We're making the kind of theatre we like to see; theatre that speaks to our interests as young Canadian professionals that dig HBO and Apatow films. Your evening should be entertaining, arousing, challenging, and fun. Above all else, that's what we're working to bring you.

Rock is a pitch black comedy about love, friendship, and how far you would go to protect someone you care about who has recently started bludgeoning people to death with rocks. It's a new Canadian play from the twisted mind of Kat Sandler (writer/director of LOVESEXMONEY, Help Yourself, and Delicacy) and it's pretty neat.  

Basically, your roomate came home with the body of a guy he clubbed to death with a rock. What do you do? (He wants to play N64 and drink beer.)  We think you'll like it.

YES. THIS! HAVE SOME LOOT!

Sound good? We hope so. We would love to have your support, but more importantly, your time and support matter THIIIIISSSSS MUCH (I'm holding out my arms.  You can't see it, but trust me it's quite impressive) and we want to offer you some nifty loot for believing in us and our work. But before we get to that, here's the talented, passionate people your cash will be going towards paying:

I LIKE ALL THOSE PEOPLE!  SHUT UP AND TAKE MY MONEY!

Still with us? You Rock (see what I did there?). We've got some nifty perks for you, because you're awesome and you deserve it. Look over there! TECHNOLOGY!----->

-The Cast and Crew of ROCK.  And Viewers Like You! *Rainbow*

PS: And once again, thanks.  Your interest and support are helping to usher in the next generation of theatre, for people like you, by people like you.  There isn't enough room in an Indiegogo window to express how much that means to us and we hope every actor, script, set, and show delivers above and beyond what you expect.  You deserve the best and we want to bring it to you.

story:
We Need Your Help 


This summer, Project Rushmore Theatre Company bursts onto the New York scene with its debut productions: 

 

VALHALLA

by Paul Rudnick

 

and

 

THE QUALITY OF LIFE

by Jane Anderson 

(a New York premiere)

 

 

The productions will feature—and be directed by—members of the company. Though written by two radically different playwrights, both plays further the company's artistic mission of exploring the American spirit. They will be presented on a rotating repertory schedule, July 16 through August 4, at the ArcLight Theatre. The company is excited, energized, and ready to go! 

But we need your help.... Won't you join us in our quest, by making a contribution? No amount is too small, or too great! By giving, you will aid a group of dedicated artists in sharing their work. You'll give exposure to two fine American playwrights and their brilliantly crafted plays. And you'll enable audiences to explore the timeless themes of identity, nonconformity, true beauty, aging, loss, compassion, love, regret, and the wonders of living and dying in America.

Your gift will also help launch a new theatre company founded on the repertory model, now rare in New York City, in which company members work together frequently, in an effort to produce a richer form of theatre. The depth of the work derives in part from the artists' deep understanding of each other.

 

The Plays

In Paul Rudnick's VALHALLA, both King Ludwig of Bavaria and James Avery of Texas spend their lives in search of beauty. Six actors alternate between the mid-nineteenth and twentieth centuries, bringing to life a grand comedy of epic scope.

In Jane Anderson's THE QUALITY OF LIFE, when Dinah and her husband visit a dying cousin, they are surprised by his end-of-life plans—and those of his wife. Anderson's play explores issues surrounding family and death, including how we prepare for, and process, loss. Her remarkable play unfolds with provocative intellect and unexpected humor. This will be the New York City premiere of Anderson’s play. She has won an Emmy and a WGA Award for her television writing, which includes Normal, an HBO adaptation of her play Looking for Normal. 

 

Background 

For the past three years, Project Rushmore has presented a series of two staged readings every month, focusing in large part on plays by emerging American playwrights. Along the way, the company has given back to the community, as well—by presenting two readings specifically in celebration of Gay Pride Week, and also by producing a special benefit performance whose proceeds sponsored three cobblestones at the new National September 11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center. Now, the company is primed to tackle our next step—presenting fully staged, fully realized productions that further our artistic mission: to explore the American Spirit.

 

Where Your Contribution Goes

There are countless expenses inherent in producing live theatre, and the economics of doing so mean that ticket sales don't come close to covering costs. The company needs $9,650, in order to make our dream come true. And with generous support from champions like you, Project Rushmore can meet this goal, allowing our projects to soar. 

Your donation will help the company pay for such things as:

  • Theater Rental
  • Licensing Fees
  • Insurance
  • Scenery
  • Props
  • Lighting
  • Costumes
  • Programs
  • Publicity

 

Other Ways to Help

We need your help in spreading the word of our fundraising campaign! Whether you are able to donate, or not, please assist us by encouraging your friends, relatives, and colleagues to visit our fundraising page here on IndieGogo. Check out our tools for sharing, right below our video at the top of this page. To share through e-mail, copy the link beside "Share This Campaign" and paste it right into your e-mail, along with an encouragement for your friend to click. Or use the Facebook, Twitter, and Google+ buttons to spread the word. Sharing our quest will make all the difference!

Thank you so much for taking the time to review our project. Won't you consider donating now, to help ensure our success? Your support will be greatly appreciated and means the world to us.

Sincerely,

 

Adrienne Doucette
Founding Artistic Director

Project Rushmore Theatre Company—exploring the American spirit!

story:
The Story: 

In the beautiful haunting and lonely ocean, a woman longs with her entire heart for a world to which she doesn't belong. She is filled with love for a mysterious man. This is a story about pursuing desire no matter the cost, the obstacles, or the laws of nature standing in the way. Loosely inspired by Tim Burton's 'Anchor Baby' and Hans Christan Andersen's 'Little Mermaid', this production uses a blend of music, sign language, and spoken language, and encourages us to question what shapes our desires and how the consequences can bind us. 

We are Deiopea Theatre and we need your help! We are an international physical theatre ensemble based in the UK, with the shared vision of creating highly visual, physical theatre. We (DAWN, from Canada and Finland, JAN, from England, and ANJA, from Germany and England) met whilst studying for an MA in Physical Theatre (international ensemble). Our unique, devised show 'Tide' is accessible to hearing, deaf and international audiences and we have the fantastic opportunity to take it on tour to Canada, Germany, across the UK, and possibly to Switzerland. We are really excited about sharing this work! By making a donation you will be helping us create shared experiences between audience members of diverse backgrounds, and helping us work towards breaking down communication barriers, which is something we passionately believe in!

What We Need & What You Get

Raising £700 will help cover production costs: set, costume, lighting and more.

Raising another £1800 will help us with our touring costs: flights, accommodation, subsistence and transporting our set.

Whether you donate £5 or £100, your generosity will be invaluable to us! As a token of our appreciation, we have some lovely, aquatically titled rewards for you, that range from a personal postcard from our tour, to having a special meal cooked by us in your own home.

Every contribution counts, whatever the size. If we don't reach 100% of our full goal, everything raised will still go towards developing and touring 'Tide'.

Our touring schedule

We are going to:
- Tristan Bates Theatre, Soho, London, June 2015
- Danceworks, Toronto, and other venues around Toronto, June 2015
- Folkwang, Essen, Germany, July 2015
- The Poly, Cornwall, July 2015
- Final performance in St.Mary's University Theatre, September 2015

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t make a donation don't worry! However, you can still contribute to the cause by spreading the word! Use the Indiegogo share tools or share our campaign on your Facebook and Twitter in order to encourage friends and family to support us. Please also join our Facebook page so we can keep you up to date with the latest information (https://www.facebook.com/DeiopeaTheatre).

We'd love to see you in the audience at one of our shows so please come along. As soon as ticket sales are released for each venue we will be making announcements on our facebook page, so keep checking back.


Thank You.

story:
Our Story

My name is Aya Travick-Best, I am 13 years old, and I am currently in the 8th grade. Dance has always been be lifelong dream, and now I have the opportunity to study at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. I attend Oakland School for the Arts, and are trained by Reginald Rae Savage, Maia Siani, and Alison Hurley. At OSA I take daily Ballet, Modern, Jazz, Reppitory, Horton, Dunham, and Pointe classes. Ever Since I was a little girl I've take West African, Haitian, Brazillian, and Hip Hop classes. My teachers have been Alseny Soumah, Collet Eloi, Heather Watkins, Kim Battiste, and Corey Action & Teela Shine. Dance is very close to my heart, and I one day hope to make it my profession. 

Outside of Dance I enjoy reading, figure skating, roller skating, watching movies, and listening to music. I have taken flute, violin, and piano lessons, and hope to have music help me along the way of becoming a known artist. My current role Models are Judith Jamison, Alvin Ailey, Alicia Keys, Prince, Michael Jackson, and my mother. 


What We Need & What You Get

In order to attend the Ailey Jr. Division Summer Program I must raise $5,000 by April 15th. This cost covers tuition for the program, and 5 weeks of housing in New York. My goal is obtain $50.00 from 100 people or $25.00 from 200 people. However all donations are appreciated.

story:
Pretty Bee and Other Translations is the first of many collaborations between Natalie George and Heloise Gold. After spending nearly 1 year together exploring their respective art forms (Dance and Light), they are ready to show the world a first glimpse of their performative findings.
 

ABOUT THE SHOW

Pretty Bee and Other Translations is a multi-layered performance using movement, vocals, shadow and light. It is an experiment in creating new relationships in collaboration as well as in breaking the traditional roles of technician, designer, and performer. Two duets are performed back-to-back, each a translation of the other. The choreography plays with revealing a journey through ever changing states of being. Can we sing opera as if we are in the shower alone and then fully embody the presence of a lizard? Can we pare down to an essential simplicity, reveal/perform the moment fully, and somehow trigger the unbounded reflections of the imagination? The piece plays with the aesthetics of change and attempts to share what often goes invisible.

ABOUT THE ARTISTS

Heloise Gold

Heloise is a performing/artist, dancer, T’ai Chi instructor and co-director of Art From The Streets (a project for homeless artists.) Her career traverses numerous paths beginning with childhood appearances with the Bolshoi Ballet (1962) to performing in Robert Wilson’s legendary 12 hour opera The Life And Times Of Joseph Stalin (1973); to participating in many experimental happenings in NYC in the 1970’s; to touring with The Deborah Hay Dance Company (1980’s); to being a key player in the inventive work being spawned in Austin in the 1980’s and 90’s; to creating numerous original works spanning 25 years. She currently collaborates with performers in Austin, New York and Europe. . Most recently she danced in a tribute concert for new music pioneer Pauline Oliveros at Columbia University; presented her work in the Fusebox festival in 2009 and 2010 and presented her work at The Majlis Arts festival in Toronto in 2011. Additionally she has been performing in Julie Natahanielsz’ Meeting Point works in Austin.

"Gold's work is an exquisite melange of gleeful humor, captivating images and finely etched movement detail, all eliciting a meditative dream state if you can stop laughing enough." - Austin Chronicle

Natalie George

Natalie is a designer, producer, and artist based in Austin, TX. These days she spends most of her time as the Producing Director of Fusebox, an annual contemporary arts festival.  As a lighting designer, she has designed Parade, Mid Summer, Cyrano De Bergerac, and Peer Gynt while teaching at St. Edward's University. Some of her other favorite designs around Austin and the U.S. include The Assumption, Magic Flute, Hamilton Township, I Witness, Baal and Glank. She is the resident lighting designer for the National Puppetry Conference at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center and Big Range Dance. Producing credits include the short film, The Runner and new plays Spacestation 1985 and Sad Sad Sad.

“The play of shadows orchestrated by Natalie George’s breathtaking light design is worth the trip in itself”- Austin American-Statesman.

FUNDRAISING

We are looking to raise $2000 in one month. We are committed to paying the artists and crew that help make our dreams come true. We have 2 amazing dancers (Elaine Dove and Julie Nathanielsz) that will join us on stage and 4 hard working technicians that will be mostly behind the scene, that we feel deserve to be paid for their art. Please help us do this.


Thank You,

Natalie and Heloise

story:
Hello there!!

Hi there! We are Stinki Pinki Productions and our piece, 'Urban Myths - Suburban Sluts' has been accepted into the New York Fringe Festival.  We be super stoked!! 'We' are Parisa Fakhri, Betsy Moore, Dion Jackson, and Ben Kusler. 

'Urban Myths - Suburban Sluts' is a spoken word piece written by our friends Kirsten Macy and Jena Kirkpatrick.

Your contribution will go toward airfare for four, lodging, advertising (postcards and posters), festival fees, and production costs.

This is a rare oppurtunity to get to perform in New York City at the lovely Cherry Lane Theatre! It's always been a dream of ours!! So, please watch our video and you will understand perfectly...maybe..maybe not.

In return for your generous donation, we will be forever greatful and love you hard.

Please, please help us keep the urban myth alive!

 

OUR DATES FOR 'URBAN MYTHS - SUBURBAN SLUTS' @ THE CHERRY LANE THEATRE IN THE WEST VILLAGE OF NYC!

 

FRIDAY 8/17 @ 8PM

SATURDAY 8/18 @10PM

SUNDAY 8/19 @ 2:15PM

WEDNESDAY 8/22 @ 4PM

FRIDAY 8/24 @ 4:15PM

 

Hope to see some of you at our show!!!!! Thanks y'all!

story:
Our Story

Touchstone Theatre has been an innovative West Coast home of new Canadian theatre for over 35 years.  We are known for our excellence and innovation. We are passionate about giving life to new plays and nurturing the work of playwrights.

Touchstone’s Flying Start program was launched in 2008 in association with Playwrights Theatre Centre as a new initiative to help stem the drain of talent from the field of playwriting. Playwrights  face an uphill battle in trying to sell their scripts to theatre companies, while trying to master the enormous difficulties of writing for the stage. While development opportunities abound, trying to get that first professional production can be enormously difficult.  Both Touchstone and the PTC feel that, while development is essential, playwrights can only truly mature with the sterling lessons a production offers.

Enter Flying Start.  The two year cycle begins with a public call for new scripts from playwrights who have yet to have a play professionally produced.  The first phase is focused on development of the script through dramaturgy and workshops with professional actors. The second phase is spent gearing up for and then realizing a full scale production using professional actors and designers.

Flying Start 2012: Shelter from the Storm

The 2012 Flying Start production is Shelter from the Storm by Peter Boychuk. This is the third play to be mentored and produced through Flying Start. Shelter is the story of Rick, one of thousands of young men who escaped the Vietnam draft and found refuge in Canada. When he gives shelter to a traumatized young American soldier who has deserted his post in Iraq, Rick begins to understand how much Canada has changed in forty years. Set in the beach, forest and surf culture of Tofino, BC, Shelter from the Storm is a play about love and loss that questions our notions of courage and cowardice. The script has already been awarded Second Prize in the 2011 Uprising National Playwriting Competition.

The Playwright

The playwright, Peter Boychuk, has just completed his MFA at U. Vic, under the mentorship of Governor General’s Award-winning playwright Joan MacLeod. Peter has already received numerous awards for his one-act plays. Afterglow has been published in the anthology Two Hands Clapping and has been produced in schools and universities across the country; Fortunate Son won the Stanley Mills Purchase Prize, Honourable Mention in the Canadian National Playwriting Competition and Best of the Fest at ACToberfest 2007; Chainmail Bikini premiered at the Calgary Fringe. In recognition of his shorter works, The Vancouver Sun has called Peter  “a rising young talent”.  Shelter from the Storm is his first full length play. This is an extraordinary opportunity for Peter. We want to give his work the best chance to succeed.

The Creative Team

A great creative team is on board: Peter Hall, Kyle Jespersen and recent Studio 58 grad Lindsay Winch will perform. The set design is by Pam Johnson; lighting by Adrian Muir; costumes by Farnaz Khaki-Sadigh; and sound by Jeff McMahan. Katrina Dunn will direct. Martin Kinch is the dramaturge.

The Impact

Touchstone’s early years were marked by its association with some of the most important Canadian playwrights of the 80’s and 90’s – Judith Thompson, Brad Fraser, Joan McLeod, John Murrell, Sally Clark, Byden MacDonald and Michel Marc Bouchard. The company has also been an important launch pad for West Coast playwrights such as David King, John Lazarus, Peter Elliott Weiss, Dennis Foon, Peter Anderson and Gordon Armstrong.  In more recent years Touchstone has given important productions to local playwrights Shawn Macdonald, Carmen Aguirre, Michael Lewis MacLennan, Janet Munsil, Ami Gladstone, as well as continuing to produce some of Canada’s national stars: Michael Healey, Jason Sherman, Vern Thiessen, Morwyn Brebner, and Daniel MacIvor. 

The opportunity that Flying Start offers – a first professional production for an important new voice in Canadian playwriting – is desperately needed.  Touchstone and its partners plan to continue the program in the hopes that it will seed a new generation of thriving local playwrights. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign by sharing it on Facebook, Twitter, or by emailing your friends.

You can buy a ticket or two or three to Shelter from the Storm through the Firehall box office at 604-689-0926 or tickets.firehallartscentre.ca

You can like our Facebook page 

You can follow us on Twitter 

Photo credits: Peter Hall, Kyle Jespersen & Lindsay Winch in Shelter from the Storm. Photo by Pink Monkey Studios.

story:
Lost in Staten Island, More Tales of Modern Living.

This spring brings the latest play and songs in the Modern Living series back to the Club at La MaMa as the final entry of their 50th anniversary season. 

Began in 2006 as a way to tell stories in a theatrical form, these are true stories about real people who struggle with the ordinary and extraordinary things we call life.  In our last edition Post Modern Living we told the story of my mom Joy, and what happened when she found a lump in her breast that turned out to be cancer. 

In Lost in Staten Island, actress Wendy Merritt is back as Joy, and she is joined by her son, the performance artist at the center of the series Mitch (played by author Richard Sheinmel); Alternately humorous and heartfelt, they spend the day together and just like the title says – they get lost in Staten Island.  Mick Hilgers; Catherine Porter; and Chris Orbach is back with his guitar, both singing and playing Mitch’s brother Robby – as he leads our band the All Star Sprit Guides in new music and songs by Clay Zambo.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Thanks for checking us out – we are raising funds for our next production.  We play in the Club at La MaMa ETC, a well-known theater at 74a East Fourth Street, in New York City’s East Village.  We go into rehearsal the second week in May and have our first performance June 15th. 

We’ve set our goal at $7500 – what you donate will go directly into the production and will help cover costumes, sets, lights, wigs (hey – we have to get that Staten Island hair just right) – it will cover running costs of the show, and transporting the instruments; among many other things.   

There are some fun incentives for your donation – the top donor gets written into the show… that’s right – your name, or a loved one’s name, or your pet’s name will be part of this play. (It comes with a copy of the script autographed by the authors and cast.) This incentive will also go to the first three people to donate at the $5000 level. 

Perks $500 and above include tickets to gala night, donate more and we will save a café table down front.  At $750 – you will receive a very unique thank you – Composer Lyricist Clay Zambo will give you an autographed hand written page out of his score. 

 

Donations are tax deductable.

Lost in Staten Island is a sponsored project of La MaMa ETC a non-profit arts organization. Contributions for the purposes of Lost in Staten Island must be made payable to La MaMa and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

 

Modern Living is a unique experience.

NYTheater.com called Post Modern Living
“the antidote for soulless synthetic musicals unspooling on Broadway”
and Martin Denton added “I loved this show.”  

Show Biz Weekly about our first edition Modern Living -
“See it with a handkerchief – as you are sure to tear up with laughter.” 

Karen Finley on he public radio show told her audience
“Everyone – go out and see this performance.”

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to get involved?  Volunteer - there are many ways you could help us out with out making a donation.  We are having events where more hands means a better time for everyone – and if you have any theatrical skills, let us know and step to the front of the line. 

Don’t live in NYC?  You can help us get the word out about the show – and forward this link to anyone who you might think would be interested. 

 

Performance Details

The Club at La MaMa
74 East 4th Street, 2nd floor
(between Bowery and Second Ave)
New York City

June 15th - July 1st
show times varry for details and tickets 
visit LAMAMA.ORG or call 212 475-7710

story:
Short Summary

We are The OG Crew aka The Original Gentlemen, an all male dance crew from Toronto, Ontario. We focus on crowd entertainment by bringing diverse choreography and a masculine flavour. 

We have qualified to compete and represent Canada at the World Street Dance Championships in Blackpool, England. There will be many other crews representing for their respective countries and we want to make sure that Canada has a crew to call their own.

 

What We Need

We are looking to raise $10,000, which is a portion of what we are going to need to be able to go. Any amount we recieve will help us get a step closer to going, so if we do not reach our intended goal, we are still hoping that with what we raise through here and from our other events that we will have enough to go.

If in the end we still don't have enough to go to England we are planning on traveling to the U.S. and compete over there. So either way we will be using the money to represent Canada outside of the country.

 

The Impact

Even though we are looking to represent Canada overseas, in the end we are really trying to represent for dance as an art form. We have always kept the crowd's entertainment in mind when we have a performance, because we want them to leave satisfied. We have been recognised as a very crowd pleasing dance crew and we have sworn to live by our name.. Original Gentlemen.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are trying to do as much other fundraising as possible by hosting workshops where people can come and learn from us. So if you are a dancer or even if you just want to learn how, it would be great to have you in our classes. We are also hosting parties where people can have a good time while remaining in a classy environment, afterall we are gentlemen.

If you can't make a donation, it would be great if you could pass this along to anybody you may know that would be willing to help us out.

story:
Why?

If you've ever been to OmCulture, whether it was for dancing, yoga,
concerts, or community events, you've made use of our floor. But
recently we've noticed the floor is splintering in places, making it
unsafe to dance and play on. It's time to fix the floor, and we're
asking the community to come together to help improve our space!

 

What's it going to cost?

We want to use Kempas for our new floor, a south east Asian hardwood
that will be durable, attractive, and most importantly, quick to
install. The Om Culture floor is a whopping 3,500 sq ft, and Kempas
costs $2.75/sq ft plus tax. We also have to install an underlayment,
which costs $0.40/sq ft. We will save some money by using volunteers
to assist in laying the floor, however we do need to hire a
professional to do the edging.

In sum:
$2.75 (the floor) * 3,500= $9,625
$0.40 (the underlayment) * 3,500= $1,400
Professional to install the edges: $2,000

Total Cost = $13,025

 

Other Ways you can Help:

Maybe money is tight but you still want to contribute? Or you just like working with your hands? To save on cost we will be installing the new floor ourselves. That means we need help (both skilled and unskilled labor) in order to make this project happen.

A couple hours of your time will help build something great! Send an email to saveourfeet@gmail.com to get on the volunteer crew or find out more.

story:
About Room to Live

The Room to Live plays are creating opportunities for BU actors, directors and playwrights. It is produced entirely because of the efforts and support of its creative team members… and hopefully you! Please consider making a donation of any size to our cause- believe me when I say every bit of support helps! $5 can help towards printing programs and posters, $20 can cover the cost of some props, $50 can cover set pieces. Please be a part of making the magic happen, and earn some thank-you prizes along the way!

The Plays

Homeland by Michael Parsons, directed by Kayla Prata

Where does a mistake end and treason begin?  This is the question haunting Reyes, a Marine Corps veteran and recluse who is content to live out her days in a one-bedroom apartment.  Her only contact with the outside world is Ruth, a volunteer for an outreach program for invalids.  Ruth has secrets of her own, and an agenda as deep as her Southern accent.  As both women reach out to each other — Ruth willingly, Reyes grudgingly — their pasts begin to creep into their private world and threaten to destroy them both.  Trust becomes the most precious commodity, and ideas of loyalty and honor come to the forefront in this one-set play.

not Jenny by MJ Halberstadt, directed by Hondo Weiss-Richmond

After thirteen years of estrangement, Not Jenny, a self-made travel writer, returns to her childhood home after learning her twin sister Jenny was paralyzed from the waist down in a car accident which also killed their mother. She stumbles into more sensitive territory than she bargained for as she attempts to reconcile the family’s difficult history, particularly when their younger brother Jimmy reopens old wounds and stands in the way of her ability to make amends. As Jenny unravels and Jimmy tempts Not Jenny with the prospect of escaping, Not Jenny’s compassion for both of her siblings is pushed to the limit.

Scene 8 by Rick Park, directed by Grant MacDermott

Mace wants nothing more in life than to become a famous actress. Her whole life has been filled with classes and lessons and auditions, leading her to what could be her big break: an audition for a show that is going to New York. At the audition, Mace nails it, until her twin brother Dixon interrupts her. To everyone’s surprise, Dixon is asked to audition as well, and when both are cast, everyone, including Mace’s gay roommate Seb, are ecstatic, until it comes to light that the brother and sister have been cast as husband and wife in a play that includes and explicit sex scene between them. When neither sibling will back down, they decide to get drunk and “go for it”. But while the liquor loosens them up, it also allows old secrets to bubble to the surface, leaving Mace, Dixon and Seb reeling by the end of the night.

Shoe Baby by Jaclyn Villano, directed by Jacob Titus

Zoe and Ethan Barnes are desperate to have a baby.  After their third miscarriage, Zoe is distraught and finds little comfort in anything besides a small stuffed bear named Sheldon.  The couple’s struggles lead them to Dr. Ava Maria Garza, a world-class fertility specialist who hates kids as much as she loves shoes.  When Dr. Garza’s treatment plan wreaks havoc on Zoe (and her marriage), Sheldon the Bear comes to the rescue… and comes to life as the son Zoe has always wanted.

Thursday, June 7: not Jenny @ 6, Shoe Baby @ 8:30
Friday, June 8: Homeland @ 6, not Jenny @ 9
Saturday, June 9: Shoe Baby @ 6, Scene 8 @ 9
Sunday, June 10: Scene 8 @ 1, Homeland @ 3
 
All performances are on the 3rd floor of the BU CFA building (855 Commonwealth Ave, Boston, MA).

story:
Our Story

We are the seventeen second-year actors at the American Repertory Theater/Moscow Art Theater School Institute for Advanced Theater Training at Harvard University: international, vibrant, diverse, and dedicated, we have spent the last two years creating a theatrical ensemble that can sing, dance, entertain audiences of all ages, recite Shakespeare, charm with Chekhov, and yes, even say a few Russian words along the way. The training that we have received is top-notch, and we are fortunate to be connected with two major cultural institutions--the American Repertory Theater and the Moscow Art Theater. The union of between the Institute and the Moscow Art Theater (MXAT) has created a historic program that provides unparalleled opportunities for training and growth, making our Institute's program one of the top ten graduate theater programs in the United States.

The two-year Institute curriculum combines study in Cambridge, Massachusetts with a three-month residency at the Moscow Art Theater. We began our training in mid-July in Cambridge and spent the spring of our first year in Moscow, and returned to Cambridge for the fall and spring of our second year. In Moscow, we take classes with prominent members and actors of the Russian theater community, as well as join the spring repertory of the theater with our own production. In Cambridge, we play an integral role in the A.R.T. community, working alongside the professional acting company and guest artists in both rehearsals and the classroom. Throughout this season, we have had the opportunity to perform in two ART mainstage productions, The Snow Queen and As You Like It.

The wide range of courses given by the international faculty gives us unique preparation for the multi-faceted demands of the professional theater. The Institute program simultaneously respects the great traditions of the past and encourages the development of new ideas and forms of expression. Our program is rigorous and requires complete dedication and commitment to honing our skills as performers. We are in classes and rehearsals thirteen hours a day, six days a week.

Some of the classes we take:

Russian Acting (Etude work and ensemble building)

Russian movement

Voice

Shakespeare

Speech

Jazz

Modern

Social Dance

Ballet

Fencing

Stage Combat

Strength Conditioning

Choreography and Audition Preparation

Singing Technique

Singing and Music Theory

Singing Repertory

Acting (Practical Aesthetics)

Acting (Outside/In)

Alexander Technique

Rhythm

 

The Impact

We now find ourselves at a new crossroads; at the end of our two years, we will be traveling to New York and Los Angeles to perform for industry professionals. This showcase will help us transition into the professional acting community, but we need a way to get there. That's where you come in!

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Any size donation is greatly appreciated. Our goal is to raise $6,000, ensuring air fare to Los Angeles for each classmate. Don't forget to check out the perks for each level of donation!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about our program and our cause! Help foster the new generation of artists!

story:
Our
Story
Darren Garraghan (Creative Producer)
A trained actor. He has worked in theatre professionally in its various forms for over three years, before re-acquainting his love for horror. He has worked in various Scare Attractions throughout the UK. He enjoys creating and developing the Mazes alongside Seb, but loves bringing in his performance experience to train the actors as well as scare the guests himself. He is currently dedicating most of his time to the company. He has just finished writing KSA's latest play (Buried), which will be touring the UK from 2012.

Seb Blaber
(Designer/Producer)
A trained theatre technician. Seb has worked professionally in London for over three years, covering many disciplines in the technical world. He is currently the lighting designer for 'Theatre of the Damned'. Only two years ago Seb was scared of anything and everything; but as is the 'business' he followed where the work was; and now his whole life revolves
around horror. He loves designing scare attractions. He takes what he has learnt throughout his years as a theatre technician to produce technically brilliant visuals and sound for the mazes. He loves creating something that he knows will make guests jump on every corner.

What are Scare Attractions?
Scare attractions are something that started in the USA and are known as
Haunted Attractions. They are terrifying  theatrical experiences in which
guests move through themed environments. These are created for the sole purpose
of taking the guests out of their comfort zones. They use theatrical lighting,
sound and special effects; add to this the professionally trained 'Scare
Actors' and it will create a truly hair-raising experience.

What you can expect within a maze?
Of course without giving away too many surprises: guests will walk through
the maze in small groups, encountering various 'Horror themes'. The mazes will
usually be in almost complete darkness, immediately increasing the feeling of
anticipation and decreasing the feeling of comfort. They will be confronted by
talented 'Scare Actors' who enjoy nothing more than making you feel uneasy.
They will appear in the darkness in the blink of an eye, and seemingly appear
to vanish just as quickly. Add the theatrical lighting, sound and special
effects, and you are guaranteed a disorientating yet brilliantly miserable
time. 

The
Impact 
With your funding, we hope to reach our target of £5000. With this we can
purchase our first outdoor, transferable venue. We will be looking to spend
£1500-£2000 on a Large Marquee. With this we will be able to tour around the
festivals and be able to commit to more Events. At this current point in time
we are relying on people giving us a venue as well as hiring us. 
We will be looking to spend £1500-£2000 on set. Currently we are hiring sets
from other companies. We would like to be completely self-sufficient. We will
be buying Fence panels, wall flats and themed dressing with this.
With the remainder of the money (£1000 -£2000) we will focusing on the
marketing and storage side of the company. We will be buying merchandise
(T.Shirts, Mugs and pens etc), a HD camera and computer. We will also be
investing in a storage for our set.
With this campaign we are sure that it will develop the company into realms of
success that due to financial situations we cant currently make. The mazes will
be of a much higher standard. We have visions for a full-time Horror Themed
Attraction, complete with mazes, fairground rides and much more. 
If the campaign is unsuccessful we will still strive to bring this new type of
entertainment to the masses. It is a passion of ours, and in two years we have
been successful; but due to finances we cant further the buisness into the
success we know it will be.

 

What
you get
$10 will get you on the VIP mailing list and a special thanks on our
website.
$25 will get you on the VIP mailing list, a special thanks on our website and
free entry for you and one other to a maze of your choice.
$40 will get you on the VIP mailing list, a special thanks on our website, free
entry to all KSA mazes for 12 months. A Kernow scare attractions T.Shirt and a
mug.
$80 will get you on the VIP mailing list, a personal letter of thanks from the
Creative team. Free entry to all KSA mazes for 24 months. 2 T.shirts and a mug.
$150 will instantly make you an assistant producer. You will get all of the
above perks. You will be mentioned in high regard on our website
and Facebook and throughout the rest of the campaign. You will also
be invited to a one day intensive Scare Acting course. As well as this you will
receive 2 T.Shirts and 2 mugs. (Travel and accommodation will not be
provided for the scare acting course, but food and drink will be). 
$250 will instantly make you an Executive Producer. You will be mentioned on
all advertising and promotions, as well as the website. You will get a personal
letter of thanks, and will be allowed free entry to all
mazes indefinitely. You will also be invited to a one day intensive Scare
Acting course. You will receive 2 T.shirts and 2 mugs. As an executive producer
you will be informed of all 'Top Secret' information and also invited to work
in one of our mazes for a day. (Travel and accommodation will not be provided
for the scare acting course, but food and drink will be).
 Kernow Scare Attractions thank you even for your time. We understand this type
of entertainment will not appeal to everyone, but we do ask from the deepest of
our most passionate hearts, to please make people aware of what we are trying
to create and achieve. We do hope you will follow us on facebook, and please
check in often to see how we are developing and where our next venture is. Once
again Thank you.

story:
You want us and you CAN handle us.

We are The TRUF.  

 

What is The TRUF?

We are a theater company with a mission:  to share stories among people, with a focus on bridging the generations.  

We produce two shows at a time in repertory, an "adult" show and a "children's" show, both centered around one theme.  With your help, we're hoping to pair Frank McGuiness's Someone Who'll Watch Over Me with a brand new commission by the talented EJC Calvert that is based off the tales of Scheherazade, Sarazad and the Monster King.  The two share a theme of...you guessed it, storytelling.

Throughout history, sharing our stories has been a means of survival. Just as the three prisoners of war in Someone share their stories with each other to stave off insanity, Sarazad lives through her stories to escape from and eventually learn to face a tough reality.

 

Where can one find the TRUF?

The TRUF can be found sharing stories among people, countries, and generations.  

Oh. You mean literally? Well then, in this particular instance, we can be found at the Canal Park Playhouse in New York City, gearing up for our productions of Someone Who'll Watch Over Me and Sarazad and the Monster King.  

 

Why does the TRUF even matter these days? 

We believe that truth grows from a seed of trust, and trust comes from sharing our stories. In our rapidly changing world, our ability to effectively communicate with those of a different generation has atrophied to a state of disrepair.  Through effectively engaging audiences young and old in the simplest and most direct form of entertainment, storytelling, we can begin to bridge the gap...

 

Nothing in NYC is free. Ain't that The TRUF? 

We need your help to raise $8,000 so that we can bring these dreams to life. Your generosity will help us to pay for everything from the beautiful space at The Canal Park Playhouse to the very rights required to use our brilliant playwrights' words. 

With each donation level, not only are you thanked with everything from our undying devotion to VIP Behind the Scenes Access, but you walk away knowing that you are  responsible for sponsoring a very specific aspect of this process.

Our hope is to reach 1,000 people willing to "don8" just $8 to our campaign, so please pass this along to anyone and everyone you can. From your grandmother to your barber, we'd love to share our story with them. Strength in numbers, my friend. 

From the bottom of our hearts, we thank you.


And that's The TRUF. (It will set you free!)

story:
Our Story

In short: 

We're a group of diverse theatre artists who are adapting Coleridge's famous poem The Rime of the Ancient Mariner into a contemporary theatrical production that delves into modern issues of war, destruction and the environment. We have a co-production lined up with Guelph Little Theatre for July 7-9 (2011), following which we will be mounting the production in Toronto, venue TBD. We are also looking to tour this project to schools, where we can help a younger generation access dense "academic" text and explore ways in which it is currently relevant.


To go further into it:

The performance aims to deconstruct urban images in a natural setting and explore themes of isolation and redemption. Through the eyes of six students with their six desks and six chairs, the world painted by Coleridge will be manifested and adapted. In that journey, the goal is to analyze the chemical and emotional response to drug euphoria and subsequent depression of the poet which followed his life after this work.

 

Though the opiate illusion stands as the framework of the piece, the true story remains as in the poem. It is the struggle of realism and the supernatural, creation of man and creation of nature and the conflict of the two coexisting. Those embarking on that journey have been hand selected performers from various training backgrounds and walks of life. Emily Nixon is a classically trained performer whose workshops in India for Shakespeare performance have lead to great recognition abroad. Andrew Pimento is highly active in Queer Cab and works often with independent companies around the city, he also is a first year acting student at Ryerson Theatre School. Emily Hughes is a Ryerson Graduate with an extensive background in aerial performance art, working as a contemporary circus artist and in the independent theatre scene of Toronto. Graeme Black Robinson is just starting education with George Brown College in tandem with Soulpepper Theatre and has advanced training in puppetry and Pachinko clown with focus on musical theatre.  Virgilia Ashton is a Caribbean -Canadian performer with heavy training in movement and body, and Eve Wylden is a veteran performer of the Toronto Indie scene having trained at University of Toronto, she has worked in numerous Summerworks shows and world premieres of works including Miss Toronto.


The director, Joseph Pagnan, uses a style of work that often embodies a highly stylized reality in both visually demanding scenography and high physical and rigid movement.  He is a huge supporter of blind casting and throughout the duration of the production each role will be explored by both male and female performers; questioning the role of gender in the performing arts and the empowerment of storytelling as a vehicle to break boundaries of both societal normative and perceived notion.


What We Need & What You Get

In total, we are looking to raise $5000 just to cover production costs of sets, rigging and costumes. This will give us the foundation we need to go into our co-production and come out with some money to rent a venue in Toronto.

In addition to discounted tickets to the show in Guelph, we are offering unique incentives like aerial lessons. Take a look.


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends!

Come out to our performance fundraiser on April 16th at HerciniArts studio (51 Jefferson Ave) in Liberty Village, Toronto!
story_txt:
Our Story

In short: 
We're a group of diverse theatre artists who are adapting Coleridge's famous poem The Rime of the Ancient Mariner into a contemporary theatrical production that delves into modern issues of war, destruction and the environment. We have a co-production lined up with Guelph Little Theatre for July 7-9 (2011), following which we will be mounting the production in Toronto, venue TBD. We are also looking to tour this project to schools, where we can help a younger generation access dense "academic" text and explore ways in which it is currently relevant.

To go further into it:
The performance aims to deconstruct urban images in a natural setting and explore themes of isolation and redemption. Through the eyes of six students with their six desks and six chairs, the world painted by Coleridge will be manifested and adapted. In that journey, the goal is to analyze the chemical and emotional response to drug euphoria and subsequent depression of the poet which followed his life after this work.

story:
Our Story

My name is Art Shulman. I'm planning to produce a play I've written called NOT ONE MORE FOOT OF LAND!  It will be performed at the Secret Rose Theater in the Los Angeles area.  Kristina Lloyd is the Director, an award winning stage and film director.

 

The play opens in February,  and we'd love you to be a part of it.

 NOT ONE MORE FOOT OF LAND!  follows the life of the most controversial Cherokee Indian who ever lived, a man still considered a traitor by many in his tribe, but a savior by others.

 His name was Major Ridge, and he lived through one of the most shameful episodes in our nation's history, an event called The Trail of Tears, in which the United States government forced the Cherokee tribe to move from their ancestral lands in the South to west of the Mississippi. 

 Imagine that! A whole tribe, thousands of people, not allowed to stay in their homes and on their land, but evicted through military force. It actually happened, in the mid-1800's. Thousands of Cherokee perished on this long and often wintry journey.

 We've lined up some terrific actors, including many fine Native-American actors, and we intend to put up a first class production that will run for 8 weeks and hopefully will gain attention because it covers how our nation, at one point in its past, dealt with a minority group that was "inconvenient" to the majority population.

 So, please support our production of NOT ONE MORE FOOT OF LAND!.

 

 

It is gonna be a great show!

 

The Impact

This is an important story we are telling. It is based on a life of the most controversial Cherokee who ever lived.  It describes how he was involved in a shameless episode in out nation's history -- the forced removal of Native-Americans from the land they'd lived on for centuries to other land a thousand miles away.

What We Need & What You Get

NOT ONE MORE FOOT OF LAND! is expensive to produce. It is costly to rent a theater and rehearsal space (about $10,000), to pay actors and a crew even small amounts ($3,000), build a set ($1,500), provide costumes ($1,000), advertise the show ($2,000), and so on. So, the project can use your financial support.

We can provide you with some rewards based on your contribution. For example:

If you donate $10 or more, we'll mention you in our program.

If you donate $20 or more, we'll do that, and send you a signed copy of the program.

If you donate $50 or more we'll do all that, and email you a pdf of the script.

If you donate $100 or more, we'll do all that, and invite you to attend a rehearsal, and give you a complimentary VIP ticket to the performance.


Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to donating to our production you can help us by publicizing our project. If you think our project deserves support so may you friends, family, and associates.

story:
Our Story

7 Towers began in 2010 as a collaboration between an actor and a dramaturg, both interested in the basic relationship between text, performer, and audience. Placing a particular emphasis on honest communication, we value fundamental methods of storytelling over expensive spectacle.

 

7 Towers is dedicated to making theatre that challenges the status quo, both in content and in production style. We seek to produce both new and classic plays that ask exhaustive and probing questions about the society we live in and the function of art within it. We are not interested in asking questions we already know the answers to. We believe that exploring contemporary experience through direct, honest, and often irreverent storytelling can open live theatre to new and diverse audiences. Whenever possible, we produce in non-traditional venues and areas that are not already saturated with live performance, thus creating opportunities for interaction with new communities.

 

We are motivated by what Martha Graham describes as a “queer, divine dissatisfaction, a blessed unrest that keeps us marching and makes us more alive.” Our fundamental vision is of a theatrical process that searches for precise and deep truth, deeper than what the average person, or even the average artist will accept as sufficient.

 

7 Towers is a sponsored project of Austin Creative Alliance, a non-profit arts service organization.

 

The Project

Our first full season kicks off with a production of Lanford Wilson’s Burn This, December 2-18. The play is an often funny, often heartbreaking look into the human soul after a tragic loss. It deals with the aftermath of a dancer’s death for his roommate, a struggling New York choreographer, and his brother, a hard-edged restaurant manager from New Jersey. Burn This is a play that speaks to the realities of living in a less than ideal world, and finding moments of beauty within it. It’s about the artist’s place within the community. To that end, we’re producing Burn This in the City View Terrace at Ballet Austin. This non-traditional space allows us connection to the larger Austin arts community as well as to the downtown business community that surrounds both our production space and the lives of the characters in the play.  

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to get this first production off the ground! Besides production rights ($600+) and production space ($1000+), we need to provide costumes, set pieces to turn Ballet Austin's space into a New York loft, advertising/marketing costs and stipends for our professionally trained artistic and production teams. (Sadly, we'll never be able to afford to pay these fantastically talented people what they're worth, but you can help us to at least show some appreciation for the time, effort, and passion they've given us!) For your help, we'd love to give you some perks (see the sidebar), and an engaging, thought-provoking night of theatre!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out! Send our campaign to your friends, family members, and anyone who acknowledges the vital role the arts play for all of us!

story:
Short Summary

  • We are a new NOT FOR PROFIT 501(c)3 theatre company who hope to do entertaining but thought-provoking theatre that reflect on society today though older neglected works as well as new offerings .
  • The campaign is to help us raise the needed funds to pay for theatre rental for the run of the show .
  • You donations ,however large or small, help bring us closer to bringing quality ENTERTAINING yet THOUGHT PROVOKING theatre at reasonable prices to audiences .We also hope to bring these works  to many who could be enriched by the stories but who perhaps have trouble affording the Arts .


What We Need & What You Get


  • Right now the amount we are asking for is for theatre rental in NYC. As many know, prices in NYC are among the highest in the world.This is one reason Broadway ticket prices are so high and producers are less willing to take chances on socially  relevant productions . We want to make theatre AFFORDABLE, entertaining yet provocative  and stimulating mentally .We also set aside certain performances for those who can least afford theatre tickets (homeless, vets, certain estranged social groups ) as well as educational facilities. 
  • At various levels of donations  , you will get show tickets , listings in our show programs ,our web page and facebook page,invitations to special events (our first fundraiser had SIR DEREK JACOBI as a guest), private dinners and more.
  • Whatever funds we raise on this campaign go towards the theatre rental.Any amounts over go towards printing and advertising costs(the more we raise, the better our ad campaign). 

  • The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Right now there is very little affordable theatre that is also thought provoking. 
  • Many of our board are actively involved in professional theatre , both on stage and off .
  • We have a wonderful show, a marvelous actor, enthusiasm-what we most need are you, your support on spreading the word, and your donation if possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We need people to work our show ,technicians, crafts people, musicians and front of house staff .
  • use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
The Dance Begins... 

Zdravo! Bonjour! Mwaramutse! Hello!

I’m Tessa Adzemovic and I recently graduated from the University of Michigan.

I have been dancing since I was five years old. At the U of M, I was the co-president of Salto Dance Company, a student-run and funded lyrical and ballet dance group.

Every year, Salto donates 50% of its show’s proceeds to a non-profit, and this year we donated to the Rebecca Davis Dance Company, whose mission is to use dance to advance the lives of children in post ethnic conflict and developing countries.  

In June I travelled to Rwanda with RDDC, and taught dance to former street boys. There I saw the potential for dance to change student’s lives. One of the boys, Moise, told me his story.

The General

 Moise left his father’s home because his stepmother physically abused him. In search of a birth mother he had never known, he lived on the streets for a year, sleeping underneath highways and scrounging for food.

The other kids called Moise “The General.” He had been chief of a street gang: charged with controlling the younger kids and their drug trade. When he arrived to Kigali, his mother refused to take him in. Devastated, Moise, escorted by the police, was taken to the re-integration center where I taught dance.

Moise was warm and generous, sharing his story candidly. Dance has transformed his life. He is now disciplined and motivated, and knows that if he works hard, he may someday go to school.

In talking to Moise, I realized the harsh reality of a child growing up in a post-genocide society.

Why do I need your financial support?

To create a dance program in Mostar, Bosnia an ethnically divided town, to help students like Moise, but in Eastern Europe. Mostar is split between East and West, with Bosnians living on the East side and Croatians living on the West.

In October, I will be part of a dance teacher training program, along with two Rwandan teachers, two Ukrainian teachers, and another American teacher. Starting in November, I will start to implement my own project.

The money donated will go to:

·  Dance studio rental

·  Music system

·  Portable ballet bar

·  Administrative support

·  Books

·  Costumes

Dance has been linked with culture and humanity for centuries. It evokes many moods and emotions, expressing values that can bind communities together. Dance and the arts in general have a role to play in international reconciliation.

I really appreciate your support and I cannot wait to update you on my progress bridging the youth of Mostar. Please get the word out and share my campaign with others.

Hvala! Merci! Thank you!

story:
Support The Arc- Top Girls

The Arc Theatre has been creating provocative, professional and vital theater in the Chicago Storefront Community for 5 years.  Forging a path for ourselves through a commitment to artistic craft, we have single-handedly grown from a small one-weekend production on the side of a hill to a full season of productions that showcase the craft of theater-making.  We are proud to have increased our visibility and reputation among the hottest Chicago Theater Artists and have brought a top-notch team to our most ambitious production yet.  Top Girls is Sexy, Intense, Hilarious and Bold- and features the talents of Chicago Artists you ought to know. 

After 5 years of proving ourselves and sharing our art, we are embarking upon our first fundraising campaign. The conservatively created budget for "Top GIrls" is over 3 times the budget of any of our previous shows.  If you've been able to see our work, we hope you think we've earned the right to ask for your hard-earned money. Help us bring it to life and support theater that outperforms our budget, every time.  Visit our website to learn more about our company and this amazing Chicago production.

Top Girls is directed by Arc Artistic Director Mark Boergers and features Patricia Lavery as Marlene, Pamela Mae Davis, Meg Elliott, Aislinn Kerchaert, Tyler Meredith, Robyn Novak, Kelsey Phillips, Natalie Sallee, Kate Smith and Lana Smithner.  Production Team includes Set Design byArc Co-Founder Cailin Short, Stage Manager Belinda Bing, Costume Designer Catharine Young, Lighting Designer Jason Hiett, Sound Designer Matt Reich, Costume Assistant Castile Ritter, Assistant Director Katrina Dion and Dialect Coach David Schlumpf. 


Our Goals: Top Girls is a unique production for the Arc and our most ambitious yet.  Every part of the process has been stretched and strengthened to new heights while still retaining our unique brand of specificity and storytelling that we have become known for.  After 5 years of gaining a reputation for quality work and adding to our team of accomplished, intelligent artists- its time to grow.  We believe there is no limit to what we can do with the gifts we have been given. 

The Arc needs increased visibility in the Chicago Theater community including play from critics and theater publications as well as the Jeff Awards and other award-granting entities.  Moreover, the Arc would like to find a home base- a place that can become an artistic home to both the Arc and the community- a social and artistic hub of commiseration and conversation that is fostered by our unique process and vibrant productions.   The Arc has spent five years creating productions that are visceral to both artist and audience member alike.  It is time to step forward and achieve our goals on a professional scale. 

Reality

The missing piece in The Arc's journey thus far has been fundraising and support.   This has been intentional- we wanted to make sure we were committed to our process and our people before we asked for patron's hard-earned cash to help our cause.  We can confidently say that we are sure and we are ready to leap forward in our professional goals.  

Good theater takes money.  Our boundless creativity has allowed us to prove we can outperform our budget, whatever it may be.  We use money well.  But theater on the level that we believe we deserve to be at takes a good amount of capital and generous support from those who appreciate quality art.   Without a healthy dose of financial support we will not be able to move on to the next stage in our journey and continue to provide high quality theater experiences to the community. We will not gain the visibility we deserve in the intensely competitive Chicago market without financial backing to our unique creativity. It is time. We are ready. Help us show everyone what we can really do. 

It starts with Top Girls, it Starts with YOU. 

This show is a beacon of what's to come with The Arc.  We are chomping at the bit to share it with you.  If you can't make a financial donation, why not at least help us get the word out about our campaign and the show itself?  There is always information available at arctheatrechicago.org and feel free to like us on facebook and join our mailing list.  Our first goal is always to engage people to embark upon a story with us.  Curious?  Come check us out.

Top Girls is directed by Arc Artistic Director Mark Boergers and features Patricia Lavery as Marlene, Pamela Mae Davis, Meg Elliott, Aislinn Kerchaert, Tyler Meredith, Robyn Novak, Kelsey Phillips, Natalie Sallee, Kate Smith and Lana Smithner.  Production Team includes Set Design byArc Co-Founder Cailin Short, Stage Manager Belinda Bing, Costume Designer Catharine Young, Lighting Designer Jason Hiett, Sound Designer Matt Reich, Costume Assistant Castile Ritter, Assistant Director Katrina Dion and Dialect Coach David Schlumpf. 


Our Goals: Top Girls is a unique production for the Arc and our most ambitious yet.  Every part of the process has been stretched and strengthened to new heights while still retaining our unique brand of specificity and storytelling that we have become known for.  After 5 years of gaining a reputation for quality work and adding to our team of accomplished, intelligent artists- its time to grow.  We believe there is no limit to what we can do with the gifts we have been given. 


The Arc needs increased visibility in the Chicago Theater community including play from critics and theater publications as well as the Jeff Awards and other award-granting entities.  Moreover, the Arc would like to find a home base- a place that can become an artistic home to both the Arc and the community- a social and artistic hub of commiseration and conversation that is fostered by our unique process and vibrant productions.   The Arc has spent five years creating productions that are visceral to both artist and audience member alike.  It is time to step forward and achieve our goals on a professional scale. 
    Reality The missing piece in The Arc's journey thus far has been fundraising and support.   This has been intentional- we wanted to make sure we were committed to our process and our people before we asked for patron's hard-earned cash to help our cause.  We can confidently say that we are sure and we are ready to leap forward in our professional goals.  
Good theater takes money.  Our boundless creativity has allowed us to prove we can outperform our budget, whatever it may be.  We use money well.  But theater on the level that we believe we deserve to be at takes a good amount of capital and generous support from those who appreciate quality art.   Without a healthy dose of financial support we will not be able to move on to the next stage in our journey and continue to provide high quality theater experiences to the community. We will not gain the visibility we deserve in the intensely competitive Chicago market without financial backing to our unique creativity. It is time. We are ready. Help us show everyone what we can really do. 
    It starts with Top Girls, it Starts with YOU.  This show is a beacon of what's to come with The Arc.  We are chomping at the bit to share it with you.  If you can't make a financial donation, why not at least help us get the word out about our campaign and the show itself?  There is always information available at arctheatrechicago.org and feel free to like us on facebook and join our mailing list.  Our first goal is always to engage people to embark upon a story with us.  Curious?  Come check us out.

story:
"A Backstage Look at 'Red'" video by Jake Jarvis originally published July 23, 2014, in the Daily Athanaeum.
Used with permission.

The Monongalia Arts Center's summer production of John Logan's RED will compete at the West Virginia Theatre Association's Community Theatre Festival on Saturday, November 8th

Co-directed by and co-starring Morgantown directors/actors David Beach and Shenendoah Thompson, John Logan's Tony-award winning play, RED, follows the artist Mark Rothko and his assistant, Ken, as they prepare the murals for the Four Seasons Restaurant in New York City in the late 1950s.

The original production ran in July, and the MAC invited the production to be entered into the WV Theatre Association's Community Theatre Festival. The Festival's winning production will represent West Virginia at the Southeastern Theatre Conference's Community Theatre Festival in March 2015.

This year's festival is close-by in Bridgeport, but taking the production on the road requires additional funding, not supported by ticket sales.

Here's where you can help!

What We Need & What You Get

To attend the West Virginia Community Theatre Festival will cost the MAC $600. (If it takes first place, attending the Southeastern Theatre Conference Festival will cost approximately $3,000, but we'll cross that bridge if we get there!) As a non-profit center, we rely on grants and donations to support the Center.

  • Expenses include the following: rights to perform the play; WVTA registration; transportation for cast, crew and set; additional props (such as canvas and paints).
  • Those who can help us achieve our goal will be invited to attend an open rehearsal of the production on Friday, November 7th, the night before competition, at the MAC. Following the rehearsal, you'll have a chance to meet and talk with the cast and crew.
  • If we don't reach our total campaign goal, all funds will go towards expenses.
  • If we exceed our total campaign goal, excess funds will be earmarked for future MACplayers productions.

The Impact

Community theatre is alive and well in West Virginia, and the MACplayers is just one of several community theatres in Morgantown that offer performances of cutting-edge works like Red. Recognition on the state level and the regional level helps elevate the performing arts in our community!

story:
Our Story

Hello! My name is Rhea and I am a member of Simone Sobers Dance, a NYC based contemporary dance company. We have recently been invited to present our work in Sweden at the Stockholm Fringe Festival. This will be the company's premiere of our new installation piece "Kaged"-a performance work about unleashing stories of women of color. So we are raising money to help cover travel costs and accommodations.

The Impact

This is a unique opportunity for the company as it will allow us to share our work at a prestigious international festival and create a cross-cultural dialogue about womens issues/stories through the art of dance.


What We Need & What You Get

Each member of the company is aiming to raise $1200 to cover costs of travel and accommodations. All funds that you donate will go directly towards my personal travel costs and accommodations for this trip.


Other Ways You Can Help

Help spread the word by passing on the link to others you think would be interested in supporting this dream of ours!

story:
Gathering Wild Presents Circa'50 at the 14th St Playhouse on January 24 & 25th @ 8pm

(there will be a special family version performed Saturday at 2 pm)

About Gathering Wild and Circa '50:

For nearly fifteen years we have been creating original work that connects people to important and resonate moments. Audiences seek to engage in a performance through a multi faceted sensory experience. We want to raise money for this show in order to take our work to another level, and we need your support!

Circa '50 is a visceral multi media dance event with original live music, projected images, and dynamic physical theatre, that breaks into and redefines with grace and humor, the engineered world of the 1950s, challenging the root of a culture bound by McCarthyism, segregation, the Cold War and essentially; the American dream.

Our story teller, "the housewife", is a woman shaped and altered by the dictates of the 1950's cultural expectations. She serves as a sensory lens in which the audience experiences the era. She shares the stage with the dancers, and as they weave in and out of one anothers stories, we find the glory and terror of the time as both beautiful and strangely haunting - and shockingly parallel to our world today.

Jerylann Warner's beautiful and unique contemporary choreography, set to iconic songs like Johnny Be Good and Mr. Sandman, brings an entirely new perspective to the music. The movement tells the story of each artist and their time period with a fresh eye. There is great liveliness to all the work in the show - but these paradoxes within are what makes the show and it's story new and unique.

Images from Gathering Wild's Circa '50

photo credit bcarrworks

To BUY TICKETS to Circa 50' click here:

https://www.woodruffcentertickets.org/village2/ticket/production_detail.aspx?perf=71957

So Why Do We Need Your Help?

This show is bigger and more technologically complex than any show Gathering Wild has ever done. We have more costs than ever to achieve such an undertaking. Theater rental alone costs nearly $6,000. Tickets sales bring in less than half of that amount! Throw in set, costume, designers, technicians, house managers and printing costs and you have an idea of why we need you!

With great gratitude we accept any and all donations to make this visionary show come to life.

Why Do Circa '50?

Gathering Wild does a full-length show annually. Artistic Director Jerylann Warner has brought many artists into her working circle for this production (including two pieces by choreographer Bubba Carr of bcarrworks, live original music by Colin Agnew, costumes by Sharon Miller, and photography by Larry Holland). While Circa '50 is based entirely around her choreography, the music and artists that inspired it, with the aid of Amber Bradshaw, a theatre director and dramaturg, Jerylann has weaved together a production that is beyond dance and more than theatre.

While delving into the fascinating and enveloping world of the 1950s, we discovered that much of what began then, still resonates today! We wanted to put what we saw as parallels, both stunningly beautiful and discomforting, on the stage for all to see.

We hope you'll help bring the 50s to life! We can't do this without you. Thank you so much for considering a donation to Gathering Wild's Circa 50.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that you may not have the money to support us, but you have time or will or perhaps a skill we can use! Please let us know if there is anything in particular you'd like to do for us (besides getting the word out of course!).

Photo and Lead Video Credit: bcarrworks

Second Video credit and campaign created by: Amber Bradshaw

To BUY TICKETS to Circa 50' click here

https://www.woodruffcentertickets.org/village2/ticket/production_detail.aspx?perf=71957

story:
Our Story

Bodies in Motion is the brainchild of dancer/choreographer Brigette Dunn-Korpela and film director Drew McClellan. It is a dance/film short that explores the natural beauty and terrain of the human body and desert landscape. It will be filmed on location in the desert this summer 2011. 

The Impact

Will promote an understanding and appreciation of how the human form and earth are connected. A creative exploration of our human relationship to the land.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1500.00 to produce and complete the project.  Money will be used to pay dancers, film crew, post production, lodging, equipment and any other incidentals needed to create this film. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us achieve our goal by spreading the word.

story:
The Path:
 It is with great love, passion and ambition that I have traveled this extraordinary journey with Zelda Sayre Fitzgerald. I have so many people to thank for their contribution and support. I have yet one more dream to fulfill: bringing "Zelda" to the international stage of the Fringe Festival in Edinburgh, Scotland in August 2012.

 

The Mission:
This mission is two-fold. First, to honor Zelda through educating others to the life and talents of Zelda Fitzgerald. Second, to showcase my my own work and talents through her life and words. Performing in Scotland puts me in a community of my peers as well as an international audience that can provide great avenues for future creative work. I believe we must each create our own possibilities to live our dreams and it takes a community, a village as they say, to help us along the way.

 

Your Donations:
Funding for this project will go towards theatre rental, Fringe Festival registration, airfare from the West Coast to Scotland, advertising at the festival, programs, and room and board.

 

The Reviews:
â€œThe captivating delivery of the dense, colorful prose envoked empathy and shame for not having appreciated Zelda's independent contribution to the arts, and here Ms Paulette delivers on her mission."

-John Wallingford, Coolin Community Center - Coolin, Idaho

 

â€œWith just simple gestures and facial expressions, Paulette does a wonderful job of walking us down memory lane of Zeldaâ€™s life, leading us through her naively idealistic years as a teenager in Montgomery, Alabama, wild and rebellious days in New York and the sophisticated and angst-ridden time in France. Paulette brings Zelda to life, and shows us a vulnerable, articulate, creative, intelligent but tormented woman."

-Ian McCarthy, Capital Hill Times, Seattle, WA

 

â€œPaulette delivers a performance that is transformative and emotional, traveling through a life by the carriages of story and flashback. To watch Paulette in this role, you abandon a simple admiration for her talent and become transfixed by the voices, the characterizations, and the places Paulette must take herself to deliver such an emotional journey for those in attendance.â€

-Michael Ward, River Current News, Carnation, WA

 

Viewings:
 To see three minutes of the show please visit www.denisepaulette.com. To view photos and audience feedback please go to www.facebook.com/ZeldaFitzgeraldOnstage.

Thank you for viewing this fundraiser and see you in Scotland!

story:
Pro is a short work that was featured at the Redcat Theater as part of The Next Dance Company at Calarts. While creating this piece I had begun following the issues surrounding women in our country and was inspired to create an empowering piece.  I feel compelled to dig deeper into the subject matter concerning women's rights and the threats to women's health care and freedom. 

With this project I plan to develop and expand Pro, giving it a new life.   I will be collaborating with composer Peter Gonzales, actress/dancer Veline Mojarro and writer/composer Daniella Lollie.  This new work is to be a piece that challenges the Catholic ideals I have grown up with and the fears I have as a woman in America.  The backlash on women's rights has just recently dawned on me. I used to ignore the unfortunate reality that older feminist influences had tried to pass down to me because I was too young to understand what these women were talking about.  This piece is to reflect the fight for control over our own bodies. While bills and laws are being passed that take away basic health care and fair wages to women, because we are seen as different, I have decided to take upon this subject matter as my first big project. As long as women are seen as inherently different, they will be treated that way.       

August 17, 18

ARC Performance Space in Pasadena 

Dancers: Chelsea Yarnell, Lexi Gibbons, Chrissy Caimares, Megan McCarthy, Olivia Goldberg, Veline Cepeida-Mojarro, Lorrin Hilton, Amanda McNussen, Bianca Mendoza

Music: Peter Gonzales, Daniella Lollie

Lighting: Andrew Munie

With your donations and support I will be able to pay the dancers, musicians, lighting designer and other aspects of production. Please help contribute to this cause and support dance in the community.  Anything helps!

Thank You!

lollieworks.org
