story:
Our Story

Actors Company of Tulsa is a new theatre company in the Tulsa area. We are dedicated to the education of the theatrical artist, connection with local business and the community and productions of quality that entertain, inform, and enlighten the city of Tulsa. About two years ago, we decided that Angels in America would be the show we would love to do because of it's timeliness and it's themes and issues. We felt that the themes dealt with in this production would resonate in the heartland of America and at this time, we feel it's an important show. We feel that our production of Angels in America will open the eyes and hearts and realize the struggles of these people in this wonderful story by Tony Kushner.

The Impact

Angels in America by Tony Kushner has been performed in almost every major city in the world, but has never been performed in Tulsa. Tony Kushner came to visit last year and spoke to the city and ignited a fire in a lot of us to tell this story that centers around the Aids Crisis in the Regan era, but also spans every single type of person that is affected by this community. This is a story of people with problems, and this is a story of hope. We hope that this production will inspire the community and the people of Tulsa that entertainment can also inform and enlighten the world.

What We Need & What You Get

We are going to need around $12,000 for the total budget of Angels in America. This money will go to the set costs, theatre costs, lighting costs, sound costs, and the rising theatrical rentals that will be needed to secure our space. From this campaign, we are hoping to raise $5000 dollars from online sources. This will allow us to have a good jumpstart from a grass roots campaign, and if we raise more money through this production, all the proceeds will go to the show. The budget is as follows:

“Angels in American Part 1”
 
Budget: 
Marketing $700 
Rights $900 (8 shows) 
Performance Space $4,800 
Costumes $500 
Properties $500 
Set $500
 
Salaries: 
Director $750 
Producer $500 
Stage Manager $250 
Lighting Designer $200 
Costume Designer $200 
Set Designer $200 
Sound Designer $200 
Actors $2,000 (to be divided)
  
Total: $12,200


 

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell everyone you know about this campaign. Tell your friends. Get the word out. We need to know that you support what we are doing because this is going to be amazingly hard to accomplish. But WE can do it. WE can make this happen in our city. And you can be a part of it. Post it everywhere, your facebook, your blog, your groups. Get a group of people to each pledge $1. Every little bit helps. Thanks for your support.

story:
June and Nancy 

written by Michelle Ramoni

directed by Kate Holland. 

When she unexpectedly falls in love with Nancy, 1950s housewife June is faced with the choice between duty and passion. Which path would you follow?

About the show:

This play has been in development for the past two years through Stage Left Studio and we are thrilled to have our world premiere in this year’s NY International Fringe Festival.  It is a groundbreaking piece that offers the audience an in depth look at  two women falling head over heels in love and dreaming of a place where they can share a life together.

We need your help to pay for rehearsal space, some of the festival costs and to help us start purchasing period costumes and set props.  We have a top-notch cast and creative team and with your help this production will be wildly successful!

 

How your contribution helps

We need help covering some of our initial costs, including:

Rehearsal Space –This is the big one – most of the funds we raise here will help cover rehearsal space.

Marketing Materials

Period Costumes – The costumes (particularly the undergarments) will be a big part of setting the time period for the show and we’re looking for authentic pieces.

The Perks!

Our overflowing gratitude – this is a very personal project for the artists involved and you will be helping to make a dream come true.

Other benefits include love letters between June and Nancy, free running classes with Michelle Ramoni, acting and dialect coaching sessions with the Kate Holland or Gabrielle Maisels, the chance to attend open rehearsals and get free tickets to the show and possibly a private party with the cast and creative team! 

The Impact

 This play offers a unique look at how far we have come in the fight for LGBTQ equality and how far we have still to go. By helping us mount this production, you will give the audience a chance to experience a beautiful and heartbreaking love story.

Previous Success

In the Fringe…

Director Kate Holland, producer Hannah Vaughn and actor Gabrielle Maisels worked together on Ms. Maisels' solo show Bongani in the 2011 Fringe Festival. After initial success in the Fringe, Bongani was selected for an extended run in the Fringe Encore Series.

Elsewhere…

The cast and creative team are alums of Carol Fox Prescott’s acting class and worked together in December 2011 under Kate Holland’s direction on Tony Kushner’s A Bright Room Called Day at the Episcopal Actor’s Guild.

Producer Hannah Vaughn is also the creator and producer of the hit lesbian web series, Dates Like This.
story_txt:
June and Nancy 
written by Michelle Ramoni
directed by Kate Holland. 
When she unexpectedly falls in love with Nancy, 1950s housewife June is faced with the choice between duty and passion. Which path would you follow?
About the show:
This play has been in development for the past two years through Stage Left Studio and we are thrilled to have our world premiere in this year’s NY International Fringe Festival.  It is a groundbreaking piece that offers the audience an in depth look at  two women falling head over heels in love and dreaming of a place where they can share a life together.
We need your help to pay for rehearsal space, some of the festival costs and to help us start purchasing period costumes and set props.  We have a top-notch cast and creative team and with your help this production will be wildly successful!
 
How your contribution helps
We need help covering some of our initial costs, including:
Rehearsal Space –This is the big one – most of the funds we raise here will help cover rehearsal space.
Marketing Materials
Period Costumes – The costumes (particularly the undergarments) will be a big part of setting the time period for the show and we’re looking for authentic pieces.
The Perks!
Our overflowing gratitude – this is a very personal project for the artists involved and you will be helping to make a dream come true.
Other benefits include love letters between June and Nancy, free running classes with Michelle Ramoni, acting and dialect coaching sessions with the Kate Holland or Gabrielle Maisels, the chance to attend open rehearsals and get free tickets to the show and possibly a private party with the cast and creative team! 
The Impact
 This play offers a unique look at how far we have come in the fight for LGBTQ equality and how far we have still to go. By helping us mount this production, you will give the audience a chance to experience a beautiful and heartbreaking love story.
Previous Success

Director Kate Holland, producer Hannah Vaughn and actor Gabrielle Maisels worked together on Ms. Maisels' solo show Bongani in the 2011 Fringe Festival. After initial success in the Fringe, Bongani was selected for an extended run in the Fringe Encore Series.

story:
BUT WHY

Here's the skinny. Brennan wrote a play. He sent it off to the Unchained Festival. They liked it. They're presenting it as part of the 2015 Unchained Festival, which takes place from June 8 - June 28th at the Chain Theatre in Long Island City, NY. So now all we have to do is fully produce and realize a show that's never been performed before in about a month. No biggie.


SERIOUSLY THOUGH WHY

Putting up the show will take people, props, set, time, and rehearsal space. MOST IMPORTANT among those are the PEOPLE. It is important to us that ARTISTS GET PAID FOR THEIR ART. The primary reason we are raising funds is to provide a stipend for the actors and technical folks involved. These are amazingly talented young professional artists who deserve to be treated as such. Help us give them an honorarium for their time and talent. CAPS LOCK IS FUN

The funds will also help cover production costs, like rehearsal space, props, set, costumes, and blood. Fake blood. Probably fake.

We will receive funding even if we don't reach our goal (but we totally will!) so every single bit helps. You're all shining stars. And your hair looks great today.


I STILL DON'T WANT TO GIVE MONEY

That's cool! Not super cool, but still cool. Here's some other ways you can help:

  • Post this bad boy on your Facepage, Tweeter, or LiveJournal (Xanga?)
  • COME SEE THE SHOW! We'll be updating with performance dates and links to ticket sales and other fun bits.
  • Hook us up with cheap/free rehearsal space
  • Do you know how to build a throne? We need a throne. For real.
  • Pray for our souls

story:
"It's not just a kitchen table..."

Before he visits for the first time... Before she leaves for good... After you've started over... At your crossroads... At your breaking point...

The stuff that matters happens in the kitchen.

Sleek stainless steel or lime-green linoleum; IKEA chairs or your grandmother's tea cozy: the kitchen table is the silent witness to the story of your life. It’s the heartbeat of your home, it’s where your guard comes down, it’s where you’re the most human. We’re investigating those moments—those frail, violent, sexy, crushing, joyful moments—that unfold at the kitchen table.

My kitchen table. Your kitchen table. Doesn’t matter—just have a seat. We’ve got something to show you.

Tell me more…

Receiving its world premiere production at the New York International Fringe Festival this August, The Kitchen Table Plays is a work-in-progress exploring the intimacy of what happens in people’s kitchens through a series of small, intertwining stories. Each short play is set in a different kitchen with all-new characters, supported by a Greek chorus of sorts that provides fluid, poetic interludes in between each play. Four actors make up the entire ensemble: playing various characters, narrating stage directions, and physically creating each world.

So what do you need?

We need your help! To do this right, we need:

  • Rehearsal space!! By far, our biggest expense.
  • Actor stipends
  • Designer stipends
  • Crew stipends
  • Materials to build our set piece (the eponymous Kitchen Table!)
  • Travel and delivery costs for the custom-built Table set
  • Insurance (a FringeNYC must-have)
  • Marketing support
  • Application and registration fees
  • TIME!
  • YOU!

But really, we can't do this without YOU. Your gifts will make it possible to tell these stories.

And what happens when I give?

All gifts will be recognized with gratitude and love in the form of digital shout-outs, name recognition in our Fringe program, and/or various other tokens of our affection -- Check out specific perks for each giving level in the sidebar to your right. To keep you engaged with this project throughout our process, we'll be updating periodically with behind-the-scenes video updates (courtesy our friends at BSD Media!), because we're experimenting here, and we want to give you an inside look at this journey.

All gifts defray the sizeable costs of self-producing in the Fringe, and your gifts will make it possible to create a real sense of place for this piece--please help us bring this play to life!

And who are YOU?

Two theater artists interested in the humanity of stories; stories that feel “real” but are freed from the restraints of “realism.” We like to play. We like to take you on a journey. We like to move mountains, but we’d rather move you.

But, really, who ARE you?

Erin Breznitsky (Playwright) is a New York City-based playwright, sound designer, and theatre artist. She holds an MFA in Theatre from Sarah Lawrence College and a BA in Writing from Susquehanna University. Her plays include Sverginata, a re-imagining of the life of Baroque painter Artemisia Gentileschi (produced at Sarah Lawrence College, December 2011); R+J, a fantastical continuation of Romeo and Juliet (produced by SLC Gradworks, 2012); and Hands, a mystical ghost story about loss and human connection. She is the recipient of the Stanley & Evelyn Lipkin Prize for Playwriting and a full scholarship to the La MaMa International Playwrights Retreat in Spoleto, Italy, where she studied with Erik Ehn. As a sound designer, her work has been seen at Manhattan Repertory Company, the San Francisco Fringe Festival, Under St. Marks, Midtown International Theatre Festival, Dixon Place, and Mabou Mines Resident Artist Program. As an arts administrator, Erin has worked for McCarter Theatre Center and George Street Playhouse. She is currently the Community Arts Coordinator at Sing for Hope. 

www.erinbreznitsky.com

Tamara Winters (Director) is a theater artist and arts advocate with a passion for new work, experimental collaboration, and works that explore our humanity in unexpected ways. Her eclectic aesthetic was first shaped at Ohio University's BFA Acting program and later refined through the interdisciplinary MFA program at Sarah Lawrence College. Her work has been seen at IATI Theater's Cimientos development series, HERE Arts Center, Cherry Lane, Dixon Place, The New Ohio, Joria Productions, the Midtown International Theater Festival, Nuyorican Poets Cafe, Truant Arts, and Ensemble Theatre Cincinnati. She is also passionate about arts advocacy, and spends her days raising funds for arts organizations and projects, including New York Madness.

www.tamarawinters.com

How else can I help?

Come to our show! We'll announce location and dates as soon as we hear from FringeNYC. Until then:

Please help us spread the word about this campaign - email your friends! Like us on Facebook! Ask your coworkers to join us! You can help us tell our story and get us to our goal!

Use the Indiegogo share tools to post about us on all your various social media!

We can't wait to see you at the Table—

we'll save you a seat!

we'll save you a seat!

story:
WHO WE ARE:

Meet 2013’s graduating actors from California Institute of the Arts in Valencia, California!  We have spent the past three or four years in 16-hour days of classes and rehearsals, nausea-inducing work-outs, blurry eyed all-nighters, and record-setting coffee-binges, and now we are awfully excited to transition into professional performing arts circles and make an impact.  CalArts actors are proud to distinguish ourselves in the industry with our training, imagination, boldness and work ethic: alumnis include Don Cheadle, Allison Brie, and Ed Harris, and are featured in major motion pictures and television shows.  Many are leaders in ground-breaking theatre around the world.  Even more important to mention, this particular gang of thespians are among the most thoughtful, supportive and generous artists around!

 

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP:

In March, the graduating class is required to travel to New York City as a company to partake in an industry showcase that allows us to interface with casting directors, agents, directors, producers and other industry professionals. This showcase is not only a required element of our final year, but also presents a unique experience and opportunity that for many past students has created significant post-graduation career prospects.

The cost of this trip to New York will far exceed what is within our student living-expenses.  As well as performing in the showcase, it is essential to be able to remain in the city for at least several days following the showcase to meet with interested industry professionals.  Each one of us hopes to spend at least one week in New York following the showcase in order to take full advantage of this trip.  All this will all amount to a slightly sweat-inducing expenditure.

 

For this reason, each year, the graduating acting class is involved in a collective fundraising effort from the beginning of the year with the aim of supplementing each student’s showcase travel. This year, as the largest graduating class ever, we are facing a particular challenge in meeting the needs of each student. But not only have we committed to ourselves to raise the funds to make this trip to New York possible, we have committed to each other! No actor left behind! We’ve been performing free shows, selling-off our worldly belongings, selling serenades and pranks and otherwise making utter fools of ourselves...and the time has come where we need your help!

We humbly request your support.  This showcase will be our first formal introduction to the industry and could likely result in our first vital invitations for representation.  Your donation would be most helpful in navigating this travel expense and things like transportation, food, and lodging, as well as headshots and business cards.  If the devotion and enthusiasm of this group is any indication of how we will contribute to the performing arts, your donation will be both well-appreciated and worthily-spent.

 

We greatly appreciate your support and want to give back for every donation received. If you look at the column to the right of this screen you can see the reward that follows each donation increment.  Thank you from the bottom of our art hearts!

Meet us! Check out our website:

http://www.calartsactorshowcase.com/?from_fb=1

See what our unique training program is all about:

http://theater.calarts.edu/

 

OTHERS WAYS TO HELP:

 

We understand if you can’t donate.  But we would be ever so grateful if you would reach out to your wealthy estranged Aunt.  Please pass this page along to your friends and family!

story:
Thanks for taking a moment to look at Gildenfire Dance's IndieGoGo Project Roots and Wings!  We are jumping out of our nest of community centers, gymnasiums and church basements and gliding down into our own sunlit space less than two miles from our current home in West Seattle.  We need a soft landing!  So we would like to build a safe, comfortable and professional dance floor. The floor—foam covered with Marley dance floor vinyl material—will be the perfect springboard for our future!

Over the years I’ve accumulated a following of students and an array of locations where I teach. Thirteen years ago, I worked as a preschool teacher.  My BA in Dance from UW was gathering dust when one of the preschool mom's asked me to teach a dance class for her daughter Michaela.  With three students I began to teach at Phinney Neighborhood Center.  I think I paid more in rent than I earned in tuition!  From the start it was important to me that no one was ever turned away who couldn't pay or could only pay a portion.  Soon enough, I taught dance at the preschool where I was a Toddler Teacher, Small Faces.  In 2008 I began teaching all the students at The Community School of West Seattle.  Eventually, I found the Highland Park Improvement Club and relocated many of my class there.  Now I teach in five places and have about 125 students. That’s a lot of little birds and a lot of scattered nests.

But I found us a new home—a big building with twenty-foot ceilings where our hearts can soar!  A space where we can have mirrors on the wall to help us learn.  A place where we can have ballet barre's for Saturday Morning Ballet.  A place that will be greatly improved with floors that will keep us safe, that will protect our longevity in dance and help Gildenfire Dance to thrive with it’s dancers. Our goal is to open the doors with a padded Marley Floor in March 2013.

Hooray, we've got the space! But to make it work, we need:

1.  Most important: Five-eights inch foam underlay and Marely Flooring $6,870 is the total cost for the flooring!

2.  Mirrors: $1,500-$2,500

We have come so far but we need this floor to open the doors!

Why should you help Gildenfire Dance build complete this project?

In short, Gildenfire Dance makes a positive impact in the community. Gildenfire Dance, encourages and uplifts its families and the young dancers who attend classes and perform in local public spaces. Here are some of the ways we do this:

Every year we provide over $1,000 in scholarships to our students in Dance and Acrobatics based on financial need.

Our tuition is far less than most local studios which provides more opportunities for all children to dance.

We donate hundred of dollars in gift certificates to local charities and schools each year.

Our programs are open to all children regardless of differing abilities and strengths.

We build self-confidence, coordination, balance, strength, grace, pride and joy every single time we open the doors.

Our performances often take place in retirement communities, bringing the joy of dance to the elderly, and the joy of the elderly to the dancers.

Please take this moment to support the work Gildenfire does to make a difference in the lives of these amazing young dancers!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need this floor to keep young dancers bodies safe and provide the spring board for our dancing and choreography:

  • Any amount we make up to $6870 will go towards the materials for the dance floor.  I will be installing the floor myself to keep costs in check.
  • Any additional money donated will go to our Mirrors Fund in order to mirror one wall  of the studio so that our dancers can continue to grow and improve their technique.  We will also be able to offer offer ballet classes!
  • Your support affords you some amazing rewards!

The Impact

This campaign will have a positive impact on the lives of children:

  • This floor will provide a safe place for children to dance.
  • We can continue to grow and offer new classes to help keep children engaged and promoting thier love of dance.
  • We will be able to afford to continue our scholarship program which benefits children whose families cannot afford to pay for dance and acrobatics classes.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about our campaign! 

  • Take a moment to share our Roots and Wings Project on Facebook, Twitter and email anyone that you think would like to support our cause.

story:
Short Summary

Hi. Hello it’s me. And you, yes you are invited to a #QueerCultHorror loosely inspired by Edgar Allen Poe’s Masque of the Red Death. Excited yet? Prepare for sexuality, intimacy, and ecstasy, as you’ll swallow down the fears of reality to enter our world of fantasy. It’s time to replace all these controversies, with our musical numbers about vulnerability, daddy problems, and toast. It'll be a party you’ll never forget! Join us.

XOXO From The Hostess With The Mostest ~ Prospero <3


The Cult Next Door is a NYC based theatre company that was founded in the depths of Pace University’s School of Performing Arts.  This eclectic mix of international performers, who have individually trained in various aspects of performance, have come together to manifest ungodly proportions. Together they incorporate music, highly physical movements, satire, and explosions to create work that reveals the strange, grotesque, and sometimes unsettling aspects of daily routine.

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need funding to pay for plane tickets, housing, props, costumes, and festival fees. 
  • Take a look at some of our exciting campaign perks! 

The Impact

  • By supporting our show, not only are you supporting new work but also lgtbtq awareness. 
  • We've worked on versions of this show at various venues around New York City including:  Pace University, Schaeberle Studio Theatre, and The Living Gallery. As a company, we have also created work at The Secret Theatre and the Producer's Club.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hi. Hello it’s me. And you, yes you are invited to a #QueerCultHorror loosely inspired by Edgar Allen Poe’s Masque of the Red Death. Excited yet? Prepare for sexuality, intimacy, and ecstasy, as you’ll swallow down the fears of reality to enter our world of fantasy. It’s time to replace all these controversies, with our musical numbers about vulnerability, daddy problems, and toast. It'll be a party you’ll never forget! Join us.
XOXO From The Hostess With The Mostest ~ Prospero <3
The Cult Next Door is a NYC based theatre company that was founded in the depths of Pace University’s School of Performing Arts.  This eclectic mix of international performers, who have individually trained in various aspects of performance, have come together to manifest ungodly proportions. What We Need & What You Get

Take a look at some of our exciting campaign perks! 


The Impact

We've worked on versions of this show at various venues around New York City including:  Pace University, Schaeberle Studio Theatre, and The Living Gallery. As a company, we have also created work at The Secret Theatre and the Producer's Club.

story:
Short Summary

  • Warts and All has been incubating in my gray matter for over ten years. However, I didn't really discover the path the writing should take until about  year and a half ago. What took so long? I forgot that I love the underdog. It was the Bible's sweet but  nameless women that needed me, not the ones with stained glass windows made in their honor. It was the women with slightly tarnished reputations that wanted their say, their chance in court. So, in my show, those women have it.  This play is a toast to the imperfect woman. The kind of woman that solves problems by shaking her hips,  slipping you a  Mickey, or by slamming a tent peg through your head.  Which, by all accounts, is exactly the kind of woman God loves. 

What We Need 

Thankfully, family and friends have covered transportation to and in New York. I could use your help with the following.

  • The venue is the Duke Theatre at 229 West 42nd street.  It costs $655.00.
  • Any money raised beyond that will be put toward the mandatory  15 tickets the festival requires each participant to sell at 20.00 each.

The Impact

Didn't you just go to a festival this summer Crystal Rae?

Yes! I paid my little happy way to  New York  to participate in  Park Avenue United Methodist Church's  curated artist Wednesdays. Their staff chose a monologue from Warts and All for their festival and I was honored to participate. The New York New Works Festival is different in that the panel judging the event  are all heavy hitters in the theatre industry. Hence my excitement about participating and the higher price tag.

What's after this festival? 

Beyond this festival the full length premier of the show will be held at The Ensemble Theatre in Houston, Texas under the umbrella of the their "local artist" series. It has a three night run! I couldn't be more thrilled.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute,  that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Consider getting the word out and making some noise about my campaign. A Facebook like, share, or Twitter tweet goes a long way.
  • If you're in New York consider seeing the show, or passing out advertisements for it.
  •  Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Send up a prayer for a sista!

story:
Which Way Is Out, by Jamaican Playwright Basil Dawkins will have it's stage debut in Los Angeles in May of 2013. This venture is being produced jointly by The Caribbean American Repertory Theatre, West, and Marcus B. Entertainment Inc. Jeffrey Anderson-Gunter, and Marcus Branche respectively. For the past 15 years, CART, West, (501c3)has been producing plays for the Caribbean community in L.A. and Marcus B. Ent. Inc.'s, Caribbean Comedy Series, has been the delight of the Caribbean community for the past ten (10) years. Both producers, having supported each other throughout the years, and decided to make this next journey a "joint" venture in an effort to make it less burdensome in implementation. We are not funded, the source of our funds are out of pocket, or through "the milk of human kindness", you. We continue to recognize the need to bring entertainment to our caribbean people in the diaspora, in an effort to rekindle the love of their homeland, and the pride in recognition of stellar work being done by their indigenous artists, and the sharing of our cultures to the masses here in the United States. This play offers a slice of life that exists, is universal, and is dealt with in a very sincere, worthy and comic style that will transcend the boundaries of our differences for the better. We have mammoth costs, but, we are willing to take the journey because of the passion that exists in our belief in the support of our people, and the need to explore, and, exchange diversity in our cultures, through understanding. We believe in the excellence, professionalism and quality of our work, and with your help in funding, success is inevitable.  Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
The Campaign

Boxed Wine Productions is nearing the end of our first full season of new and exciting theater, and we are currently in rehearsals for our biggest production to date- Paul Rudnick's epic comedy Valhalla. Financially, we're almost there- but we're asking for your help to get us across the finish line.

The Show

Valhalla follows the stories of King Ludwig of Bavaria and James Avery, two characters living 60 years and half a world apart. What drives them both is an unshakable need to find and possess what is beautiful in the world around them. They move along their respective paths until finally their stories come crashing in on one another with at times disastrous and hilarious consequences.

Valhalla is, amongst many other things, a hilarious comedy with tremendous heart. We fell in love with the characters of King Ludwig and James Avery, and their relentless quests for beauty in a seemingly dark world. We laugh when they fail and cheer when they win, delighting in their ups and downs and urging them forward towards their own Valhallas. But more than anything, we love Valhalla because when we look at it, we see ourselves- and are convinced that audiences will do the same- coming away enlightened, enchanted, and with a smile on their faces, looking for whatever it is that is beautiful and precious to them in their own lives.

What we're asking for:

Funds raised by this campaign (which will be processed and donated to the company through our Fiscal Sponsor, Fractured Atlas, and are therefore tax deductible), will go towards the final costs of one of the following costs of production:

Space Rental: We've rented a beautiful theater that fits the piece perfectly, and are excited for the first time to be making our home their for a two week run- the longest run of any of our productions to date.

Creative Team Fees: After working many years for free, we believe that paying everyone involved in our projects is an essential step towards becoming a more professional and stable company. We have been working to grow our modest stipends for each production- a little bit at a time- in order to help our collaborators make ends meet.

Design: Just as ambitious as staging this epic play in the first place- with its seemingly neverending cast of characters and huge shifts in space and time- is designing the space in which the magic can happen. We have an excellent director in Chris Bowser, and an excellent design team in Brian Hendricks, Alex Thrailkill, Kaela Garvin, and Marika Kent. Your donation will help us in transforming the Little Secret Theatre in to a space where all our dreams can come true.

What you get in return:

In exchange for donating to our campaign, the company is pitching in with some unique and creative rewards- we hope you'll have as much fun receiving them as we will in creating them for you.

story:
What inspired Subverted?

Subverted was written as my senior thesis to graduate with honors and a Bachelors Degree in acting from Pace University. The topic came about because I have lived in Brooklyn, East New York my whole life and I have witnessed many people stay “prisoner to the block.” Once I started attending Pace, I realized that often, growing up in “the hood,” you are accustomed to certain learned behaviors that you only learn are “wrong” or “classless” when you leave, if you ever get that chance. When you leave you see that the “outside world” doesn’t dress, talk or live the way you have your whole life. You are told to assimilate and to be tolerant of the larger world’s ignorance about where you come from, but the reality is, that the larger world is never forced to reciprocate. And that’s because “the hood” is never a place they have to go to improve their lives or reach their American dream.


The Synopsis

SUBVERTED portrays the destruction of Black identity as seen through the eyes of Eden, an 18 year-old girl living in any urban city in the USA. Through the colliding viewpoints of 18 friends, family members, and historical figures (all portrayed by actor, writer, and spoken word poet Dominique Fishback) Eden discovers that the promise of “equal opportunity” still, to this day, does not exist. She questions why the people she loves the most continue to live blindly subverted by an unrelenting history that they did not live through, yet inherit and must accept. Eden’s journey will make a difference in our understanding of what true equality actually looks like.


 

What We Need & What You Get

  • The $12,000 raised will go into booking a NYC theater for a 3 week run! I've only had the opportunity to perform Subverted for very limited runs, such as four performances at Pace University, two performances in Culture Project’s Off Broadway theatre in their Women Center Stage 2013 Festival. And, an upcoming, single performance, at the 14th Street Y with the MCC Youth Theater. But that doesn’t give a great deal of opportunity for you, your family, and your friends to see it, does it?
  • The money raised will also be going towards paying for an amazingly talented creative team (all of whom have, or are currently, working on Broadway), helmed by director Terry Berliner, who has worked across the country, Off Broadway and on Broadway—as the resident director of The Lion King--and on many other great shows! www.terryberliner.com

  •  You will get all of this talent, for an off off Broadway Price! 

  • The donations will also go towards the purchase of all of the materials for set, sound, lighting, costume design, and rehearsal space as well as marketing, promotional material, and more. 

 


The Impact

  • Subverted is worth the time and the money. Subverted has caught the eye and has stayed in the minds of people that include Gloria Steinem, Kathy Najimy, and Lynn Nottage. Visit the following link to see audience reviews and quotes. 
    • http://www.dominique-fishback.com/subverted-original-one-woman-show.html
     Subverted is worth the investment because when I think of “equal opportunity,” I think of the fact that while there are no physical chains or masters saying certain people cannot learn or reach the American dream, there are still these “slum areas”/ "the ghetto", that are not given the same tools that other communities have such easy access to. Subverted will help us all look at race and class differently. It has been created in a way that it resonates with people of all ages but especially the youth, and afterall the youth is the future.

    Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

•  Please spread the word, share the campaign and donate whatever you can.

•  If you have access to free rehearsal space, or set materials, or your great at promotional duties, that too is a very helpful donation.

www.dominique-fishback.com (writer and performer)

www.reignentertainment.com (Cinematographer and editor, Marcos Sotomayor)

With love Dom 

@dymeactress (Twitter)

Like the Subverted Facebook page

https://www.facebook.com/subverteddf 





Selected Character list:

EDEN: 18 African American. Lead

SUSANNA: Eden’s grandma. 

CHARLOTTE: Slave girl.

MASSA CHARLES: Slave owner.

MARY: Massa Charles daughter. 

TOBY: Slave man. 

RAY RAY: 10 year old, video head. Robin to Quan's Batman

QUAN: 11 years old, video head. 

TEACHER: Woman, White, timid

TONEYA: Ghetto, loud and obnoxious.

SLAVE MAMMY: Charlotte’s mother. 

TYSHAWN:  The ladies love him

GRANDPA EARL:  

BETTY: TYSHAWN/RAYRAY’s mom.

BRI: 6 years old.

CARLA: 6 years old Puerto Rican. BRI’s friend.

story:
Theatre: the art that keeps on giving. In a world gravitating towards personal entertainment, theatre is a unique artistic form that encourages a sense of community, a place of belonging and, most importantly, tackles some of life’s hardest questions in a way that is accessible for a diverse audience.

EMUNAH is a colourful theatre piece that ties together stories of faith, doubt, and disbelief. This unique production will take each audience member on a different journey. Delving into an enthralling spiritual realm, witness our five performers seek proof of a higher being. Throughout various stages of their existence, they come face-to-face with the power of their doubts.

H-Dubbs is fortunate enough to be performing in Montreal’s 2014 St-Ambroise Fringe Festival. We are beyond excited for this opportunity and we need your help to make this our best show yet!

Of course, with a project exploring life’s uncertainties, the last thing we want is for you to doubt our campaign. So, we will try to be as honest and clear-cut as possible to show how we plan to use our funding to cover budget costs:


At the end of it, sometimes all we’re really looking for is human connection. Maintaining theatre’s vocation, our aim is to give back a performance that will inspire, stimulate, and create a safe space for conversation. EMUNAH expresses the innate human desire to discover what spins this little blue planet we call Earth.

story:
WHO ARE WE?

LAFA is proud to be partnered with The town of lakeshore, LAFA participates in community inspired events such as, performing for seniors at Oak Park Terrace, preparing for an upcoming performance of CHARLIE and tackling social issues by presenting skits to various schools around our community.

This past year, LAFA Staff & Alumni has had the pleasure of donating endless volunteer hours; over $3500.00 to local charitable organizations, 200 tickets to seniors and underprivileged children, as well as, 5 scholarships having a combined worth of over $2000.00 to local children allowing them the opportunity to participate in the arts. We have provided workshops to schools, social organizations and have been hired to produce productions independently.


What We Need & What You Get

We only need to raise 1/3 the price of the building.  We need $200,000 out of $600,000.

The Puce Centre is closing and we do not have a place to go.  LAFA is looking for a new home to continue its mission for the children of the Lakeshore community. As its original building will be up for sale in the coming months, LAFA wishes to continue its operations by investing in a new building. With your help, we can make this wish possible.

We want to create a space where aspiring performers can come together and create artistry.  In the building we will have the following:

DANCE STUDIO

ACTING STUDIO

PRIVATE MUSIC ROOMS

CASTING ROOM

BLACK BOX THEATRE

OFFICE SPACE

LOBBY

Our program gives your business an opportunity to be exposed to over 1000 families! You will also have a direct link on our website and you will become a featured patron in our Monthly Newsletter! All this for a very small investment, as you become an active supporter of the arts in our youth!

All gifts to Lakeshore Academy of Fine Arts, no matter the measure, are always welcome and produce a positive impact on the students’ training, inner strengths and perpetuate the continued success of the Academy.Your Generosity is recognized and regarded in the highest esteem by all those at LAFA.

Hello Parents, Students and Staff of LAFA,

My name is Kathy Zambito and I am here to not only listen but to share my personal experiences and journey with the Academy both through my eyes and through the eyes of my daughter Samantha.

Like most parents, it was important to me that my children be involved in extra-curricular activities.  It is sometimes a challenge making that decision and finding and activity or sport that your child feels excited about. For my husband and I, we not only wanted our children involved in something physical, but something creative as well.  It is here that we looked at our children’s personalities to find something that was well-suited to inspire, motivate and challenge them.

I will speak of Samantha specifically because of her love for and involvement with LAFA.  My daughter was an extremely shy little girl outside of the home.  While she had no trouble ‘hamming it up’ at home, she lacked the self confidence to show off her bubbly personality and sense of humour outside of her comfort zone.  We felt that finding an outlet to bring Samantha out of her shell and improving her confidence was extremely important.  Samantha’s exuberance and energy needed to be shared with others!

Now that I’ve touched on how wonderful I think my daughter is, let me also tell you about my fondness for Sarah, the owner, director and everything else that makes LAFA what it is today. Sarah’s passion for the fine arts and for this Academy is something to be admired and makes her a wonderful role model for our children.  LAFA is not just a ‘babysitting’ service. It is a place our children have gone to learn, grow, make new friends and have fun.

Samantha would not be the young woman she is today without Sarah’s influence.  Every child needs a mentor outside of his or her parents and Sarah is exactly that to Samantha.  She is someone to admire and emulate.  Samantha has made a journey from being too scared to audition for a play to auditioning for play with confidence, auditioning for a movies and she is now both a junior instructor and a junior director with LAFA.  We couldn’t be more proud of her and as parents, we are extremely grateful for Sarah’s role in our daughter’s journey. 

I am sure many of you parents are feeling the same way. Watching our sons and daughters express themselves through acting and performance art is something to be admired.  We have also watched these kids become responsible, respectful and confident young adults.  There is not much else a parent can ask for.

On behalf of Sarah, LAFA, myself, my family and hopefully your families as well, I am making a plea that we all take part in helping to save LAFA.  Not only for our children but for young children looking for an outlet or activity to stimulate and excite them.

Those of us who know Sarah know that she does this for the pure love and passion she has for acting, improv and the performing arts.  And as I have seen personally, she has a special bond with all of our children and takes a vested interest in their confidence, happiness, creativity and involvement with LAFA.

I ask that we return this passion and show our gratitude by giving back in any way we can.  Let’s band together as parents of LAFA and supporters of Sarah to do what we can to raise money to open a new facility and continue to watch our children flourish and grow as well as children in generations to come. 

Thanks so much for listening and for your support.
story_txt:
WHO ARE WE?LAFA is proud to be partnered with The town of lakeshore, LAFA participates in community inspired events such as, performing for seniors at Oak Park Terrace, preparing for an upcoming performance of CHARLIE and tackling social issues by presenting skits to various schools around our community.This past year, LAFA Staff & Alumni has had the pleasure of donating endless volunteer hours; over $3500.00 to local charitable organizations, 200 tickets to seniors and underprivileged children, as well as, 5 scholarships having a combined worth of over $2000.00 to local children allowing them the opportunity to participate in the arts. We have provided workshops to schools, social organizations and have been hired to produce productions independently.What We Need & What You GetWe only need to raise 1/3 the price of the building.  We need $200,000 out of $600,000. The Puce Centre is closing and we do not have a place to go.  LAFA is looking for a new home to continue its mission for the children of the Lakeshore community. As its original building will be up for sale in the coming months, LAFA wishes to continue its operations by investing in a new building. With your help, we can make this wish possible. We want to create a space where aspiring performers can come together and create artistry.  In the building we will have the following:DANCE STUDIOACTING STUDIOPRIVATE MUSIC ROOMSCASTING ROOMBLACK BOX THEATREOFFICE SPACELOBBYOur program gives your business an opportunity to be exposed to over 1000 families! You will also have a direct link on our website and you will become a featured patron in our Monthly Newsletter! story:
Little girls want to be reality stars?!  The only female rapper in the mainstream is a Black woman that calls herself "Barbie"! And many of the most talented women in the industry have become egomaniacs!  According to tv/web personality, recording artist, & actress Amanda Seales, we've witnessed the Death of the Diva.

In her latest project, a hilarious musically infused one-woman show, Amanda morphs in and out of a multitude of characters using narrative, comedy, rhyme and song to tell her theory of what caused the destruction of the mainstream media image of the iconic powerful woman and the women it will/has affect(ed).  Exploring the influence of imagery, she seeks to assign accountability to the lack of female images in the mainstream, and raise awareness on the repercussions that has had and will have on women.  Accompanied by a three-piece band, and video imagery, the show is dynamic and interactive compelling audiences to laugh, empathize, and nod their heads to the original musical numbers integrated throughout.  Its theatrical commentary on the image based society women are still defining their identities in, makes Death of the Diva a riveting piece as unique as its subject is universal.  


Who is this show for?

We hope to take this show to schools, colleges, universities, theaters, we'll even put it up in a barn!  Fact is we want as many people to see this show as possible because its message speaks to everyone.  Young women are especially who we hope to have the opportunity to see this show about powerful images and the lack there of.  In this current world of super celebrity, reality tv, and pop everything the distinction between what's real and not real can become hazy. In Death of the Diva we keep it real and keep it funny! 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $4500 minimum in order to get this play up and on its feet.  Money will be going to rental space of the theater, promotional materials, paying for the band and band rehearsal space, rental of musical equipment, costumes, and of course to put a little something in the hands of the artisans who have come together to bring this message to life!  Below you will see the list of contribution options and the dope perks that come along with each.  Here in the grass roots we get to be honest and true artists but it is your funding and support that makes it possible for our vision to grow to fruition!  :)


Other Ways You Can Help

Hey, these are tough times.  We totally get it!  But all is not lost!  You can still be of a great help by spreading the word via twitter, fb, tumblr, email etc!  The oldest and best form of promotion is word of mouth!  So we urge to shout it from the internet (and hey, if you're willing, literal) roof tops "I know about this awesome play and they need help from us to share the awesomeness!"  Folks will definitely listen!

story:
demolished.  And as Silicon Valley (San Jose, CA)  is not know for it's Art and Style - this old theater in the Burbank District to many looks like nothing more than the next high rise.

Why do we want to save this old theater?

We envisioned this place being a place where people can learn the Arts - dancing, music, visual arts, drama, comedy, film acting and film production - an all in 1 place - a true Creative and Performing Arts Center!

But we didn't forget that once Artists are trained - they need places to perform!

While there always seems to be plenty of places to book huge mega events, we feel the intimate experience is lost.  We want these Artists to interact first hand with their audience, even if it's the latest Independent Film producer attending the first screening of their own film!

So working with Architects and Designers - we planned out a renovation to this old Theater that would convert it into multiple "micro venues" - where room sizes can be as small as 30 seats up to as large as 175 seats.  (EDIT: Why "Micro Venues"? why not restore the original single screen 850+ seat Theater? The main reason is HWY 280 click here to see what we mean.)

These micro venues to a degree inspired by the various types of Bed and Breakfasts of the world ( each room would have it's own unique theme ), would be suitable for any type of live events - and smaller rooms would be dual purpose with comfy seating for Independent or Art House Film Showings as well.

In effect as various Students are finishing up what they learn in class - a micro-venue room can be filled with Friends and Family for Recitals, at the same time more experienced Students working together on Sketches for Comedy or Drama can open up for Public Shows, or Musicians ready for another week of open mic night ( we run this once per week now ).

We could go on and on, but I hope you get the idea... we want a place for Artists to learn and to have fun!  And a place where people can come and have fun seeing or experiencing the latest Art the Artists have created!

So where are we in this vision?

We started a year ago, we moved "Studio Sharise – Discover the Artist Within (our Creative and Performing Art School)" - into the upstairs unit at the Burbank Theater (San Jose Mercury News covered the story) .  We had lengthy discussions with the owners to start plans to renovate and restore the whole Theater... Well as the weeks and months went on - we realized that these owners were really just happy to take our money and were very content to do nothing...

So if the owners are doing nothing, what is this campaign for?

Well, not only did the owners happily take our money and do nothing, but they didn't even bother to pay the mortgages!!!

In late October the property will be foreclosed upon; and once it goes to public auction - it's anyone's guess what will happen next.

Will some new amateur investor buy it thinking they can make a quick dollar or two and end up doing nothing for 10+ years (like the current owners). 

Will the bank be able to sell it at all? - will it just end up as one more bank owned property boarded up, fenced off, broken windows, graffiti everywhere? Well it's almost that now.

What do we need the money for?

(EDIT: As our newly purchased 2nd mortgage has been recorded, we've started discussions with large Private Investment groups, it may be possible to fast track this plan, and avoid the 3 month process of reinstatement and re-foreclosure.  If this alternative plan happens then 100% of all funds raised here will go directly to refurbishing the property.  However we still need to prove to these investment groups that there are people who are interested in this project, so please continue to contribute - any amount - and share this!!!)  We retained the services from both a Real Estate Law Firm, and a Foreclosure company to help us. We have now purchased the 2nd mortgage and will use it to gain ownership of the building.

$110,000 will be used to reinstate the first mortgage, to stop the current foreclosure.

$ 40,000 will be used to hold the property for 3 months and pay for a new foreclosure on the 2nd mortgage we just purchased, the goal to gain ownership of the building.

$150,000 total is required.

What happens if we get more than the campaign goal?

We have plenty of things in mind. The entire building will be painted to restore it's Art Deco style. We will have the tile work fixed, cleaned, and restored. We will have the parking lot asphalt repaved to remove the large potholes and mini-canals. We will have the broken glass fixed or replaced. We will repair the lighting that illuminates the sidewalks at night, encouraging those that prey in the shadows to look for shadows somewhere else. We will install night vision security cameras on all sides of the building, watching roof lines, marquees, etc. to end the carriers of the graffitists. And lastly we will hire a neon light contractor to restore the Burbank Sign.

What happens if we don't make the goal?

Well I guess those perks can't really happen.  But, we take our chances with the Public Auction at the end of October, and we will use any money you donate here - to either; insist that the new owner allow us to use this donated money you provided to do the exterior repairs we listed above, or if no one bids we will use the donated money to attempt to buy the property from the bank.

The Results:

If we make our campaign goal, then in 4 months from now, we go to public auction; if we win at auction (which is very likely – as we'll explain below); then what happens next?

Once we own the building, private investors who know us, trust us, and want to see our vision for the Burbank Theater happen – will know that that people really do care about keeping an old Theater from turning into 1 more high rise, or even more unsold condos or townhouses.

Seeing each of you donate to this campaign and it being successful will be the proof our investors need; they will then know that if they put in $3+ million – that their really are people who want to see this Burbank Theater turned into something fantastic!

But wait!

Why do we think we'll win at Public Auction in 4 months from now? And what if we are outbid?

“Upside down” is the term. The 1st mortgage by itself is several hundred thousand dollars MORE than the current commercial valuation of the Burbank Theater. So if this building does go to Public Auction next month from the 1st mortgage foreclosure, it's questionable if anyone will want to buy the building at the asking price the bank is required to ask by law.

So... since we purchased the 2nd mortgage, if we stop the 1st mortgage foreclosure by paying them the overdue amount – in 4 months when we put this up for Public Auction the building won't be massively Upside down – it will be Ridiculously Upside down. Which will likely scare away any potential real estate developer or investors who just wants to try and use the Theater to make a quick profit.

So it's “unlikely” anyone else will outbid us in 4 months, but – it's not impossible. So what would we do – if we don't end up being the owner?

Simple. Remember above we mentioned a year ago we moved "Studio Sharise" into the Upstairs? We have signed 10 year leases. Unfortunately if the new owner is crazy enough to outbid us at public auction to buy a property massively overpriced – they may try to take us to court to try and get rid of us. If that happens – we would use the proceeds from this campaign to fight the new owner in court; the goal is the same prevent the building from being bull-dozed, and then get it refurbished.

Alternatively if the new owner really just wants to be the owner of the Theater - then as mentioned in our “What happens if we get more than the campaign goal?” section above - we would insist on having the outside of the building refurbished – and we would use the money you donated to us for that purpose exclusively.

So who are we anyway?

Mariposa Productions LLC – was founded and is owned by Sharise Parviz – she chose the name Mariposa (meaning butterfly) to mean the whole process, of the caterpillar that goes through the metamorphosis and turns into the butterfly; her company was created to produce story through film or stage that really showed the human condition of change – wrapped inside a family friendly or local art house film style. Sharise also employs music, dance, improv and acting teachers, film & stage production staff are brought in as needed. In effect we are Artists working to bring our trades to Silicon Valley.  And once the Burbank Theater is usable again they'll be plenty of space for her experienced students to be putting on performances!

Are contributions tax-deductible?

No, and Yes.

This campaign strictly is about Mariposa Productions LLC – gaining ownership of the Burbank Theater and then starting the refurbishment if monies above the goal are donated, and therefore this is not not tax deductible.

However “Studio Sharise – Discover the Artist Within” ( a division of Mariposa Productions LLC - located upstairs at the Burbank Theater ) - runs programs for at-risk teens, low income families, and even brings volunteers from her school to local retirement homes each week. Donations to “Studio Sharise” are tax-deductible through a special program hosted by Fractured Atlas. So if you are interested more in helping those that have more special needs, please click on this link and receive full 501(c)3 non-profit deductible status for your donation.

Thank you!

So much for you help saving this Theater and bring Style and Arts to so many more people.  You can check our Mariposa Productions and Studio Sharise on Facebook - to see what we've been up to already - in our mission of bringing the Arts to everyone who is willing to try!

more in helping those that have more special needs, please click on this link and receive full 501(c)3 non-profit deductible status for
your donation.Thank you!So much for you help saving this Theater and bring Style and Arts to so many more people.  You can check our Mariposa Productions and Studio Sharise on Facebook - to see what we've been up to already - in our mission of bringing the Arts to everyone who is willing to try!

story:
BOOTLEGGERS RUN has been a dream of mine for two years. I thought, “How cool would it be to live inside a 1930's mobster film?” You know, where they dress the dress, and talk that ole “mobster talk” right at you. What if you could meet the likes of the real Lucky Luciano, or bootleg for “Scarface” Al Capone?

In short BOOTLEGGERS RUN will transport you into a stylized world (like a mobster film from way back in the day) where you and nine others will travel back in time and experience fascinating moments and places.  All the while interacting face-to-face with the founders of organized crime in America.  Here you’ll play both sides of the law.  Come live your history!

Your generous contributions will help take Live IN Theater to the next level. In order to do this the right way, we need “mula”. Funding will help with the look of the production, dialogue training by coaches from HBO’s Boardwalk Empire, movement, music, and rehearsal space. To the moon Alice! 

About Live IN Theater

Live IN Theater creates interactive murder mysteries and immersive experiences through the streets of NYC, based & inspired by real life. Come live your history!

About Carlo D'Amore

I love history and I love the theater. I want to continue to use moments in history to create utterly unique experiences that place the audience in the middle of the action as they Live IN Theater. Audiences are wanting more.  There is an unspoken demand for theater to catch up with the rest of the world. The days of passively experiencing theater are beginning to change. I love the theater because when it works it can be magic. But our relationships and lives are changing at a very rapid pace, and theater needs to evolve. It needs to become less exclusive, more inclusive and accessible. So, whether it’s called “process drama”, “reality theater”, immersive, interactive or whatever, for me as an artist it is ultimately about play. Play = Fun. Come play with us! 

Carlo D'Amore is the creative director of Live IN Theater.  An award winning actor, playwright, educator and Drama Desk nominated director with years of experience in the theater. Broadway, off Broadway, regional and international theater credits, as well as television and film.

story:
Who are we? 

IMPACT Dance Company is a Contemporary Dance company with an array of talented dancers with different backgrounds, body types, ethincities and education. As a company we strive to raise awareness, volunteer in multiple communities and utilize dance as a medium for positivity in life. 

We are using Indiegogo.com to fundraise for our second season which starts this July! We will end the season with two performances at Green Street Studios in Cambridge, MA on November 29th and 30th. 

This season we are focusing on themes based around individualism, inner strength and a mix of human rights. 

What makes IMPACT different is that every season, our Company performance will benefit a specific charity, reasearch or person. Our first Benefit Concert helped raise over $1,000 for a beautiful girl named Hailey who has Cerebral Palsy and her family. This season we will be donating proceeds from our performances to The Human Rights Campaign! 

 

What we need help with! 

We need help paying for all of the little things it takes for a show to be successful and worry free for our artists! Here is a breakdown of what your donation could help fund. 

 

$25 pays for one costume.

$50 pays for one professionally edited piece of music. 

$75 pays for part of the dancers' salary.
 
$100 pays for a House manager for both performances. 
 
$125 pays for skirts for the women's piece. 
 
$150 pays for rehearsal space for one piece. 
 
$200 pays for a Photo shoot. 
 
$250 pays for Marketing, Programs and Tickets. 
 
$300 pays for a Lighting Director. 
 
$500 pays for Theater rental for one performance. 
 
 
* Of course you can donate any amount you wish, this is just a glimspe into what we have to pay for! 
 
We have some fun perks available for certain donation amounts! Check them out on the right of the page :) 
 

The IMPACT

Helping IMPACT reach our goal will enable us to: 

  1. Pay our very dedicated and talented dancers fairly for their time. 
  2. Put on an AMAZING show, with beautiful costumes and lighting.
  3. Market our performances properly to invite even more audience members. 
  4. Allow our Artistic Director to rest easy at night! 

Why help us reach our goal? 

  1. We have a good track record. 
  2. We made our goal with Kickstarter last season.
  3. We have some wonderful gifts for our supporters. 
  4. You will forever have our love and appreciation. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know times are tough and not everyone can contribute a cash donation. Here are other ways you can help us out. 

  1. Help spread the word! Share the link to this page on your social media sites and send to your email contacts. 
  2. Visit our website www.impactdancecompany.net and share with friends! 
  3. Donate your time or talents! We can use volunteers for perfomances, marketing, anything you can think of! 
  4. Contact us if you are interested in any of the above, or if you have any of your own ideas on how you can contribute. impactdance2@yahoo.com

story:
Dance is my passion.

Hello there!

My name is Ben Green and dance is my passion. I have been dancing for a total of 3 years now, but dance has always been in my blood. Dancing with umbrellas in the living room was quite a love of mine at a very young age. So you can say that dancing runs through my veins. 

I am a contemporary dancer with training in modern dance techniques including Horton & Graham, and also training in Ballet and Jazz. I have attending Las Vegas Academy of Performing Arts as a dance major for 3 years, and have made it into the prestigious, highest level in the school for my upcoming senior year. 

My teachers have always complimented me on my work ethic, focus, and my sophomore  dance teacher said, "You work like a bull in my class." I have always taken dance very seriously and always strived to improve on my technique and develop my own style and choreography.

 

An amazing opportunity.

After the best audition of my life, I have been offered a spot on the highest Senior Performing Arts Company at Bunker Dance Center, the most prestigious and best dance studios in Nevada. It is an amazing honor to be given this opportunity and I would be the only male dancer on the team, which consists of all of my closest friends.

Being a part of the studio I will have the opportunity to work with world renowned choreographers, and So You Think You Can Dance choreographic masters, such as Peter Chu, Stacey Tookey, Travis Wall, along with taking classes with amazing faculty from professional dance companies all over the world. I have gotten the opportunity to work with these amazing individuals before, along with my dream teacher and owner of Kidd Pivot dance company, Krystal Pite, but I would love to be able to work with these choreographers and execute their pieces on a regular basis. 

Along with the amazing training and pieces I would be able to experience, Bunker Dance Center also is nationally acclaimed when it comes to dance competitions, and many of the competitions I would be a part of offer amazing college scholarships. 

All around, this is an opportunity I would devastated to have to turn down.

 

I need your help.

The tuition for my dance classes because of how advanced the company team I would be on, and the competion and travel fees, comes to about $12,000 dollars a year. 

Almost $1,000 a month. 

With my current financial situation at home, I cannot pay for this. I am able to pay bits and pieces here and there depending on the fees due that month, but I NEED YOUR HELP to make this dream come a reality.

Any donation helps! The little contributions all add up, and anything you can give helps my chances of being able to stay a part of this amazing dance company!

 

Can't donate? There are other ways to help!

As my family is struggling financially, I complete understand that a donation is not a possiblity for everyone, and that is competely okay! 

I would really appreciate it if you would just spread the word about my campaign to your friends, family, on your social networking sites, and to anyone who might be intersted in sponsoring a young dancer.

Thank you so, so, so much for your time and effort. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR HELP.

story:
Welcome to our Indiegogo campaign!  Many of you know us already, as you've supported us the past three years by coming to see one or more of our shows.  In June we're producing a staged reading of Abundance, written by Beth Henley, and a production of Talley's Folly, by Lanford Wilson.  We are hoping to raise $3,000 to pay for the following items:

1) Production Rights = $600

2) Actors & Crew = $1,000

3) Sets, Lights, Costumes & Props = $1,000

4) Publicity = $400

We've worked with many incredible people over the past three years, and this year the following folks are collaborating with us: Larry Hecht, Holly Temple, Greg Ungar, Diana Dresser, Drew Horwitz, Brian Shea, Mindi Kessler, Te Yelland, Stefan Richmond, Julia Owen, and Davy Davis.

Any size contribution will help.  Really.  $5 or $10 is great.  It'll help us buy a costume piece, or pay for a lighting instrument, or take a bite out of purchasing the licensing rights to both plays.  And if you can't contribute here, please come see ABUNDANCE and TALLEY'S FOLLY in June, and help spread the word about us.

To learn more about Sis Tryst, visit us at: www.sistryst.com.

With gratitude,

Sis Tryst Productions
Anne Penner / Ashlee Temple / Allison Watrous

story:
What’s Green Gravel?

The Green Gravel Comedy Festival is a three-day alternative comedy festival in multiple venues in the town of Toledo, Iowa. Offering affordable shows and workshops in alternative comedy, Green Gravel aims to showcase Iowa’s finest comedians while giving fans the chance to see some of their favorite headlining acts!

Thanks to everybody who contributed to our 2013 fundraiser! We shot for the moon and were able to make 30% of our "super goal" with mere social media and the occasional blog pushing us. If you pitched in: THANK YOU! 

Please visit www.greengravelcomedyfest.com for full details and tickets!


Video Credits are Fun!

We got this video together with absolutely zero budget-! We have been crazy lucky to have the talents of these ladies and gentlemen! Thank you for surviving on Porto’s and 7-11, guys. Green Gravel owes you dearly! 

Directors of Photography: Evan Watkins and Michael McAlister

Editor: Evan Watkins

Map Sequence: The Boyers Productions

Crew: Lori Finkel, Steven Feinartz, Andre Danylevich

ENORMOUS, ENDLESS, GIGANTIC THANKS: Dave Anthony and the LA PodFest crew, Todd Glass, John Ennis, The Devastator, Yes Equals Yes, Mat Alano-Martin, Jamie Flam and Kian Nafeiy. Emeralds for their brilliance in the closing tune "Candy Shoppe" - please buy their album "Does It Look Like I'm Here" here. 

OUR SPAZZIEST, DEEPEST GRATITUDE TO EVERYONE WHO PITCHED IN TO MAKE THIS VIDEO!


If you have any questions/concerns/feedback, please contact: Lee@GreenGravelComedyFest.com

To keep tabs on Green Gravel, please visit www.greengravelcomedyfest.com and/or you can follow us on Twitter or like us on Facebook! Please and thank you!


PROUD PARTNERS:

story:
The Finest! IMPACT Troupe (Inspiring Mentoring Positive Activists Called Teens) is a group of teens who research, write, and perform skits, scenarios, and dances that speak to social, political, economic, and cultural struggles.

They take snapshots of these struggles and relay them theatrically with audience participation.

IMPACT challenges audiences to look at society and ask, ï¿½what is the problem?ï¿½ and ï¿½how can we make a difference?ï¿½ IMPACT performances address how we, as people, can take responsibility for our actions, and move toward a more positive, compassionate, service-oriented society. Through thought-provoking, enthusiastic, dynamic theatre and dance (edu-tainment), IMPACT! entertains and inspires audiences to ï¿½actï¿½ towards positive change.

 

Pinneberg has extended an invitation to bring IMPACT to GERMANY!

The dates are set for July 22 - August 5, 2012.

The Rockville Sister City Corporation has pledged $5,000 toward the trip.

To make this once-in-a-lifetime educational/cultural exchange

opportunity happen for this talented troupe,

We are raising $30,000 by February 17, 2012. You can help.

 

"We all remember the most stunning and wonderful performance by The Finest! at Town Center in Rockville (Maryland) in March 2010 for the occasion of the 150th anniversary of our city,

when we all rose to our feet for a long-lasting standing ovation."

 

These are the words of James McConkey, President of the Rockville Sister City Corporation. On that day, a delegation of visitors, including the Mayor, from Pinneberg, Germany, paid the highest of tributes by asking

The Finest! IMPACT Troupe to come visit on a cultural exchange.

In a letter to the DAGRP (the Pinneberg Sister City partner) McConkey also states,

 

"...this exchange...will provide the opportunity for a life-altering experience for a group of wonderful young people... to share their art with Pinneberg and other audiences...(and)

teach some of their skills to interested individuals (in Germany)."

 

IMPACT is one of the youth ensembles that make up The Finest! Performance Troupe that began in 1989, as a part of an after school program conducted by the City of Rockville, Department of Recreation and Parks.

IMPACT is one of four performance-based ensembles that use theatre arts to engage audiences and participants, teaching conflict resolution skills, violence prevention, tolerance, leadership development, and activism.

IMPACT is a program like no other, designed to help young people develop empowering theatrical skills, leading to self confidence, heightened self-esteem, and personal integrity. The troupe is the brain-child of

Artistic Director/Choreographer/Writer and veteran performer, Kashi-Tara Barrett.

 

As part of the exchange visit, The Finest! IMPACT Troupe will choreograph and rehearse a performance piece with the championship award-winning, Pinneberger Dance Academy.

 

The good people of Pinneberg are opening their doors for two weeks to these deserving young students, and with your help, we can pay travel, touring and daily expenses.

 

Your generous donation will contribute to cultural awareness and global understanding.

Take pleasure in helping these young people of IMPACT carry this powerful message of peace and social action across the Atlantic.

Make your donation today, and help get the word out to others,

 

"TOUCH HEARTS THROUGH THEATRE ARTS!"

story:
THIS CAMPAIGN IS CLOSED. THANKS FOR THE SUPPORT! 

TO BUY TICKETS TO THE SHOW GO TO:

WWW.BROWNPAPERTICKETS.COM

 

FOR MORE INFO CHECK US OUT ON FACEBOOK @ 

https://www.facebook.com/events/195431387264049/?fref=ts

 

Who We Are

 

YOGURT is a brand new theatre company based in Vancouver, Canada. Specifically focused on bringing interesting works to new audiences. We want to help cultivate the growing interest in indie theatre in Vancouver. There is a movement of curiousity into what the new face of theatre will be, we want to be part of that discussion. Most of all We want to Share Cold Comfort with you. YOGURT -get cultured

This exciting production will be brought to you by:

 

Patrick Keating (Floyd)

Chris Cochrane (Stephen)

Katey Hoffman (Dolores)

 

Kevin Bennet (Director)

 

Christopher Gauthier (set/costumes)

Robin Richardson (Production Manager)

 

What We Need 

We need to raise funds to help pay for:

 

Set and Costumes (approx 500$)

Performance space (approx 3000$)

Rehearsal space (depends on fund raising totals)

publicity (depends on fund raising totals)

 

Cold Comfort by Jim Garrard

Cold Comfort was written in 1982 and is a very unique Canadian play. It's a dark play set in a small dilapidated house on the side of the trans-canada highway in Saskatchewan. A man crashes in a storm and is "rescued" by an older man who brings him back to his house as a gift for his Daughter who has just turned sixteen, Stephen realizes that this place is unsafe for Dorothy and that her father Floyd is clearly disturbed. He plans to take her away but Floyd has other things in mind. 

We will be performing at the Havana theatre Jan 31- Feb 9

Other Ways You Can Help

Come down to the Havana and see the show!

and of course...

Tell your friends!
