Christopher Gauthier (set/costumes)
Robin Richardson (Production Manager)
 
What We Need 


We need to raise funds to help pay for:
 
Set and Costumes (approx 500$)
Performance space (approx 3000$)
Rehearsal space (depends on fund raising totals)
publicity (depends on fund raising totals)
 


Cold Comfort by Jim Garrard
Cold Comfort was written in 1982 and is a very unique Canadian play. It's a dark play set in a small dilapidated house on the side of the trans-canada highway in Saskatchewan. A man crashes in a storm and is "rescued" by an older man who brings him back to his house as a gift for his Daughter who has just turned sixteen, Stephen realizes that this place is unsafe for Dorothy and that her father Floyd is clearly disturbed. He plans to take her away but Floyd has other things in mind. 
We will be performing at the Havana theatre Jan 31- Feb 9
Other Ways You Can Help


Come down to the Havana and see the show!
and of course...
Tell your friends!

story:
What is BloodPlay? 

'BloodPlay.', presented by the Nuyorican Poet's Cafe, is a reading series of three new plays, by three new playwrights on three different nights, October 20th, 21st, and 22nd. 

These plays are going to be presented in the renown cultural epicenter of the New York City, the Nuyorican Poet's Cafe, and performed by local actors under the direction of New York City's hottest young directors. 

The plays include:

Parading the Noose by Connor Lane Sampson

When Osama Bin Laden’s death is broadcast to America, a bus accident, love, and secrets drive a whirlwind competition to claim who is the most victim. 

FIND. by Tristan Carter-Jones

Told through a series of two person conversations, FIND. chronicles the mental breakdown of a young woman named Stay.

Miami is Sinking / Pastelito Guerreras by Thomas Daníel Valls 

An hour before Miami is swallowed by an ocean surge, four friends reunite on the Beach to fulfill their pact that would make them the Warriors of Miami.

What We Need & What You Get

The project needs $600 for the sole purpose of publicity. With one event spanning across three different nights for three different plays each night, we need as much attention as we can get!

The Nuyorican Poets Cafe has GRACIOUSLY provided their beautiful facility for us to use and our wonderful directors and actors are working with our writers, entirely free of payment. 

Any and ALL fundraising money that exceeds the $600 mark will go straight into the pockets of our director, stage manager, and actors- so there's no reason to stop as soon as we hit the $600 goal! 

Of COURSE, we have some awesomely unique and personable perks for any and all who donate even a dollar; so be sure to check the perks for a detailed breakdown!

The Impact

These three plays will be presented at their rawest and most tender form for live audiences, giving our writers, directors, and actors to converse with the public, to cultivate new ideas, and cut deep into the skin in hopes of developing broader visions for the stories' futures. 

Our three writers are recent graduates of NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, where they spent the past four years working and developing plays together. Collectively, their work has been presented, performed, and produced locally, regionally, and nationally; and this is just the beginning!

Other Ways You Can Help

If for whatever reason you are unable to contribute; no worries! 

Please contact us at our event email; bloodplaytheseries@gmail.com and we will provide you with a press package; put us up on your facebook! Take a picture on your phone and mass text it to your friends! Tweet about it! Do all that you can!

No matter what though; be sure to check out BLOODPLAY. a series in Three Parts at the Nuyorican Poet's Cafe October 20th, 21st, and 22nd. All plays begin at 7 PM and drinks will be served starting at 6 PM!

story:
Check out photography on display in Gorham, ME at The Gorham Grind. All proceeds from the sale will go to the project!


Short Summary

I'm a twenty year old college student from Maine. I spent over a month last year in Kenya learning about the health system, meeting clinicians and getting to know a beautiful country with huge potential. The people I met there have a passion to help their fellow citizens, but the opportunity is too often few and far between. We have a recyclable, easy-to-use, cost-effective and most importantly life-changing clubfoot bracing system. This innovation will allow communities to change the future's of it's children. This deformity can no longer steal regular lives from the 1 in 1000 children born each year. It's design is perfect for an underdeveloped system and this fundraiser will allow us to bring it to the communities in Kenya.

What We Need & Where It Goes

The specifics of this project are straightforward. The brace is incredibly easy to use, once someone has basic training (which can easily be done in less than an hour). It is a plastic brace that comes in a size that has fit every child treated so far. It can be used again and again throughout each community. The funds we need are in order to bring us back to the nation of Kenya to do the initial training and to create enough braces to provide the clinics and health centers with. 

The Impact

This project has the potential to make treating clubfoot in Kenya a reality. Currently this is a deformity that means the end of a life for a child in Kenya. It means no ability to walk or work and in many cases, in a developing nation, that means no livelihood for the child. There is no future for too many children crippled with clubfoot. However, this bracing system seems to be a perfect, easy and renewable system to give them back the chance at life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't give to our fundraiser, we would love your support. Spread the world about our site and our mission! Send the link to your friends and family. Knowledge is key and we need help to get knowledge of our project out there!

Thank you for taking some time out of your busy workday or from a long to-do list. This could mean the world to so many- we appreciate really appreciate the read.

story:
Who Are We

We are a youth run non-profit theatre company in Kingston, Ontario looking to raise funds to help us continue to provide opportunities in theatre for youth between the ages of 13-30. Blue Canoe has been established in our community for the past 7 years; we have produced 22 productions engaging over 500 youth in theatre, dance, music and theatre production. Several of our alumni have gone on to pursue theatre at post-secondary and professional levels. Our goal is to provide youth a chance to explore the performing arts as a platform to further pursuits or simply as an outlet for creativity. We need your support to help continue to offer these wonderful opportunities to our membership.

You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown- 2012

Why We Need Your Help

Kingston’s youth theatre company is looking for funding to help continue to provide opportunities for young people between the ages of 13-30 in the performing arts. We help them to gain experience creating theatre in the community of Kingston, not just within the school systems. As a non-profit organization, we have access to project funds to help specific productions, but not operation expenses to offset space rental, insurance, storage and other day to day expenses. Though we have been able to bring in funds through ticket sales, the company continues to grow and ticket sales are simply not enough to keep us operating.

Many student run companies have been able to engage youth at the post-secondary schools or within high schools, but the unique opportunities Blue Canoe offers bring students into the community and with your help, this funding will enable our company to continue to serve the youth of our community.

 

The Drowsy Chaperone- 2013

Blue Canoe’s Impact on the Community

Blue Canoe brings High School, Post Secondary and other youths together under one roof for the same common goal: to create quality affordable theatre for the community of Kingston and the 1000 Islands. Over the past 7 years we have engaged over 500 youth in 22 theatrical productions in Kingston and Gananoque.

In our 2012 season we produced 5 musical productions all at the Baby Grand Theatre, downtown Kingston, with audiences all over 88% of our total house capacity, with 3 productions having sold out runs; Cabaret (January 2012), You’re a Good Man Charlie Brown (April 2012) and Avenue Q (August 2012). We have animated the Baby Grand theatre with big musicals and entertained the community with our energy and drive.

The Kingston Whig Standard on Blue Canoe:

The Drowsy Chaperone 4.5 stars out of 5
Next to Normal 4 stars out of 5
You’re a Good Man Charlie Brown 4 stars out of 5
Tick, Tick...BOOM 4 stars out of 5
Sweet Charity 4 stars out of 5

Glengarry Glen Ross- 2011

“Imaginative, energetic and engaging” Kingston Whig Standard on Cabaret, 2012

"Every once in a while, I go to a play that makes me want to wear sunglasses because it dazzles and sparkles so much. Such is the case with Blue Canoe’s production of The Drowsy Chaperone." Kingston Whig Standard on The Drowsy Chaperone, 2013

"Production is a cut above the rest!" Kingston Whig Standard on Sweeney Todd, 2010

Testimonials

Watch for more testimonials in a new video by Artistic Associate Jordan Richards, coming soon…

Lee Clapp, BCP Alumni
"My decision to pursue a Bachelor’s degree in Voice Performance was definitely influenced by my performance experience with Blue Canoe.  The challenging yet comfortable environment was essential in fostering the development of my skill and confidence as both a young performer and person.  Blue Canoe really provides invaluable opportunity to young individuals, which in turn contributes in such a big way to Kingston’s whole artistic community."

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you run a business and would like to purchase advertising space in our show programs, you can contact our general manager at gm.bluecanoe@gmail.com. Or you can make a private donation to the theatre company by contacting us.

Please pass around information about our campaign and help keep Blue Canoe afloat.

Visit our Website: www.bluecanoeproductions.ca
Like us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/BlueCanoePro
Watch us on Youtube: www.youtube.com/BlueCanoePro
Follow us on Twitter: www.twitter.com/Blue_Canoe_Pro

General Inquires: blue.canoe@hotmail.com or 613-449-5777

story:
Who We Are

The Fire This Time Festival is a platform for early-career playwrights of African descent to explore new voices, styles and challenging new directions for contemporary theater.

Exploring themes from euthanasia, hero-worship, inter-generational conflict, homophobia, and more, the Fire This Time Festival creates dynamic theatrical experiences. The festival has quickly become a destination for diverse audiences, producers, and artists seeking exciting possibilities and opportunities in contemporary drama.

 

Our New Season

Our fourth season begins in January 2013. Our core program will be a full production of short plays, running over two weeks. We will introduce new work from:  

                                    

Dennis A. Allen II

Danielle Davenport

Jason Holtham

Tracey Conyer Lee

Eric Lockley

Nehanda Loiseau

Cynthia Robinson

Nathan Yungerberg

 

In addition to our core program, several playwrights from prior seasons will return with staged readings of full-length works.  Panel discussions are also a part of our annual events.

 

The Campaign - $5,000 in Two Months

In this challenging economy, we remain committed to keeping ticket prices low, and making sure audiences from all income levels can attend our shows.  As we seek donations, the Festival has attracted support from a few core individuals and we've even gotten a few grants. But it is not enough to cover all expenses. 

$5,000 will close our gap for the season.  This $5,000 will go directly to the artistic expenses for the program, giving us the means to actually compensate our roster of talented actors, directors and other collaborators. 

We're engaging nearly 40 artists this year, and were not promising them millions, but we would like to provide modest stipends and cover travel costs.  You can help us do that.

The Festival has reached a very exciting moment.  Many of our playwrights, directors and actors are enjoying new and exciting professional opportunities. There has never been more demand for what we do.  And we want to do more! 

Help us keep the fire burning by making a donation today!

 

More on What We Do

The first season of the festival brought together over thirty performers, directors, and other collaborators to create an amazing evening of short one-act plays. Presented by Horse Trade Theater Group over a sold-out run in February 2010. The Festival has evolved into an annual event, expanding upon its core short play presentations to offer panel discussions, staged readings, and other programs.

 To date, the Fire This Time Festival has produced new work by the following playwrights: Jesse Cameron Alick, Deborah Asiimwe, France-Luce Benson, Jocelyn Bioh, Radha Blank, Christine Jean Chambers, Camille Darby, Kevin R. Free, Marcus Gardley, Kelley Nicole Girod, Katori Hall, Ione Lloyd, Zoey Martinson, Yusef Miller, Derek Lee McPhatter, Dominique Morisseau, Antoinette Nwandu, Jerome Parker, Germono Toussaint, and Pia Wilson. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't make a contribution there are many ways to help. Tell your friends about our campaign.  Join our mailing list, or inquire about volunteer opportunities.  We want to hear from you! www.firethistimefestival.com

story:
SICK CITY BLUES

Jake Shore's SICK CITY BLUES is a full-length drama about organized crime and the crooks who try to stop it appearing in FringeNYC'14. 

Location: The Connelly Theater: 220 E 4th st, Manhattan, NY
Dates: (Saturday: 8/9, 9:00-10:20pm) (Monday: 8/11, 7:00-8:20pm) (Thursday: 8/14, 4:45-6:05pm) (Saturday: 8/16, NOON-1:20pm) (Friday: 8/22, 1:15-2:35pm)
Featuring: Stephen Heskett, Cara Moretto, Justin Colon, Adam Files and Gavin Starr Kendall.
"...but in the delicate performance of Mr. Heskett, Len is more than a joke. It's a scene stealing portrayal..." -The New York Times Review of Stephen Heskett's performance in Ecstasy.
Jake Shore
Shore is a writer, director and Adjunct English Professor at Wagner College and Monroe College. FringeNYC'13 gave Shore's DOWN THE MOUNTAIN AND ACROSS THE STREAM an Overall Excellence in Playwriting Award. Indie Theater Now put DOWN THE MOUNTAIN into their "Best of FringeNYC'13" collection, and the play was a Top Ten Choice for the Stanley Drama Award. 
Shore's short fiction has appeared in Litro, Halfway Down the Stairs, The Pitkin Review, Calico Tiger and Fiction365.com. 
Why Money? 

To Shore's dismay, putting on a play costs much more than writing it down. Below is a breakdown. 

Every donation helps, and you'll get gifts. Please look right for the gifts. 

Fringe/Marketing Fees: $900

Artist Fees: $550

Rehearsal Fees: $600

Postcard/Program Fees: $300 

The Reason

During life's darkest times, fulfilled art is light. Shore began working furiously on SICK CITY BLUES the week DOWN THE MOUNTAIN AND ACROSS THE STREAM opened, and finished tinkering in time to start rehearsing for FringeNYC'14. Your donations will fuel SICK CITY BLUES and give it a fighting chance in the largest multi-arts festival in North America.

story:
Hi and thank you for checking out our campaign!  Are you looking for a new theatrical experience this holiday season that’ll lift your spirits without seeing any ghosts? We’ve written a new, original feel-good musical for the holidays and want to present the World Premiere this season – with your help. It’s a musicalized version of the beloved short story by O. Henry, “Gift of the Magi”, with additional characters and plot lines.

The story takes place in New York City circa 1905, where a young woman named Della wants to buy her husband, Jim, a gold chain for his cherished pocket watch, but can’t afford it. So, she sells her gorgeous long hair in order to buy it. When she buys it and gives it to him at Christmas, he can no longer use it, because he sold his precious watch in order to buy Della beautiful combs for her long hair! It’s a poignant, ironic tale of sacrifice and love.

We’re planning to produce this musical in the Los Angeles area for a 3-week run in December 2014 and need to raise $40,000 in order to do it. That’s where we need your help. And we have great perks for you, too! You’ll be a part of presenting a heart-warming piece of theatre to the community and receive our undying gratitude.

“Gift of the Magi: The Musical" was presented as a staged reading by the Dramatists Guild a few years ago and was very well-received. We look forward to taking the next step in its development, if you can give us your support. We appreciate any amount. Think of your donation as an early holiday gift. : - )


If you’d like to donate, but don’t want to do it online, you may send a check made out to FRACTURED ATLAS  and mail it to: The Magi Company P.O. Box 333 Lake Forest, CA 92609. Thanks!

And if you can’t afford to donate, please “like”, share, or comment on our sites, or forward this email to friends.

Thank you in advance!


Beverly Bremers & Faith Grant


OUR DIRECTOR

We're so excited! We just confirmed Barry Pearl as our director! Barry is best known as Doody in the film of "Grease", and the Broadway productions of "Baby, It's You", "Bye Bye Birdie", "Oliver!", & "The Producers". Plus he has directed & acted in countless theatrical productions all over the country, including "Night Hawks", "Harry Days - The Musical", "Twelve Angry Men", Hairspray", & "Guys & Dolls" in Los Angeles and "Grease" at the Cabrillo Music Theatre in Thousand Oaks.  So our show is in very capable, loving hands.


ABOUT  US - THE WRITERS

Beverly Bremers – Composer/Lyricist - Beverly has written the music & lyrics for 4 stage musicals which were produced in Los Angeles and San Diego: “O’Mary’s”, produced twice in San Diego at the Hahn Cosmopolitan Theatre and Diversionary Theatre. “The Glitter Palace” had the distinction of running for over 9 months at the Playbill Theatre in Hollywood, starring such notables as Marcia Wallace, Orson Bean, and Lu Leonard. “Have A Jewish Christmas” had a holiday romp at the Victory Theatre in Burbank, and Bev’s first musical, “Born A Unicorn”, played the Inner City Cultural Center in Los Angeles directed by Ted Lange (“Love Boat”).




Beverly received a platinum record for writing the energetic song, “Mousercise” for Disney, which became the theme for the long-running show on the Disney Channel, a show at Disneyland, and a video. She has also enjoyed chart success with several of her songs in the U.S. and Europe, including “Morning Music” and the theme from the film, “Hopscotch”.

Additionally, Beverly has been the recipient of several awards such as the L.A. Weekly Best Musical for “The Glitter Palace”, the AGLA Image Award for “The Glitter Palace”, The American Song Festival Best Song, and the Seoul International Song Festival Best Song, where she represented the United States as performer and composer.

Beverly is also a known recording artist & actor, having starred on Broadway in “Hair” and “The Me Nobody Knows”, starred in the Los Angeles productions of “The Rocky Horror Show” and “Menopause the Musical” and hit the charts with the million-selling, “Don’t Say You Don’t Remember” & “We’re Free”. She has also appeared on numerous TV shows & films, as well as commercials, industrials, clubs, & concerts.

Faith Grant – Book – Faith began her writing career working as an entertainment journalist for LA City News Network and had her own entertainment column in the Salem Times Newspaper in Oregon.  She was also a staff writer for the American Psychiatric Association’s newspaper interviewing such notable individuals as Carl Sagan.

Faith worked for many years for Bob Stewart Productions (25,000 Pyramid, Celebrity Double Talk) assisting in the development of various new game shows and writing puzzles and copy for their game shows on the air. 

After that, she became a staff writer for Kushner-Locke Productions and Four Point Entertainment penning 14 produced teleplays for the long running show Divorce Court. Additionally, she worked as a story editor for many produced television scripts executing final editing and revisions. 

Gift of the Magi: The Musical is a very dear project to Faith since it is based on arguably the most famous work of her favorite short story author, O. Henry.

LOGO PAINTING - Melissa Daye, Tatoo artist & painter.

BUDGET

Salaries - Artistic, Technical, Front of House: 60%

14 actors • 4 musicians • Director • Music Director • Orchestrator • Choreographer • Designers (Set, Lighting, Costumes, Props) • Playwright and Composer Royalties • Stage Manager • House Manager • Technical Director • Carpenter(s) • Light and Sound Board Operators • Running Crew

Rental Costs: 15%

Performance Space • Rehearsal Space

Materials: 7%

Set Materials • Costume Materials • Prop Materials

Publicity: 15%

Publicist • Photographer • Poster/ Flyer/ Postcard Design and Printing • Bulk Mailing Costs • Paid Listings/Advertisements • Poster Service • Website Design and Maintenance

Other: 3%

Box Office Services • Audio Recording • Video Recording • Script Copying • Ticket and Program Printing

Please visit www.giftofthemagithemusical.com to read the synopsis, writer’s bios, & listen to the music.

Please tell your friends about the show and this campaign:

    • "Like" posts associated with GIFT OF THE MAGI: THE MUSICAL
    • Share this funding link on social media 
    • Send people to our website - www.giftofthemagithemusical.com
    • Follow our Tweets - www.twitter.com/gift_magi_music
story_txt:
Hi and thank you for checking
out our campaign! 
Are you looking for a new theatrical experience this
holiday season that’ll lift your spirits without seeing any ghosts? We’ve
written a new, original feel-good musical for the holidays and want to present
the World Premiere this season – with your help. It’s a musicalized version of
the beloved short story by O. Henry, “Gift of the Magi”, with additional
characters and plot lines. 




The story takes place in New York City circa 1905, where
a young woman named Della wants to buy her husband, Jim, a gold chain for his
cherished pocket watch, but can’t afford it. So, she sells her gorgeous long
hair in order to buy it. When she buys it and gives it to him at Christmas, he
can no longer use it, because he sold his precious watch in order to buy Della
beautiful combs for her long hair! It’s a poignant, ironic tale of sacrifice
and love.




We’re planning to produce this musical in the Los Angeles
area for a 3-week run in December 2014 and need to raise $40,000 in order to do
it. That’s where we need your help. And we have great perks for you, too!
You’ll be a part of presenting a heart-warming piece of theatre to the
community and receive our undying gratitude.




“Gift of the Magi: The Musical" was presented as a staged
reading by the Dramatists Guild a few years ago and was very well-received. We
look forward to taking the next step in its development, if you can give us
your support. We appreciate any amount. Think of your donation as an early
holiday gift. : - )




If you’d like to donate, but
don’t want to do it online, you may send a check made out to FRACTURED
ATLAS  and mail it to: The Magi Company P.O. Box 333 Lake Forest, CA 92609. Thanks!






And if you can’t afford to donate, please “like”, share, or
comment on our sites, or forward this email to friends. 

Thank you in advance!



Beverly Bremers & Faith Grant


OUR DIRECTOR

director! Barry is best known as Doody in the film 
of "Grease", and the Broadway productions of "Baby, It's
You", "Bye Bye Birdie", "Oliver!", & "The Producers". Plus he has directed & acted in countless theatrical
productions all over the country, including "Night Hawks", "Harry Days - The Musical", "Twelve Angry Men", Hairspray", & "Guys & Dolls" in Los

story:
Hi!

I'm Tim McCorry and I sincerely appreciate that you've taken the time to consider this fundraising campaign for Coyote, a brand new musical!

Here is a brief synopsis:

Based on a true story, Coyote is a modern American tale of love and immigration. Pedro and Bernadice are young lovers determined to be reunited. Bernadice hires a mysterious smuggler known only as Coyote to sneak Pedro across the border and elude the authorities.  In an amazing journey from Guatemala to the Pacific Northwest, they discover the power of friendship and love to overcome betrayal and fear.

Back to the pitch!:

The music and lyrics are written and the proceeds of this fundraiser will help to  put it before a room full of industry professionals in what is called a "29 hour reading". It will fund the "Broadway Ready", fully orchestrated, professionally sung performances that potential producers need to hear in order to get Coyote to the stage!

For me, this has already been an amazing journey. When I first received the page and a half true story that is now Coyote, I was astonished by how mesmerized I was. I now realize that as the grandson of immigrants, the "coming to America" story still resonates. As I wrote the songs which are the mileposts of the story, I have become ever more deeply engaged in the dual threads that make this such a compelling story. First, the power of love to overcome fear and second, the determination of people everywhere, to make a better life for themselves and their families. It is my hope that Coyote will advance both of these themes.

Each of the songs of the Coyote describes in vivid detail the action and emotions of the moment, They are as varied in dynamic range and rhythms as the journey itself from tender romantic ballads to dark and fantastic flights of illusion. Choreography will no doubt take the effect of several of the songs to even higher levels.

As I have written the songs for a story that covers over three thousand miles, I have also become immersed in the "Pan American" sounds that will inspire the orchestrations. One such example is the marimba, the national instrument of Guatemala with its rich and expressive melodic history of Mayan and Spanish influence.

I have spent the past 3 years at my piano, "the orchestra in a box", as I like to call it, composing the music of Coyote. With your help, it will now leap to the stage! 

You can read and hear more of Coyote at  www.CoyoteTheMusical.com . You can also join our Facebook fan page at Facebook.com/coyotethemusical and please spread the word by sharing the news with as many folks as you can.

Thank you so much for reading and I hope to see you  on Broadway!
Merry Christmas, Happy Hannukkah and Happy New Year!

Sincerely,

Tim McCorry

story:
Bonjour à tous,

 Je m’appelle Gaëlle Le Roy, j’ai 35 ans,  je suis comédienne et j’ai eu cette année  l’opportunité d’avoir carte blanche pour présenter le spectacle de mon choix, dans la programmation culturelle de la ville de Champagne aux Mont d’or.

C’est ainsi que Dernier Appel pour Broadway est né. Je me suis dit que quitte à écrire une pièce de théâtre, autant y mettre tout ce que j’aime et me faire un maximum plaisir en l’interprétant.

C’est pourquoi ce spectacle est avant tout MUSICAL ! En effet, étant  une grande fan des Comédies Musicales anglaises et américaines je rêvais de chanter et de danser sur scène accompagnée de musiciens « live » et pas d’une bande son. Interpréter  le genre de rôle qui ne nous est que trop rarement proposé !  À Lyon en tout cas…

 Je tenais également  à ce que cette pièce soit un moment de détente et de rire, c’est pourquoi ma pièce :  « Dernier Appel Pour Broadway », même si elle est construite sur une situation de départ « dramatique », et qu’elle défend  une idée qui m’est précieuse, reste une COMEDIE !  Avec ses codes et ses personnages hauts en couleurs. 

Le PITCH :

Prenez un  célèbre show man qui a perdu la mémoire et une femme  au caractère bien trempé prête à toutes les extravagances pour la lui faire recouvrir ; Ajouter un ouragan, et deux policiers complètement déjantés, arrosez le tout de grands airs de comédies musicales  et de quelques standards du jazz américain… et vous obtiendrez une comédie piquante ,chantante et dansante, pleine de quiproquos et de rebondissements.

DERNIER APPEL POUR BROADWAY ,une comédie pailletée qui nous rappelle qu’il faut toujours se battre jusqu’au bout pour les choses qui nous tiennent vraiment à cœur.

                                                     #            #             #

J’ai personnellement  eu la chance de voir en  « vrai » Ce genres de Shows à Broadway et à Londres, et  j’en suis revenue avec des paillettes plein les yeux, alors en créant ce spectacle, l’idée était de partager un peu de ces paillettes avec le public. A mon échelle bien entendu !

Mais même à mon échelle, un spectacle comme celui-ci, pour être crédible et professionnel, demande un minimum de fonds. C’est pourquoi  je lance auprès de vous  cet appel aux dons.

En effet, l’argent récolté permettra entre autres de financer :

Les décors

Les costumes

Les accessoires

La communication (affiches ,tracts, pub internet )

Les cours de Chants

La chorégraphe

La location des salles de répétitions

Les défraiements divers

L’accordage du piano pour chaque représentation

Il est très important pour moi de récolter ces fonds, afin de pouvoir monter ce spectacle dans les meilleures conditions, et  offrir à notre public un spectacle de qualité, qui lui laissera j’espère, le souvenir d’un excellent moment passé en notre compagnie.

 Ce projet me tient vraiment à cœur car il s’agit de ma première expérience en tant qu’auteur et metteur en scène et j’ai la chance d’avoir une équipe formidable et talentueuse,  qui m’accompagne et me fait confiance sur ce projet :

Comédiens : Elise Dano, Réda Chéraitia, François Tantot.

Piano : Grégory Ballesteros ou Cécile Wouters

Chorégraphie : Mélanie Ferrière

Assistant à la mise en scène : Matthieu Loos

Création Lumière :Eymeric Jorat

Traduction en québécois : Camille German

 C’est donc  pour eux et pour notre futur public que je vous le demande :

A VOTRE BON CŒUR M’SIEURS DAMES ! Aidez-nous à vous faire rêver .Vous pourrez voir par vous-même ce que nous aurons fait de ce fantastique  financement participatif, dès le :

12 JANVIER 2014 car DERNIER APPEL POUR BROADWAY est programmé  dans la très belle salle de LA COMEDIE ODEON rue grolée  69002 LYON

Tous les Dimanches à 14h30 !jusqu’à fin mai.

Ce sont les petits ruisseaux qui font les grandes rivières, alors peu importe la somme que vous pourrez donner, l’important est de participer et surtout de faire passer cet appel autour de vous ! en utilisant les outils à votre disposition sur ce site d’indiegogo, sur les réseaux sociaux, par mails etc…

ON COMPTE SUR VOUS !!

D’avance merci, et Rendez-vous le 12 Janvier ! 

Gaëlle Le ROY

Et La Compagnie Les Babilleurs

story:
The Show

Dear Life is an original play written by Sophia Woodward and directed by Sachi Lovatt. It will be premiering at the 2013 Vancouver Fringe Festival. Come support independent, local theatre! 

Site-Specific Theatre
Dear Life is part of the Fringe Onsite Program in the 2013 Vancouver Fringe Festival. This is site-specific theatre, meaning the show is written for, and performed at, a specific location: the Granville Island kid's waterpark.

Synopsis
Two sisters trapped in the realm between life and death battle a fearful darkness that holds them there. Will they take grasp of the life they let slip through their fingers, or be ferried prematurely to their death -- or worse, be condemned to limbo for eternity? Sibling angst and sword fights ensue.

Us - Sachi & Sophia

We are actors, friends and roommates embarking to create our own work and tell compelling, relevant stories. Together we created the theatre production company, The Seicho Sisters. "Seicho" means growth. We constantly seek personal growth and development in our personal and creative lives.

Since a very young age, Sophia has dreamed of creating her own work and playing her own characters. She is thrilled for her play, Dear Life, to mark the beginning of this dream's realization.

What We Need

This is a non-for-profit endeavour. We have a budget of $1200 that is soley dedicated to the production itself. Funds are needed for: props, extension cords, sound equipment, graphic design, poster printing, photography, videography, lights, costumes, make up, set dec, and more. And this doesn't even include the $800 Fringe mentorship program fee!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially to this production, it would be most helpful if you could spread the word about this show- the more people who can come see the performance the better!
 
How? Refer people to our website: www.dearlifetheplay.com or encourage them to look up "Dear Life" at www.vancouverfringe.com and buy a ticket. And share this indiegogo page on your social media accounts!
Find Dear Life on page 53 of the Fringe Program Guide

And this doesn't even include the $800 Fringe mentorship program fee!


Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to contribute financially to this production, it would be most helpful if you could spread the word about this show- the more people who can come see the performance the better!
 

How? Refer people to our website: www.dearlifetheplay.com or encourage them to look up "Dear Life" at www.vancouverfringe.com and buy a ticket. And share this indiegogo page on your social media accounts!
Find Dear Life on page 53 of the Fringe Program Guide

story:
Short Summary

Hi. My name is Carrie, and I'm a Special Effects Makeup Artist. What is special effects, you may ask? Special effects is the makeup, or general effect (Such as something catching fire, or getting shot) that is done on camera, or on stage. Don't get it confused with Visual Effects, which are done Post production, usually with CGI.

Raising this money is very important to me, because otherwise with my current financial situation, I would not be able to expand my current makeup kit from the point where it is at now, to a more practical and versatile kit. And if I want to go anywhere with makeup, I won't get far with what I have now.

Any donations towards my goal will be greatly appreciated.

What We Need & What You Get

With the money I raise, all of it will be put towards my makeup kit. I would really like to replace my grease paints with the highly superior alcohol activated paints, getting Third degree, a silicon modelling compound,  and much much more.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just taking the time to read all of this has meant the world to me, so even if you can't contribute, you're still Number One in my heart!

**NOTE:One of the great things about IndieGogo, is that even if I don't reach my campaign goal in time, I will still get to keep however much money I raise. ALL FUNDS raised by this campaign WILL be put towards makeup

story:
WHY WE'RE HERE 

Hi, we're Rock Bottom Movement. We're taking on our very first 'official' dance short film project & we're looking for some support to help us make it happen. For the first time in RBM history we have 4 artists collaborating from all different sectors to create a truly original work that will be accessible, online, for free to anyone who'd like to dive into the world of the company even if only for a few minutes. 
We really can't do this without your support. We've been so lucky to have such amazing backing so far and we will continue to make work and be smart financially in order to keep spreading and sharing our vision. Each and every donor and supporter stays near and dear to our hearts. We are endlessly grateful and truly realize how important you are to the community we've worked to build! 
We're serious about this, and we're in it for the long haul. But until we're recognized for having been operating for a while we need to look for some help in places past grants and prizes. Help us get there. This video is a crucial stepping stone for us. 

PERKS! 
It's Canada. It's cold. We get it. And we don't want you to have to trudge out in the snow to come watch our work (but we don't want that to mean we have to stop working!). BONUS? We'll even keep your noggin' warm as you watch us from the comfort of your own home. 
Every donation 25$ or more will receive a Rock Bottom Movement custom toque delivered straight to your door. Additionally, every donation 50$ or more will also receive a limited edition copy of the DVD!
EVERY donation will get a shout out on our social media. So you can brag to your friends about how awesome you are for supporting the arts. 

ANYTHING HELPS! 
Anyone who knows us will tell you we know a thing or two about making a little go a long way. Anything & everything helps us cover rentals, costumes, materials etc. If you cannot contribute financially become our wing men & women. Help us share our message! The goal is simple. We're after the ability to share our art with as many people as possible - any way you can help us in that is SO very appreciated. 

THE ARTISTS 
4 main artists from very different disciplines are collaborating to develop a truly original creation. 
Alyssa Martin - Choreographer & Co-Director (Toronto)
Rene Gibson - Videographer & Co-Director (Toronto)
David Robert Shewchuk - Composer & Violinist (UK)
Kelsey Wilson - Costume & Visual Design (Montreal)

5 of the RBM Company Members will be performing in the film and working with Alyssa on the development of the work. 
Mary-Dora Bloch-Hansen - Company Member Since 2012 
Corrado Cerruto -  2012 
Julia Cosentino -  2014 
Josh Doig - 2013 
Taylor Hunt -  2012 

ABOUT THE COMPANY
Founded in 2012 by choreographer Alyssa Martin, Rock Bottom Movement is a Toronto-based company dedicated to the creation and presentation of inventive original dance work. The company prides itself in celebrating the individual and the imagination in all its glories and all its flaws, especially the latter. Alyssa’s work with Rock Bottom Movement has been featured in many festivals, exhibitions, installations and events. The company has busked all over the downtown core of Toronto and have presented and toured multiple self produced full length works. Rock Bottom Movement’s work has been hailed as vivacious, hilarious, psychedelic, innovative, playful and clever. In addition to performing, RBM inspires local youth [the next generation of mover and shakers] through creative workshops. A growing company, Rock Bottom Movement hopes to break the boundaries between dance and theatre, inspiring audiences ages 3 to 103 to start dancing in their kitchens.

story:
Short Summary

This production tells of two families who've been affected by a common enemy, but neither family saw it coming.  There were no predictors on what was about to take place and how drastically their lives would be changed forever.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to be able to put on a production that would educate individuals and their families regarding Alzheimer’s and Dementia,  through Performing Arts and provide an outlet especially for caregivers.  We want to also be able to connect them to resources within their community.

In order to do this we need a budget of $20,000 which will help to cover the following:

  • The band
  • Stipend for the actors
  • Sound and Lighting
  • Theater space rental for tech rehearsal(s) and show(s)
  • Set design and prop rental
  • Wardrobe
  • Marketing & Advertising
  • Resource gathering for caregivers and their families in various cities

Perks are to the right of this campaign:

There are perks to the right of this campaign some of which are at various levels that will help to bring this production to the stage, a voice to those that are affected, and that will also show our appreciation for your support.  Secret Perks are available at the Silver through Platinum levels.

Availability of perks:

  • Platinum Level (1)  - available through special link
  • Gold Level (3) - available through special link
  • Silver Level (10)  - available through special link
  • Bronze Level (6)



The Impact

There are a number of people and families within certain communities that have been affected by Alzheimer’s or Dementia, but some of them are suffering in silence.  For the vast majority this is their first encounter with a disease of this magnitude and they don’t know how to deal with the feelings and emotional baggage that this disease can bring.

Education is key and bringing this information to people in a comfortable, entertaining, but yet realistic way that will give people the space to share, laugh, cry, feel connected, be uplifted, become educated, and feel empowered to make a difference and know that they are not alone.

This will also help families to make more informed decisions when it comes to the care of a loved one as well as the importance of taking care of themselves as a caregiver.

Risks & Challenges

This is a first time run for Just 1 Voice Productions, which is the reason why we have chosen to partner with Gifted Productions, a seasoned professional theatrical company.  This will help to minimize mistakes, cost overruns, and keep everything on track.  There are always going to be challenges in putting on any professional show, but we don't want lack of funding to one of them. The subject matter is of major importance considering the number of Americans and their families who have found themselves caring for loved ones with little to know help or former knowledge of the disease and all that it brings.  We welcome and need your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute to the campaign at the levels that are posted, there are other ways in which you can be of assistance:

  • Get the word out by forming what is known as a street team and make some noise about our campaign if you would like for it to be your city and use social media to spread the word.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word.
  • All donations in any monetary amount are welcome.  So please donate

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Hi everybody. If we haven't met, my name is Walker Vreeland and I'm an actor, singer, writer and radio personality. I am so excited that my autobiographical monologue FROM SHIP TO SHAPE will be making its New York premiere at the United Solo Theatre Festival in September of 2017. Please help this show make its mark in NY so that this important story can reach as many people as possible.
 

What is FROM SHIP TO SHAPE?

When I was 23, I took a job as a lead singer for Norwegian Cruise Lines. But I could never have imagined the voyage that lay ahead. Boarding the Bermuda-bound ship would precipitate a mental breakdown so severe, I would wind up months later at Johns Hopkins Hospital's Mood Disorder Psychiatric Ward. FROM SHIP TO SHAPE is a tragicomic (and musical) autobiographical monologue about one young man’s struggle with mental illness in today’s world. It's about losing your mind while chasing your dreams, the relentless pursuit of healing and how a cruise ship can push you over the edge. Learn more about the show at www.fromshiptoshape.com
 

The Impact 

Here's why FROM SHIP TO SHAPE is a story that needs to be told:

  • The more awareness raised about the issue of mental illness the better it is for everyone. A more educated, enlightened public means those who need help are more likely to get it, and the medical community receives the support necessary to provide and improve that help.
  • The subject matter is universal. One in four people struggle with mental illness in some form. We are not alone. And yet, the stigma surrounding it is still prevalent in our culture. Most people don't want to talk about it, even in this day and age. Did you know that only half of those affected seek treatment because they are embarrassed or ashamed? According to The National Alliance on Mental Illness, “The average delay between the onset of symptoms and intervention is 8-10 years.”
  • Standing up and telling our stories of suffering and recovery with honesty, humor and self-acceptance normalizes mental illness and ensures the stigma and shame is upstaged by a sense of shared humanity, solidarity and the dignity that all survivors deserve to feel. A world in which we can laugh at and make fun of our own mental breakdowns is a world in which those who are instinctually reticent to reach out for the help they so desperately need will more likely have the courage to do so.


What I Need

My ultimate goal is for the show to have a run Off-Broadway and subsequent tour so that it may reach as wide an audience as possible. Then I intend to adapt the monologue into a book, and then a film.

In order to get there, I need this premiere to have an impact. The show needs to sell as much as possible, so that a real buzz is created, so that it's reviewed as much as possible, so that the right people see it- people who will be able to assist in taking FROM SHIP TO SHAPE to its next stage of evolution.

All funds raised will go towards the following expenses:

  • rehearsal space
  • marketing items (such as flyers, programs, etc.)
  • hiring a director
  • hiring a stage manager
  • hiring a lighting designer
  • hiring lighting and sound operators
  • hiring musicians to play for the show
  • hiring a publicist
  • advertising

***5% of all funds raised will be donated to The Alexander Wilson Schweizer Fellowship which funds a mood disorders teaching program at Johns Hopkins Hospital. The Fellowship is a permanently endowed fund, the income from which is used to educate families and the public on understanding depression and bipolar disorder; and to train psychiatrists and other professionals in mood disorders research and clinical care.

 

What You Get

See the list of our Indiegogo perks! Whether you donate $5 or $500, we have many ways of saying THANK YOU for your generosity. Some of our perks include:

  • Social media shoutouts
  • A thank you in the program
  • A FROM SHIP TO SHAPE mug
  • A FROM SHIP TO SHAPE teeshirt
  • A signed script
  • A producer credit for the premiere
  • A performance of FROM SHIP TO SHAPE at an agreed upon time and location.
     

What people are saying about FROM SHIP TO SHAPE.

"Hilariously presented with true grit and humility."
-Hamptons.com, March 2011

“Mr. Vreeland’s openness and raw honesty within From Ship to Shape brings his audience one step closer to a world free of the stigma surrounding mental illness…the subject matter is universal.”
-Southampton Press, April 2016

“Entertaining and thought provoking…[an exploration of] our dreams and aspirations: how we achieve them and what it does to us when we can’t.”
-Scott Schwartz, director, April 2016

"From Ship to Shape by Hamptons radio personality Walker Vreeland plays prime time tomorrow. It’s the funny and wrenching account of Vreeland’s personal struggle with mental illness in which sanity surfaces in unlikely places.”
-Newsday, April 2016
 

Risks & Challenges

Indiegogo suggests having a section about "the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal" and what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles. What qualifies me to overcome hurdles is everything that I have been through up until now. Whether I'm able to raise the money or not, I will be standing on a stage on September 30, 2017 at 2:30pm telling my story. Having said that, if I can survive bipolar disorder, sciatica, multiple divorces, liver cancer and the death of my beloved Persian cat Beany Baby- all before age 38- I can Goddamn well raise $6800. 

       

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you can't contribute monetarily, there are many other ways you can help! 

        • You can share this campaign on social media.
        • Spread the word about the show.
        • And of course you can buy a ticket for the performance! (Click on this link for tickets: https://www.telecharge.com/Off-Broadway/United-...
          ***Remember to choose the date and time of the show: September 30, 2017 at 2pm.)

story:
In Brief

A princess escapes with her lover, only to lose both her child and husband. In her grief, she falls into an eternal slumber and transforms into a vast mountain range in northern Thailand. But when a boy's soccer team becomes entrapped in her caves, the princess awakens and a new relationship begins.

  • We are a team of Thai and American theatre artists that are passionate about representation, mythology, and drama! Come meet us:
    • SJ is a theatre-maker with a specialty in puppetry of all forms. They are an alum of Northwestern University and currently traveling Thailand as a Henry Luce Scholar using performance to help with community-building and empowerment.
    • Greg is a director and writer (usually) based in DC. He is an alum of the University of Michigan and affiliated with the Lab for Global Performance and Politics and 4615 Theatre Co.
    • Irene is a performer who also runs InsightPact, a design research and  leadership development consultancy. Irene is a calls Bangkok, Berlin and the US East Coast home. DOI NANG NON is Irene’s return to theater since performing in Avenue Q in 2013 and Urinetown in 2014. 
    • Mack is a performer and co-founder of Splashing Theatre in Bangkok. An alum of Thammasat University, Mack has been seen all over Bangkok's theatre scene most recently in B-Floor's Manoland, and the Thai-Japanese collabaration, Pratthana.
  • The world was watching closely when the Wild Boars soccer team was trapped in the caves of Doi Nang Non. Us Americans were exhausted from the white-centric focus on Elon Musk and Hollywood's immediate jump on developing a story centering around British saviors. Our Thai collaborators were equally upset with how Thai celebrities and government officials were quick to capitalize on the event for fame and reputation. We decided that we wanted to work on a play that focuses solely on what happened in the caves -- not on the outside. When we discovered that there is an entire mythological tradition involving the life of the mountains itself, we knew that our story would be one that would put Thailand first, above all. 

What We Need & What You Get

Thanks to a grant from the Asia Foundation in partnership with the Henry Luce Foundation, we were able to offset a lot of costs, but now we just need to cover the loose-ends:

  • Puppetry construction, design, and materials costs: This play will make extensive use of shadow puppets designed by Jae Sirikarn Bunjongtad. We want to pay her fairly for her work and also give her budget to help create the best figures from quality materials, especially in the case of redesign or accidents!
  • Wages: The money will help contribute to the stipend we are providing our performers, staff, and musicians too! Nobody works for free, and we will ensure that our team will earn fair compensation for their labor.
  • If the funds do not reach our goal, we will use whatever money received and focus it on our team's wages. 

The Impact

Our show aims to shift the narrative away from the "rescuers" and onto the history of Northern-Thailand, its rich mythological tradition, and, of course, the boys team.

  • After the show opens, we will submit it to festivals around the world to help spread the story!
  • Our team has a track record of success: Greg directed the world premiere of Emily Wilson's translation of The Odyssey; and received critical acclaim from The Washington Post, DC Metro Theatre Arts, DC Theatre Scene and more for his regional premiere of 410[GONE] by Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig.  SJ helped Manoland tour to Tokyo, Japan with Mack as a performer, as well as serving a stage manager for the production in all of its iterations. They also created puppetry for B-Floor's Midsummer Night's Dream and work with Makhampom Theatre Group on creating workshops for communities in northern Thailand. 

Risks & Challenges

Our rehearsal process will be a fast one, and of course since play is so ambitious there are many challenges we will face. 

  • The rehearsal process is short, but having workshopped the piece already in prior, we have defined goals to reach. Seriously, some of the choreography and sequences have already been created!
  • We have a research trip planned in Chiang Rai to help develop a concrete concept and implement it in place for the process.
  • Greg received training at Odin Teatret and specializes in physical scores and movement creation. He's also worked with incredible director-choreographers like Carolina Pizarro, Linda Goodrich, Jesca Prudencio, Anita Gonzalez, and Joel Valentin-Martinez and has a clear and concise method of creating streamlined movement.
  • SJ and Jae are expert puppeteers and craftspeople, who have breadths of experience in creating and using custom and found objects too!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help, but can't give money, here are some things you can do!

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. SHARE IT!!
  • If you're a Thai national, please reach out to us to help with ground-marketing!

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
In Brief
A princess escapes with her lover, only to lose both her child and husband. In her grief, she falls into an eternal slumber and transforms into a vast mountain range in northern Thailand. But when a boy's soccer team becomes entrapped in her caves, the princess awakens and a new relationship begins.

We are a team of Thai and American theatre artists that are passionate about representation, mythology, and drama! Come meet us:
SJ is a theatre-maker with a specialty in puppetry of all forms. They are an alum of Northwestern University and currently traveling Thailand as a Henry Luce Scholar using performance to help with community-building and empowerment.
Greg is a director and writer (usually) based in DC. He is an alum of the University of Michigan and affiliated with the Lab for Global Performance and Politics and 4615 Theatre Co.
Irene is a performer who also runs InsightPact, a design research and  leadership development consultancy. Irene is a calls Bangkok, Berlin and the US East Coast home. DOI NANG NON is Irene’s return to theater since performing in Avenue Q in 2013 and Urinetown in 2014. 
Mack is a performer and co-founder of Splashing Theatre in Bangkok. An alum of Thammasat University, Mack has been seen all over Bangkok's theatre scene most recently in B-Floor's Manoland, and the Thai-Japanese collabaration, Pratthana.


The world was watching closely when the Wild Boars soccer team was trapped in the caves of Doi Nang Non. Us Americans were exhausted from the white-centric focus on Elon Musk and Hollywood's immediate jump on developing a story centering around British saviors. Our Thai collaborators were equally upset with how Thai celebrities and government officials were quick to capitalize on the event for fame and reputation. We decided that we wanted to work on a play that focuses solely on what happened in the caves -- not on the outside. When we discovered that there is an entire mythological tradition involving the life of the mountains itself, we knew that our story would be one that would put Thailand first, above all. 


What We Need & What You Get
Thanks to a grant from the Asia Foundation in partnership with the Henry Luce Foundation, we were able to offset a lot of costs, but now we just need to cover the loose-ends:

Puppetry construction, design, and materials costs: This play will make extensive use of shadow puppets designed by Jae Sirikarn Bunjongtad. We want to pay her fairly for her work and also give her budget to help create the best figures from quality materials, especially in the case of redesign or accidents!
Wages: The money will help contribute to the stipend we are providing our performers, staff, and musicians too! Nobody works for free, and we will ensure that our team will earn fair compensation for their labor.
If the funds do not reach our goal, we will use whatever money received and focus it on our team's wages. 


The Impact
Our show aims to shift the narrative away from the "rescuers" and onto the history of Northern-Thailand, its rich mythological tradition, and, of course, the boys team.

After the show opens, we will submit it to festivals around the world to help spread the story!
Our team has a track record of success: Greg directed the world premiere of Emily Wilson's translation of The Odyssey; and received critical acclaim from The Washington Post, DC Metro Theatre Arts, DC Theatre Scene and more for his regional premiere of 410[GONE] by Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig.  SJ helped Manoland tour to Tokyo, Japan with Mack as a performer, as well as serving a stage manager for the production in all of its iterations. They also created puppetry for B-Floor's Midsummer Night's Dream and work with Makhampom Theatre Group on creating workshops for communities in northern Thailand. 


Risks & Challenges
Our rehearsal process will be a fast one, and of course since play is so ambitious there are many challenges we will face. 

The rehearsal process is short, but having workshopped the piece already in prior, we have defined goals to reach. Seriously, some of the choreography and sequences have already been created!
We have a research trip planned in Chiang Rai to help develop a concrete concept and implement it in place for the process.
Greg received training at Odin Teatret and specializes in physical scores and movement creation. He's also worked with incredible director-choreographers like Carolina Pizarro, Linda Goodrich, Jesca Prudencio, Anita Gonzalez, and Joel Valentin-Martinez and has a clear and concise method of creating streamlined movement.
SJ and Jae are expert puppeteers and craftspeople, who have breadths of experience in creating and using custom and found objects too!


Other Ways You Can Help
If you want to help, but can't give money, here are some things you can do!

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. SHARE IT!!
If you're a Thai national, please reach out to us to help with ground-marketing!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Who are we?

We are a group of female dancers wanting to share our stories and voices through movement and art. Mook Dance Company was created by Artistic Director, Winnie Berger, in 2014. Her passion for choreography bloomed out of an Independent Study in which she created a 30 minute piece about her sister, Violet, who was diagnosed with Autism in 2013. With a 16 year age gap and a 3000 mile distance, the biggest gift she felt she could give was art. Post graduation, the sentiments of sharing her story through choreography and dance remained. Mook was created in the casual sense of Winnie simply wanting to create and move with people she felt were honest, caring, humble, and wickedly talented. And that is the kind of art and environment Mook still aims to accomplish, although on a much broader and more serious scale now. We have our first all Mook single bill show, called sub//merge, in April 2017, and we couldn't be more excited for this next big step. 

Since 2014, Mook has added and created 10 works for their repertoire, and we continue to make more! We aim to create movement that tells a story tangible to audience members that is ethereal, comprehensible, evocative, and relatable.

 

Why we need help

Having a small company in New York City is one of the most arduous pursuits imaginable. Not only is the city saturated with small dance companies, but there is little money or support for the arts, in general. Applying for grants, raising money, and having any sort of monetary base for our company to thrive and grow has been increasingly challenging. And this is where we need your help. We need help in funding for the first quarter of our 2nd year. 

Mook Dance Company's 2017 Season is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Mook Dance Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Welcome to Our Home - Tangled

Human Body Expression presents a world premiere at dance: made in canada/fait au canada this summer, choreographed by HBE's Founder & Artistic Director Hanna Kiel. The work features eleven emerging dance artists from the Toronto community, and will be performed from August 17-20, 2017 on d:mic/fac's Mainstage at the prestigious Betty Oliphant Theatre.

Welcome to Our Home - Tangled  explores the strength behind the family bond. Inspired by family relationships, in this piece we witness the ups and downs around a family’s differences, conflicts, and inner workings. Amidst this turmoil the family nonetheless finds a way to unite; its members still feel love and compassion for one another. From this work, choreographer Hanna Kiel questions, “What makes a family stick together through the thick and thin, and why is this bond unbreakable?”  Through exploring different personalities and the physical relationships between them, Welcome to Our Home - Tangled aspires to discover the true strength behind the family bond. 

Photos by Drew Berry.  Dancers: Andrea Gregorio, Samantha Grist, Peter Kelly, Kathleen Legassick, Nikolaos Markakis, and Sarah MacDonald

--

Welcome to Our Home - Tangled

Choreography by Hanna Kiel

Rehearsal Direction by Natasha Poon Woo

Original Music by Greg Harrison

Lighting Design by Noah Feaver

Dancers: Mahesh Halkeri, Martha Hart, Emily Hobbes, Peter Kelly, Tia Kushniruk, Sarah MacDonald, Nikolaos Markakis, J.T. Papandreos, Tara Pillon, Jake Ramos, and Roberto Soria

 

Where You Come In: Give & Get Back

With a cast of eleven dancers, the scale of this production is significantly larger than most of the other works being presented at d:mic/fac 2017.  As such, HBE needs your help to ensure our artists are properly compensated for their work. Your contributions will go directly to paying the fourteen artists (choreographer, rehearsal director, composer, lighting designer, and eleven dancers) for their involvement in the project.

This time commitment includes:

  • 60 hours of creation/rehearsal
  • 4 hours of tech rehearsal
  • 3 performances at the Betty Oliphant Theatre

With your support, we aim to provide our artists with a minimum of $500 each. d:mic/fac's $3,000 fee, combined with our goal to raise an additional $5,000, will allow us to compensate our artists at this rate. The funds raised will be divided among the artists, whether or not we reach our target. Should we surpass the $5,000 mark, additional funds raised will go towards an increased artist fee, and/or a post-production celebration dinner for the artists.

We won't let your contributions go unrecognized.  For each donation of $25 of more, you earn exclusive perks such as:

  • A shout-out on HBE's social media platforms
  • Personal messages directly from the artists
  • An exclusive invitation to observe Welcome to Our Home - Tangled in rehearsal
  • Complimentary tickets to see Welcome to our Home - Tangled as part of the Morrison Series at d:mic/fac
  • Eternal gratitude from all the dancers and everyone at HBE!

 

No Money? No Problem.

We understand that it isn't always possible to make a financial contribution. Not to worry - you can still help!

  • Spread the word about this campaign - share this page and our promotional videos, and tell your friends and family to check it out!
  • Attend the 2017 d:mic/fac Festival from August 17-20 -- visit www.princessproductions.ca/dance for full schedule, tickets, and details
  • Follow Human Body Expression on social media to help us gain visibility and stay up-to-date on what we're up to! www.facebook.com/HBEdance | @hbedance

No matter what way you are able to help, we are grateful for your support!

About the Choreographer

Dora Award nominee Hanna Kiel is from Seoul, South Korea, and moved to Vancouver in 1996. She has since presented her work at 12 Minutes Max, PlanB Singles and solos Festival, Dancing on the Edge Festival, Asian Heritage Month Festival, Pulse at the Scotiabank Dance Centre, Roundhouse Centre, and Surrey Arts Centre in Vancouver.  In 2007, she collaborated with Yoko Ono as a dancer and choreographer at the Centre A. Since moving to Toronto in 2008, Hanna has continued working as an independent dance artist, choreographing for George Brown Dance, Ryerson Dances, the School of Toronto Dance Theatre, Kenny Pearl’s Emerging Artist Intensive, IGNITE, ProArte Danza, Cadence Contemporary Ballet Company, Ballet Jörgen, Alias Dance Project, The National Ballet of Canada, and Decidedly Jazz Danceworks (Calgary).  In 2012, she was the winner of Northwest Dance Project’s ‘Pretty Creatives’ international choreographic competition.  Hanna was an emerging choreographer for Springboard Danse Montréal 2015. She is founder and artistic director of Human Body Expression and one of the founders of The Garage, a dance development and exchange collective group in Toronto.

story:
The Man in the Moone

We are Rhum and Clay. The above video was filmed in a warehouse in Hackney where we have been building the set for our latest production, The Man in the Moone. We are a physical theatre ensemble based in London and this is the fourth show we have created professionally. It will also be the third production we have taken the the Edinburgh Festival Fringe.

The show will be on at the Pleasance Courtyard which is really exciting for us as the Pleasance is one of the most respected venues for theatre at the Festival.

The Man in the Moone tells the story of a man who falls in love with the moon and abandons everyone and everything in his life to get there.

As with all our shows it will be highly physical with a strong emphasis on visual storytelling combined with a playful sense of humour. It will be entirely created by the cast in the rehearsal room. The team involved is:

Cast
Christopher Harrisson
Julian Spooner
Matthew Wells
Daniel Wilcox
 
Design
Alberta Jones
 
Lighting Design
Geoff Hense
 
Stage Manager
Rob Stenson
 
Producer
Sarah Wilson
 
Construction Chief
Rhys Robinson
 
Publicity Design
Sandra Dieckmann
Christopher Harrisson

We're really excited about this show and think it's going to be our best yet. However, to really make the most of the festival for the show and the company, we need your help.

The Fringe and how you can help

The Edinburgh Festival Fringe is the biggest arts festival in the world, with over 2800 shows taking place this year and competition is fierce for audiences. However, it is also the best platform for us as a company to showcase our work, not just to audiences, but to important people in the arts industries who flock to the Fringe each year searching out good productions. However, it is also an expensive undertaking and we can't do it alone.

We are hoping to raise £3000 towards the cost of this project. The money we receive will go towards:

  • Venue Hire
  • Accommodation
  • Transport
  • Publicity and printing costs

We're very grateful for any support you can give us and to say thank you we're pleased to offer some fantastic perks, that range from pin badges to posters, to greetings cards to free tickets to our shows.

Please share this campaign with anyone you think would be interested in helping out this project.

Thank you

Chris, Julian, Matt and Daniel

Rhum and Clay Theatre Company

story:
Allow me to introduce myself..

My name is Renee DiAugustine-Bower and I currently maintain operations of the Berwick Theater.  I took over this responsibility when my grandfather passed away last summer. 

My grandfather, Vincent DiAugustine, was a legend in the small town of Berwick, PA. He was a man of many trades, but his passion was in the Berwick Theater.  He maintained operation of the Berwick Theater for over 40 years and sold tickets in the ticket booth every night until he fell ill a few months before his death.  

When my Pop got the news that he had a little over a year to invest in a digital projection system that would run him about $60,000, or he would no longer be able to show new movies, he didn't quit.  At the ripe age of 88 years old, my grandfather actively pursued his options.  Even in my Pop's last moments, the Berwick Theater wasn't far from his mind.  It was literally his dying wish to keep the doors open at the Berwick Theater.

We must convert to digital or we will be forced to turn the lights out forever.

Movies have been produced on film for the last 100 years, but 35mm film is becoming a thing of the past. As the world changes technology is booming. Hollywood has made the decision to convert to digital format for movie distribution.  In a little less than a year film distribution from all major production companies will be in digital format. Film projection systems will finally meet their long awaited fate and become obsolete.

The good and the bad.

The good news is that Hollywood did this to dramatically lower the costs of production and distribution, which will ultimately lower our costs. It also means that we will have a much more efficient way of showing movies. No more sound pops, scratched films, missing frames, splicing, bad sound, and shaking. The picture will be sharper, the sound will be phenomenal, and we will have a lot more freedom and opportunity with our movie choices.  

To "go digital", means the picture and sound quality will be amazing.  The system itself will be much more energy efficient.  For instance, there will no longer need 2,000 watt bulbs to shine through the film strip.  Sounds perfect, right? Unfortunately the bad news is that this new upgrade will cost upwards of $60,000. The equipment to upgrade the sound system alone, while very cutting edge, is very expensive. Many small town single screen movie theaters have already shut their doors because the upgrade is too costly. The film studios have offered multiplex theaters substantial discounts to make the conversion to the digital projection system, but independent theaters like ours have not been offered such an opportunity. 

A little history. 

The actual structure of the Berwick Theater goes back a long way.  It was originally built and maintained by the Patriotic Order Sons of America for it's intended use as an Opera House.  In the 1910's it was renamed the Lyric and later it became the Palace.  It's believed that it was being operated as a playhouse at that time. Records show that it was the Strand in the 1920's-1930's and operated as a movie theater.  Our patrons tell of silent movies and later popular titles like “Stowaway” with Shirley Temple.  

In 1937 there was a devastating fire, but it seems that the Strand was more fortunate than it's neighboring play house.  In 1969 major renovations were made to the theater.  It was those renovations that the Berwick Theater still very much resembles.  The whole project included fire proof walls, state of the art technology for it's time, the infamous BIG screen and many other upgrades that cost upwards of $90,000 at that time.  My grandfather purchased the Berwick Theater in 1971 and has had it ever since.  He leased it for a number of years but resumed control in 1997 and maintained it until his death in July 2013.

Though changes have been made to the theatre over the years, it still exudes a certain character that's unique to small town theatres such as this one.  It's a charming theater that resonates history with every turn, from it's cast iron exit signs, art deco theater seats, to it's original classic aisle lighting.

Low-cost Entertainment. 

My grandfather was proud to provide low cost, family friendly entertainment to his community. He insisted that prices never exceed the already low $4 admission fee. Sine I've taken over the responsibilities of the Berwick Theater, I've only raised prices that I absolutely had to.  The Berwick Theater is a low-cost, family friendly source of entertainment that I believe is important to this community.  

The theater acts as an anchor for the downtown business community the same way that a multiplex attracts shoppers to a mall. It is part of the character and vitality of the town. If the theater is forced to go dark part of the attraction of  downtown Berwick will be lost along with it.

The Berwick Theater doesn't bring in a profit, and hasn't for a long time.  Every cent that comes out of the Berwick Theater, goes right back into it.  My pop never cared about a big profit, he just did what he had to keep the lights on.  I don't intend to change any of that.  The more profit we bring in, the more money we can put back into the theater.

What's in the future if we can make the conversion?

Well, when I look into my crystal ball, I see endless opportunities.  If we raise more than our goal, we intend to make some much needed upgrades.  Even if we don't exceed our goal, I anticipate that the options that come with a digital system will draw a bigger crowd, leaving us with a bigger profit to put back into the theater.  

We will be able to show indie films, and hopefully launch our very first indie film festival. We will be able to show old movies and family classics.  I am hoping to live stream bands, host plays and comedy acts, and maybe even invite a group to put on a Rocky Horror Picture Show.  I also see the Berwick Theater being a phenomenal wedding venue, and a source for community events.  I want to be as involved with the community as possible!  Going digital is the first step.

So how do you know I can do this? 

As a 22-yearold newlywed, fresh of out college, I'm ready to take on this task with a fresh new perspective.  I've opened up the task to the community and have welcomed their input.  I am not alone on this task.  My family (new and old) has been so supportive and incredibly helpful.  The community has given us an absolutely overwhelming response.  

There are two major reasons why I won't give up on this theater.  The first is one of the last things that my grandfather said to me, before he passed away.  My Pop said to me: "Renee, how I am I going to keep the theater open?"  "I have to make that digital conversion".  I gave my Pop my word that I would continue his legacy, and I truly believe that's what let him rest.  

I will not give up this battle without my best effort.  The second reason I won't give up, is because of the absolutely incredible response that my family and I received when I let our Facebook followers know about the passing of my grandfather.  Berwickians from all over, came forward to let us know that they had our back if we were to continue with the Berwick Theater.  So many people knew my grandfather and his infamous stories.  It's been 6 months, and I'm still constantly receiving sympathies for my pop's passing, and kind words about what a great man he was.  That's why I won't give up on this place.

So now the question is: Do you support the Berwick Theater? Even if you can't contribute financially please join us on facebook and share the link to this campaign. Maybe stop by the theater and take in a movie some night. I know you will enjoy yourself!
