He was a man of many trades, but his passion was in the Berwick Theater.  He maintained operation of the Berwick Theater for over 40 years and sold tickets in the ticket booth every night until he fell ill a few months before his death.  When my Pop got the news that he had a little over a year to invest in a digital projection system that would run him about $60,000, or he would no longer be able to show new movies, he didn't quit.  At the ripe age of 88 years old, my grandfather actively pursued his options.  Even in my Pop's last moments, the Berwick Theater wasn't far from his mind.  It was literally his dying wish to keep the doors open at the Berwick Theater.We must convert to digital or we will be forced to turn the lights out forever.Movies have been produced on film for the last 100 years, but 35mm film is becoming a thing of the past. As the world changes technology is booming. Hollywood has made the decision to convert to digital format for movie distribution.  In a little less than a year film distribution from all major production companies will be in digital format. Film projection systems will finally meet their long awaited fate and become obsolete.The good and the bad. The good news is that Hollywood did this to dramatically lower the costs of production and distribution, which will ultimately lower our costs. It also means that we will have a much more efficient way of showing movies. No more sound pops, scratched films, missing frames, splicing, bad sound, and shaking. The picture will be sharper, the sound will be phenomenal, and we will have a lot more freedom and opportunity with our movie choices.  To "go digital", means the picture and sound quality will be amazing.  The system itself will be much more energy efficient.  For instance, there will no longer need 2,000 watt bulbs to shine through the film strip.  Sounds perfect, right? Unfortunately the bad news is that this new upgrade will cost upwards of $60,000. The equipment to upgrade the sound system alone, while very cutting edge, is very expensive. Many small town single screen movie theaters have already shut their doors because the upgrade is too costly. The film studios have offered multiplex theaters substantial discounts to make the conversion to the digital projection system, but independent theaters like ours have not been offered such an opportunity. A little history.  The actual structure of the Berwick Theater goes back a long way.  It was originally built and maintained by the Patriotic Order Sons of America for it's intended use as an Opera House.  In the 1910's it was renamed the Lyric and later it became the Palace.  It's believed that it was being operated as a playhouse at that time. Records show that it was the Strand in the 1920's-1930's and operated as a movie theater.  Our patrons tell of silent movies and later popular titles like “Stowaway” with Shirley Temple.  In 1937 there was a devastating fire, but it seems that the Strand was more fortunate than it's neighboring play house.  In 1969 major renovations were made to the theater.  It was those renovations that the Berwick Theater still very much resembles.  The whole project included fire proof walls, state of the art technology for it's time, the infamous BIG screen and many other upgrades that cost upwards of $90,000 at that time.  My grandfather purchased the Berwick Theater in 1971 and has had it ever since.  He leased it for a number of years but resumed control in 1997 and maintained it until his death in July 2013.Though changes have been made to the theatre over the years, it still exudes a certain character that's unique to small town theatres such as this one.  It's a charming theater that resonates history with every turn, from it's cast iron exit signs, art deco theater seats, to it's original classic aisle lighting.Low-cost Entertainment.  My grandfather was proud to provide low cost, family friendly entertainment to his community. He insisted that prices never exceed the already low $4 admission fee. Sine I've taken over the responsibilities of the Berwick Theater, I've only raised prices that I absolutely had to.  The Berwick Theater is a low-cost, family friendly source of entertainment that I believe is important to this community.  The theater acts as an anchor for the downtown business community the same way that a multiplex attracts shoppers to a mall. It is part of the character and vitality of the town. If the theater is forced to go dark part of the attraction of  downtown Berwick will be lost along with it.The Berwick Theater doesn't bring in a profit, and hasn't for a long time.  Every cent that comes out of the Berwick Theater, goes right back into it.  My pop never cared about a big profit, he just did what he had to keep the lights on.  I don't intend to change any of that.  The more profit we bring in, the more money we can put back into the theater.What's in the future if we can make the conversion? Well, when I look into my crystal ball, I see endless opportunities.  If we raise more than our goal, we intend to make some much needed upgrades.  Even if we don't exceed our goal, I anticipate that the options that come with a digital system will draw a bigger crowd, leaving us with a bigger profit to put back into the theater.  We will be able to show indie films, and hopefully launch our very first indie film festival. We will be able to show old movies and family classics.  I am hoping to live stream bands, host plays and comedy acts, and maybe even invite a group to put on a Rocky Horror Picture Show.  I also see the Berwick Theater being a phenomenal wedding venue, and a source for community events.  I want to be as involved with the community as possible!  Going digital is the first step.So how do you know I can do this? As a 22-yearold newlywed, fresh of out college, I'm ready to take on this task with a fresh new perspective.  I've opened up the task to the community and have welcomed their input.  I am not alone on this task.  My family (new and old) has been so supportive and incredibly helpful.  The community has given us an absolutely overwhelming response.  There are two major reasons why I won't give up on this theater.  The first is one of the last things that my grandfather said to me, before he passed away.  My Pop said to me: "Renee, how I am I going to keep the theater open?"  "I have to make that digital conversion".  I gave my Pop my word that I would continue his legacy, and I truly believe that's what let him rest.  I will not give up this battle without my best effort.  The second reason I won't give up, is because of the absolutely incredible response that my family and I received when I let our Facebook followers know about the passing of my grandfather.  Berwickians from all over, came forward to let us know that they had our back if we were to continue with the Berwick Theater.  So many people knew my grandfather and his infamous stories.  It's been 6 months, and I'm still constantly receiving sympathies for my pop's passing, and kind words about what a great man he was.  That's why I won't give up on this place. So now the question is: Do you support the Berwick Theater? Even if you can't contribute financially please join us on facebook and share the link to this campaign. Maybe stop by the theater and take in a movie some night. I know you will enjoy yourself!

story:
Play Pen Productions and why we need you.

Play Pen Productions is run by Minal Patel (Producer and Artistic Director) and Tania Azevedo (Director and Producer). 

The Company was formed in 2012 and our main aim is to create excellent standards of new theatre and re-invent current theatre by using a collaboration of physical theatre, music, other physical techniques and unconventional performance spaces to give our audiences a fresh and different experience to ones they may have had before.

Having sold out runs of our previous two shows; 'The Picture House' - A New Musical & 'Oedipus Renewed' and reinvention of the greek classic, our current adventure, Scenes from 'Hello Again' is the next step in fulfilling our aim of excellent theatre making. 

This stage of the project is very important to us as it is a challenge and a trial of our work and a test of whether we can make this show a success. We will be performing the first three scenes of the widely unknown musical to draw attention to the re-invented style of the piece and depending on its success we have been offered a three week run of the full show later on in 2014. 

Now we need your support. 

We are approaching people like you for your contributions to help us reach our goal of £2500 and more to enable us to fulfil the needs of this project for now and for its future run, these include:

- Payment costs for Creatives and Performers.

- Production costs e.g. Lighting equipment, Sound equipment, Set, Props, Costumes and Various Hire costs.

- Marketing and Publicity.

- Investment in the future of this project.

In return for your generous donations we are offering you a variety of different gifted options as a heartfelt thanks, Depending on your donation, the bigger the prize!

We'll also send out some special videos, letting you know what we're doing with your donations and keeping you updated on the whole project right from the planning stages up until the final leg of the shows. We are determined to have you a part of the Play Pen family and we think no better way to do that than to know exactly whats going and get some exciting insights into our work and talent.


The Impact you'll make.

As young producers and performers we are aiming to work on projects of this calibre for a long period so one of the most important things we can can benefit from is your support. You may or may not be aware of the difficulties we come across when raising funds as producers and although that is a major part of every project, our fundamental aims are to create very high standards of theatre in any capacity for everyone to enjoy and learn from, without your help we can't do that.

Your contributions to our project will not only directly affect us, but in turn will help us to reassure our community of producers and performers alike that work comes when we  can work hard for it and make it ourselves. Your valuable contribution will enable us to not only create work for ourselves but for many others too.

Other Ways You Can Help

We absolutely understand that not everyone is in a position to donate financially however don't worry if you can't, we could use your support by

- Spreading the word about the show amongst your friends, family and contacts

- Following us on social media and checking out our project updates and sharing those

- Coming along to our shows and giving us your feedback and opinions

- and in many other ways

Our supporters and audiences are our most important tool for success and without your help and determination, none of our projects can be as successful. 

So if you can't give anything via donation, then still please share this link with your contacts and keep following us at 

Website: www.playpenproductions.org

Facebook: www.facebook.com/playpenprod

Twitter: @playpenprod

Thank you so much for your time.

Get supporting us!

Minal and Tania at Play Pen Productions.

story:
Hello Lovers of theater and history!

A Call to Conscience (c2c) is a Readers Theater Group committed to facilitating transformative, social change by reacquainting audiences with some of the great leaders and speakers of our time.  Using a variety of speeches, essays, adaptations and dramatizations of historic moments in a mixed media format (theater, music and the visual arts); we revisit the contributions of many of our historic icons and the moments that have changed our history.   

Founder/producer/writer, Linda Jo Smith, was inspired by a discussion on the full text of Dr. Martin Luther King’s “Mountaintop Speech” choosing the reader’s theater approach to “call” the public to consciousness by focusing on historic leaders of our time. Linda is a graduate of Community Arts in Training fellowship of the St. Louis Regional Arts Commission and has worked for the St. Louis Public Library for over 13 years where she is responsible for the planning and implementation system-wide community programming. 

In June of 2014 we plan to present a screening of Hole in the Head: A Life Revealed.  This award-winning documentary tells the story of Vertus Hardiman and nine other children who lived in Lyles Station, Indiana, in the 1920s.   In 1927, African American families were approached by doctors deliberately misleading them into thinking that their purpose was to fight a ring worm epidemic. In reality the children were irradiated as a medical experiment sponsored by the local county hospital. 

 

Vertus Hardiman

c2c intends to invite the filmmaker to the Missouri History Museum for a screening of the documentary.  This will require flying him in from Long Beach, CA and paying for hotel and ground travel.  Readers from c2c as well as volunteers from the community will “read” events from a timeline listing victims of unethical human experimentation throughout human history as a prelude to the screening.

We need your help to take A Call to Conscience to the next level!

We  plan to offer adults, as well as middle and high school students, the opportunity to experience history through the words of dynamic icons of politics, music, theater, the civil rights movement and a variety of other platforms. Single presentations and tailored workshops are designed to meet the Common Core Standards of the English and Language Arts curriculum set by the Missouri Department of Education.  All workshops end with culminating performances. 

We need funding to submit our application for 501(c)(3) tax exempt status to make us eligible to apply for grants that will help retain staff and operating expenses.  

What We Need & What You Get

Budget: A Hole in the Head

Wilbert Smith (filmmaker)

Honorarium  $2,500.00

Airfare/Hotel,  Round trip  from Altadena, CA  $1,000.00 (approx.)

Taxi (round trip)       $80.00

Event Expenses

45-day Public

  Performance License    $199.00

Promotional materials

 26”x39”Posters @ $13.95    $55.80

Refreshments  (Bixby’s)     $250.00

Total    $4,084.80 (documentary

501 (c)(3) Tax exempt application/consultation   $1,200.00

Total request  $5,284.80


Founder Linda Jo Smith is a writer/storyteller and author of the Treasury of Twisted Tales and a collection of poetry entitled Involuntary Traveler.  Inspired by a discussion on the full text of Dr. Martin Luther King’s “Mountaintop Speech” Linda chose the reader’s theatre approach to “call” the public to consciousness by focusing on historic leaders of our time. Linda earned a B.S. degree from Howard University in Washington, D.C.

Fannie Bell Lebby, co-founder and artistic director of A Call to Conscience is an actress and director who received rave reviews for her one-woman act as Alberta Hunter and Moms Mabley.  Fannie has her Master’s degree in Theatre/Cinema from Texas Southern University in Houston, Texas.  She is committed to the philosophy that the arts are essential in the effort to bring about social change.

Co-founder Linda M. Nance's singing takes you from the realm of opera to the soul of gospel. A talented writer, Linda is also key to the development of the concept for the group, Linda serves as Financial Officer and brings strong program management and fundraising skills to the team. She holds Bachelor degrees in Sociology and Psychology from Maryville University in St. Louis, Missouri.

LaVelle Wilkins-Chinn has thirty-plus years of performing arts experience with several St. Louis theatre companies and writes under the nom de plume, Loue Chinn. She has been a participant of the Hurston-Wright writing conferences and is currently she’s scribbling out a novel.

The Impact

The writers, director and performers experience history as speeches and historical accounts of icons, such as Nelson Mandela, are adapted to create a “conversation” between the performers on stage as well as with the audience.  While in rehearsals, adults and teens either experience for the first time or are reacquainted with the impact the subject has had on American and/or world history.  Emotion is heightened with the music that was prevalent during respective historical context of the time which leaves the performers and with a sense of understanding of the subject and the times in which they lived.  The audience is always supplied with lyrics to sing along with the cast and we often invite readers to be a part of our program that achieves our objective to be interactive which  furthers our goal to bring about transformation and  to be inspired to become involved with organizations committed to bring about social change.

Our perks offer an opportunity to show your desire to bring about social change through the arts.  We have t-shirts with our c2c logo and key tags in addition to our literary and storytelling talents.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word about A Call to Conscience by attending our events and telling your friends on Twitter, Facebook, etc.and post and share how you were impacted by our performances and programs.  “Like" us on Facebook at A Call to Conscience.

story:
Sexpelliarmus II!

Last year's Atlanta Nerdlesque hit is back! Sexpelliarmus: A Whimsical Wizarding Burlesque Revue is now at The New Atlanta Shakespeare Tavern. We are extremely excited about being in one of Atlanta's destination theaters, but as our production grows, so do our production expenses. That's where you come in!

What Do We Need?

As a collective of passionate, like-minded nerds and geeks who all would have gone to Hogwarts for college if they accepted FAFSA, we fund the entirety of our production out of our pockets.   We desperately need assistance with production and company expenses, to step up the level and quality of immersive experience we provide for you, our audience.  The production expenses include:

  • Backgrounds
  • Printed promotional materials
  • Props
  • Graphic design
  • Administrative work
  • Merchandise and other swag
  • Performer travel expenses

    • Why Do We Need It?

    Our goal has always been to provide our audience with the highest quality immersive experience, and to pay our staff, artists and performers a wage worthy of their level of talent.  However, with a company that starts out with 0 capital, and production costs funded entirely by the staff and crew, ticket sales only cover expenses in part, leaving us in the red. These funds, while providing you with great shwag, bonus opportunities, and awesome prizes, help us to continue to bring a level of production worthy of our audience. 

    Why Sexpelliarmus?

    The history of burlesque as a genre is rooted in parody. Nerdlesque as a burlesque subgenre captures this spirit in a modern way. As Atlanta's own nerdlesque performance collective, the Hysteria Machines production company seeks to bring the past to the present and engage the incredible nerd community that Atlanta boasts.  As a performance collective of like-minded geeks and nerds of all fandoms, Hysteria Machines works tirelessly on production of their shows throughout the entire year.  Our ultimate goal with Sexpelliarmus II: to immerse our audience in the whimsical wizarding world, while bringing a production quality worthy of the Shakespeare Tavern stage, and keep our artistic staff, cast and crew well-fed and happy. 

          


    Risks & Challenges

    Moving to a larger venue brings new challenges and obstacles. In order to create a show that befits a venue like The New Atlanta Shakespeare Tavern, we have more to worry about than Death Eaters and Dementors.

    • Larger stage requires more set pieces and backgrounds
    • Larger seating area makes creating our signature immersive environment more difficult. This requires additional decorations and staffing.
    • Our cast has expanded with new original numbers including the lovely ladies of the Beauxbatons Academy of Magic

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We understand that not everyone can provide funding, but you can still help make this show a success

    • Let your friends know about this campaign. Share and promote us.
    • Tell people about the show. If you've seen it, tell them about it. If you want to see it, let us know!
    • Like our page on Facebook. Reach out to the performers. We want to know how excited you are for this show!

    This is our passion!

    We are passionate about the Wizarding World, and bringing our audience along with us into it.  Many of us grew up on this iconic series, have read the books and seen the movies dozens of times, and have had our fair share of butterbeer, chocolate frogs and Bertie Bots Beans. You can help us  continue to grow this passion into a production that encourages nostalgia, engages our audience in intelligent, sexy, comedic entertainment, and turns even the most frightening dementors and Death Eaters away with our sheer joy!

story:
BACK IT UP PRODUCTIONS is seeking to raise $9,000 for the World Premiere of Mr. Irresistible, a new sci-fi musical theater comedy by D'Arcy Drollinger & Christopher Winslow opening March 28th, 2013 at La Mama, etc., in New York City.

We are thrilled that La Mama will be present and house this new show!  We have been working non-stop on refining the script and music and now need to raise the funds necessary for a full production.  This is an amazing opportunity for this show and for us as artists.  We hope that you will come along on this “irresistible” journey with us!

All contributions go towards the production costs, including: sets, lighting, costumes & sound…and are tax deductible! 

THE SHOW

Mr. Irresistible is a sci-fi musical-comedy thriller, set in the mid 1980’s.  Based on Aesop’s fable The Wolf in Sheep’s Clothing (Careful What You Wish For), Mr. Irresistible tells the story of a lonely woman who purchases a robotic lover in the hopes of finding happiness and validation in a seemingly cold and heartless world; until she learns that her new “boyfriend” was built to make her fantasies come true, the good and the bad.

When Eileen Morchinsky, a lonely secretary lost in the shuffle of corporate America, the butt of water cooler jokes and living alone in a mouse-infested five-floor walkup, spots an ad for a fully functioning mechanical male companion, she decides to stop reading her romance novels and begin living one. When the exterminator, Joey Bartalucci, shows up to wrangle the rodents in her apartment, she mistakes him for her mail-order groom and a tender relationship is born.  But the couple’s newfound bliss short-circuits when the real Acme Brand Mr. Irresistible finally arrives.

Joey is no match for the seemingly perfect specimen of manhood and quickly finds himself single again, while Eileen finds herself in the arms of the man she’s always dreamed of.  Her Mr. Irresistible comes fully equipped to make her fantasies come true…all of them.  And after complaining about a coworker, who mysteriously winds up dead, Eileen begins to realize what her robotic Romeo is capable of.  Eileen vows to return the hunky purchase and win back her one true love, Joey.  But Mr. Irresistible was made to Eileen’s specifications, and if returned, will be recycled for parts.  When his Artificial Intelligence switches into survival mode, a game of cat-and-mouse ensues, forcing Eileen to make a life or death decision. In that process, she discovers her true voice... and the truth that the love she went searching for has been with her the whole time.

THE HISTORY

Mr. Irresistible was conceived in 1998.  It was written over the course of a year and given a reading in NYC during 1999.  In 2000 I began working with Richard Frankel on Hairspray, The Musical and Mr. Irresistible was shelved.  When I started the conversation of a residency with ODC (Oberlin Dance Collective), Mr. Irresistible seemed like the obvious choice.  The concepts and structure of the show had already been created, so it would be easy to jump into quickly.  Also, over the decade the subject of robotics and Artifical Inteligence had made it’s way to the forefront of the cultural dialogue.  In many ways it feels like the themes of the show are much more relevant today.

I had meet Chris Winslow the year prior and we had written a number of songs together.  The creative process is very similar for us both, so when the idea of Mr. Irresistible came up, it made perfect sense to collaborate on the project.  This meant keeping the foundation of the show, it’s concepts and characters, but essentially rebuilding it.  The script and songs that make up the current Mr. Irresistible were created in-part during the Creative Artist Residency at ODC in San Francisco, during 2012.  It was given a studio reading mid-point through the residency; and a subsequent theatrical stage reading with full cast and band, on completion of the residency.

During this time I had met with La Mama to debrief after my last show they presented, Project: Lohan.  They invited us to present on their Main Stage in 2013.  It seemed like the perfect trajectory for Mr. Irresistible - to take it to the next phase of the incubation process  It has all moved very quickly for us and this show, but it seems very right.

THE TEAM

The New York cast includes: Stephen Di Blasi, Cindy Goldfield, Jacquelyn Graham, Chris Hall, Mara Jill Herman, Nicholas Park, Molly Pope, Clayton Dean Smith, and Kirsten Wyatt. 

The creative team includes: Music Direction by Seth Weinstein, Choreography by John Paolillo, Costume Design by Dustin Cross, Lighting Design by Wilburn Bonnell. Directed by D’Arcy Drollinger.  Presented by La Mama Etc., Produced by Back It Up Productions, Onemoe Music and Trent Kendall.

D'Arcy Drollinger's original works include: Project: Lohan, Scalpel!, The Possession of Mrs. Jones, Pink Elephants, Above and Beyond the Valley of the Ultra Showgirls, Suburbia 3000, Shit & Champagne, The Cereal Killers, and the upcoming, Mr. Irresistible.

D'Arcy has also worked as an actor, director, choreographer and producer.  Other credits include: The Producers (first Broadway production), Hairspray the Musical (first Broadway production), F.A.G.G.O.T.S. The Musical, the Thrillpeddler’s revivals of the Cockettes musicals Vice Palace & Hot Greeks, and VH1's Divas 2000 featuring RuPaul.   He directed and co-starred in the stage adaptations of Sex and the City, Designing Women and Roseanne, as well as playing the role of Chrissy Snow in a live version of the TV classic, Three’s Company.  He is a co-founder of Back It Up Productions and Crackers In Bed, INC.  D’Arcy is the creator and resident choreographer for Sunday Skool – every Sunday at the Academy of Ballet – and home of the SF based dance troupe SexiTude!  He is an original member of the critically acclaimed post-punk San Francisco art-rock group Enrique and a firm believer in the ridiculous. Drollinger has been a participant in the BMI Musical Theatre Workshop and is a member of the Dramatists Guild of America.

Christopher Winslow is currently serving as Music Director for "The Fourth Messenger" by playwright Tanya Shafer that will play at the Ashby Stage in Feburary of 2013.

Christopher Winslow recently composed and music directed for Playground SF which was presented at Berkeley Rep.  He worked with SF playground the previous year, and both years his compositions were selected for the “Best of Playground Series” which plays at the Brick House in Potrero Hill.  In 2011, Chris composed and music directed an original full-length musical comedy called “OMFG! The Internet-dating Musical” which ran at ODC  Theater.  He received a grant from the Zellerbach Family Foundation to support this work.  His work on “The Lily’s Revenge” brought Taylor Mac’s piece to life at The Magic Theatre.  He served as assistant MD for “Jerry Springer:The Opera” with Ray of Light Theater which played at the Victoria Theater in San Francisco.  Chris has worked on several projects at the San Francisco School of the Performing Arts, The Spindrift School of the Performing Arts and SF Arts Ed.  His composing projects have included a full-length chamber opera “Gaveston, Favorite of the King” written with playwright Ken Prestinizi who received an Individual Artist Grant from the San Francisco Arts Commission and was produced in concert in San Francisco and in Los Angeles in a full production at Celebration Theatre.  A musical adaptation of “Peer Gynt” commissioned by U.C. Davis was created as well by Winslow/Prestinizi. 

For more information visit mrirresistiblemusical.com

If you’re unable to contribute at this time, your assistance in sharing this campaign with friends would be greatly appreciated.  Thank you for your support!  And thank you for helping to co-create new live theater!

story:
WINTER WONDERSLAM III



 

PARTY WORLD RASSLIN' - it's the seasonal party and wrestling spectacle at 4th Tap Brewing Co-oP in Austin, TX - one of the largest free parties in town. For our last show, your support allowed us to board a sunken ship and meet ghost pirates, floating skeletons, cool fish, and seaweed! Over a thousand people screamed and raised their fists as a burly Nova-Scotian hurled a corporate raider against the beertanks. We drank, we partied, we freaked out and came together in a celebration of absurdist theater - the fellowship of TRVE KVLT PARTY VIOLENCE!

PWR was started in a backyard by a small group of friends. It's grown far more than we ever thought it would. We continue to do a DIY show that is all-ages and free to the public, even as costs increase. This is directly owed to you - the Multiverse. We consider everyone who has come to our shows and supported us to be part of PWR. Your continued support allows our core ethos to flourish. It means so much to us - and we pledge to put everything we have into making the most fun event you will attend all winter.

What do we have in store for PWR's 10th (!) Party? Hellsport, an evil and probably-supernatural corporation has begun drilling DEEP UNDERGROUND in search of arcane artifacts. They've discovered ICE CAVES - and their meddling threatens the lair of our precious MOTHER WORM! She even appears to be getting sick, and not eating the corrupt businessmen we feed her! We've got to stop this - and we'll do it the only way we know how - with wrestling!

Mother Worm wriggles most when the heart of the champion is nearby. And who has the heart of the champion? We’ll find out in...the FOAM FUMBLE, a free-for-all, multi-wrestler battle! Our Partyweight Champion Dock Master, has decided that HE WILL ENTER THE FOAM FUMBLE and put his belt on the line! Hellsport, however, has sponsored a “SECRET ENTRANT” who they seem to have supreme confidence in! Is it Dan "The Man" Ziglar? Is it...someone, or SOMETHING, else?

WHO WILL HOLD THE PARTYWEIGHT BELT? This story will be told, as well as the continuing stories of Luigi Primo, Pastaman, Theodosia, Dazza Longbarrel, Booma the Tiger, Randy "the Eagle" Eagleman, BARON ZAHKEY, Kippy (aged 13), Pink Eye, Hot Dog, the NARRC, Dadbod, and many others! We are building something that we think is epic, cathartic, as well as ridiculous and fun, and we hope you'll join us.

In addition to Rasslin' spectacle, PWR is sponsoring 2 social outreach projects this season. We want to express the community and decency that PWR instills in all of us involved:

- A women-only self-defense class, made possible through LION KRAV MAGA. Check out our facebook page for details, and how you can sign up.

- A canned food drive at the show. More details to come - food will go to SAFE austin. http://www.safeaustin.org

 

What is this money used for?

$5000 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?

First, an important recitation: PWR is free and we want to keep it free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for it as long as we can.

PWR is also now an 80-person organization putting on a show for 1500 people. One and a half thundo! Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spent just north of $8,800 to create Skeleton Cruise and $11,000 on SLIP N SLAM.

Through diligent saving and prudent investment, we've managed to bring our fundraising goals down by about $600 from its highest point in June. We are continuously able to improve the show and make it grander; your support and our careful budgeting have allowed us to do this without ballooning our costs! And it's all on the backs of our beautiful volunteers who submit themselves to the Multiverse out of love. We've survived more than two years as we've grown into the massive wrestling party you know today—and we're not slowing down! Accept no impostors! HELL RIGHT.

That said - our Indiegogo costs HAVE increased by about $400 from our last show. We don't have to rent space-coolers this time, but we're paying ~$333 more to buy even sweeter EXCLUSIVE MERCH for you to get from this campaign. Prepare for hoodies and longsleeve shirts with printing ON THE SLEEVES - what?! Also, we've allocated $200 more to our staff to add additional personnel.

Some of the cool things your donations have let us do include:
 

  • Art and design. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage. 4th Tap was turned into an UNDEAD PIRATE SHIP by their selfless capable hands. Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.

  • Emergency Precautions. We're paying for the services and equipment of EMTs—now that we’re well over a thousand attendees strong, we want to make sure no catastrophe prevents Trve Kvlt Party Violence.

  • Safe space/security: PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem, no questions asked. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.

  • Paying artists. Capitalism is whatever, but we work hard to make sure everyone who contributes art gets some money in exchange—whether our art team, our powerful tech wizards, or our video crew.

  • Projection and lighting. Huge audiences compel us to try to use every part of our venue—so that all audience members can find a comfortable view of the show. We’ve found a ton of bargain-barrel prices on new lights, new projector equipment, and new mounts. WINTER WONDERSLAM III will be our best-looking show yet.

  • Profit sharing: Our performers literally put their lives on the line FOR FREE. Everyone performs for PWR out of pure love. However, if we EXCEED our Indiegogo total, we combine that with profit from our sales at the merch table. After meeting any additional costs we've incurred, we invest 20% back into PWR and then split the rest among all our staff who worked on the show. We give performers a "double share" of this profit sharing in order to reflect their artistic contribution.

  • Training: Party Violence is its own unique sport. We have crafted a training program that makes use of experienced pro-wrestling coaching to help keep our PARTY ATHLETES smooth n' safe.  

For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a majority of them. Below is our complete budget.

Show Expenses: $2105
Misc: $25
Props: $300
Art: $600
Food: $100
Promo materials: $100
Video: $200
Security: $160
Insurance: $385
Printing: $235

Operational Expenses: $850
Ring Repairs: $150
Discretionary Show Expenses: $300
New Projects Capital: $400

Other Expenses: $4264
Artist pay: $2300
Indiegogo fees & rewards production: $1964

Extremely Hype Swag

Check out this EXTREMELY HYPE SWAG! It's Indiegogo exclusive! Donate and pick a "perk" to grab one.



If want to get your stuff before January, please order your stuff by November 26th so you can pick it up at the show, otherwise we will ship it to you as soon as we can! Holiday shipping can lag out pretty hard!
 

Risks & Challenges

 

Challenges:

PWR has become robust and its universe swole with powerful party drama. As it continues to grow wantonly like an uncontrollable teen (and our expectations for our performance climb) we approach a new realm of costs we could not have imagined before.  We work every day to keep our costs down and remain sustainable and responsible. We are depending on the support of our Multiverse to keep our show free and open—thank you for your continued support.  Rest assured we are working night and day to make sure this event is the most fun thing you do all quarter.

 

Risks:

The only risk is the risk of not partying hard enough. We laugh at the concept of "risk." It is as outmoded as "shame," or "weakness." We have sworn to party 'til death, and we will do so.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and WINTER WONDERSLAM III!
Here is the Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/536663603188874/

HMW

As it continues to grow wantonly like an uncontrollable teen (and our expectations for our performance climb) we approach a new realm of costs we could not have imagined before.  We work every day to keep our costs down and remain sustainable and responsible. We are depending on the support of our Multiverse to keep our show free and open—thank you for your continued support.  Rest assured we are working night and day to make sure this event is the most fun thing you do all quarter. Risks:The only risk is the risk of not partying hard enough. We laugh at the concept of "risk." It is as outmoded as "shame," or "weakness." We have sworn to party 'til death, and we will do so.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and WINTER WONDERSLAM III!Here is the Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/536663603188874/HMW

story:
LockUnity is a community of lockers in Montréal dedicated to the promotion and support of locking culture. Our mission is to push the locking movement by making it accessible, visible and respected throughout Québec and Canada. 

FR: LockUnity est une communauté de lockers à Montréal vouée à promouvoir et supporter la culture du locking. Notre mission est de pousser le mouvement du locking en augmentant l'accessibilité, la visibilité et le respect du locking à travers le Québec et le Canada.

Campaign Goal

We are reaching out to the street dance community around us as well as friends, family and lovers of dance for help. We want to raise $5000 for our 10 year anniversary event: Unlock The Funk which will be held from Sept 1-3, 2017. Montreal is beginning to be recognized as a city known for locking culture, dancers and events. Our event will help raise the bar on quality locking events in Montreal. 

The money raised from this campaign will go directly to our weekend-long event: Unlock The Funk. This will help to cover artist fees, flights, accommodations, venue, DJs, transportation, promo materials, online promotion, and administrative costs.

In exchange for your donations we are offering some amazing gifts including fresh locking gear, passes to the various Unlock The Funk events, and private lessons with teachers from LockUnity. Check out the Perks section to get more details.

By contributing to the creation of this event you will help to further establish locking in Quebec and Canada. Locking events, like Unlock The Funk, encourage young dancers to grow and improve which greatly benefits the entire dance community.

Your contributions will help us build locking in Montreal and bring this inspirational dance to a larger audience. Whether you are able to contribute at this time or not, we still need you to help us get the word out! Please share the link to this campaign and tell your friends, family and anyone who enjoys dance. We feel this is a great project to support and we thank you in advance for any contributions you are able to make!

FR: But de la campagne

Nous appelons la communauté de danseurs du Canada, nos amis, notre famille ainsi que les amoureux de la danse à nous aider financièrement. Nous désirons amasser 5000$ pour l'organisation de l'événement célébrant notre 10ème anniversaire: Unlock The Funk. Cet événement aura lieu les 1, 2 et 3 septembre 2017. Montréal est en voie de devenir une ville connue pour la culture du locking, la danse et les événements. Unlock The Funk sera un point marquant de la reconnaissance du locking à Montréal et au Canada.

L'argent amassé durant cette campagne ira directement à l'organisation de Unlock the Funk. Il nous aidera à payer les artistes invités notamment pour le transport et l'hébergement, à payer les locaux, les DJs, le matériel de promotion et les coûts administratifs.

En échange de vos dons, nous offrons des cadeaux appréciables tels que des vêtements de locking, des entrées aux différents événements de Unlock The Funk et des leçons privées avec des danseurs de LockUnity. Allez voir la section Perks pour plus de détails.

En contribuant à la création de cet événement, vous aidez la communauté de locking à s'établir au Québec et au Canada. Les événements comme Unlock The Funk encouragent les jeunes danseurs à améliorer leur connaisances et compétences, ce qui bénéficie à toute la communauté de la danse.

Votre contribution nous aidera à bâtir la communauté de locking à Montréal et de la partager à un public plus large. Que vous soyiez en mesure de contribuer financièrement ou non, nous vous encourageons à nous aider en parlant de l'événement! Vous pouvez aussi partager le lien de cette campagne à vos amis, votre famille, ou toute autre personne. Nous avons le sentiment que ce projet sera à la hauteur de la communauté de locking canadienne et nous vous remercions à l'avance pour toute contribution!

Visit http://www.unlockthefunk.ca for event registration and more info!

story:
City Dance Live is an online dance studio featuring classes taught by legends, leaders and rising stars in the global dance community. The site is being created by Sandy Lee and Miles Pineda-Kenedi. Sandy is the owner of City Dance Studios in San Francisco and co-owner of Momentum Design and Photography. Miles is a renowned Bboy and a member of Renegade Rockers. He is also a popular Bboy instructor in the Bay Area.

We have been working on this project since June of 2010 and have depleted our resources so we are trying to raise money with Indiegogo to help with the programming of the site. We are extremely close to being ready to launch. We need to raise $5,000 to finish with this phase. If our campaign is very succesful, and we hope it is, we will purchase new computers so that we can speed up all the editing that we do every week.

Our goal with City Dance Live is to provide a platform to connect our world class instructors with anyone, anywhere, anytime who wants to watch, learn and be entertained. We are based out of San Francisco and currently film all of our classes at City Dance Studios. 

Another goal of this venture is to help the remarkable dancers in our global network make a better living from their art. Our instructors are the best in the world at what they do and we think they should be compensated better for reaching this level. 

We are starting with over 20 amazing instructors and we hope to open our site up to additional elite dancers and instructors as we build the business. So far, we will be offering classes by Kid David, Les Twins, Roxrite, Jardy Santiago, Yuri Zhukov, Pharside, Krystal Meraz, Percy Aroncillo, Ay Hasegawa, Professor Lock, Ynot, Eddie Styles, Eric Fenn, Jaffar Smith, Ysabelle Capitule, ProfoWon, Ellen Kim, Miles Pineda-Kenedi, Emerson Aquino, Rob Nasty, Carlo Atienza, Rocko Luciano, Bibi Khalili, Dennis Infante, Bgirl Crykit, Bionic, Mr. Wiggles and Laura, Reginal and Deyvron from Criminalz Crew in Paris.

Initially our instructors are mostly associated with hip hop and urban dance but In the future we will be adding classes by instructors from many other dance genres such as ballet, contemporary, jazz, tap etc.

Stage Two of the project will involve bringing many of our classes to our students live. Thank you for exploring our project and we hope you feel inspired to contribute :-)

story:
About The Play

Two people- who’ve been found on the autism spectrum- find themselves stuck in clown school to learn social skills. Naomi, a dance prodigy in her twenties, feels in colors and refuses to wear a clown nose. Cole, a percussion virtuoso, can recite a complete history of the xylophone, but won’t meet your eyes. Measured against scales of social competence, they’ll push the boundaries of compliance to find connection in an isolating world and shatter the complacency of the nameless faces and disembodied voices running the show.


About Goat Song Theatre Collective

Our company members and guest artists are multi-disciplinary theatre collaborators interested in one thing: making cool shit you want to see. Under the leadership of Artistic Director Abigail Birkett, Executive Producer Carissa Jade Olsen, and Head of Production Ryan Schaap, Goat Song Theatre Collective pushes boundaries and breaks convention to tell stories that actively engage audiences, ignite their imaginations, and spark critical dialogue within our community. 


Who We Are

Hillary Collazo Abbott (Stage Manager, Properties Designer) Hillary is delighted to be working on the premiere of With My Eyes Shut!  She just finished working as the Assistant Stage Manager for WaterTower Theatre's production of Lord of the Flies and as the Stage Manager for Lord of the Flies PROJECT.  Other regional credits include Creep, Sexy Laundry (WaterTower Theatre); The Producers (Huron Playhouse, Inc.); and Footloose (Freed Center).  Hillary holds a BFA in Musical Theatre and a BFA in International Theatre Production from Ohio Northern University.  "Without no strength there is now struggle."

Abigail Birkett* (Director) Abigail is excited to be back in the Out of The Loop Festival. Her directing credits include a staged reading of The Black Slot (Kitchen Dog Theater), Nightflyer to Lansdowne (Eugene O’Neill Theatre Center), and Bright Ideas (Southwestern University). She is currently working as the Emerging Artist Intern at Undermain Theatre, where she has assistant directed several productions including Long Day’s Journey Into Night, The Night Alive, The Droll and The Testament of Mary.  Abigail has also worked with Kitchen Dog Theater, assistant directing the world premiere of The Firestorm and the regional premiere of Thinner Than Water. She recently appeared in Richard III (Shakespeare in the Bar) and Dallas, Etc. (TRIBE). Her playwriting credits include Honeybuzz, a one-act play (Eugene O’Neill Theatre Center), Refrigerate After Opening, a short play (Student Play Festival, Southwestern University) and Home Sweet Canadia, a co-written devised piece (Eugene O’Neill Theater Center). She also worked as 2nd assistant director on Love Land, an award-winning independent feature film. Abigail received her theatre degree from Southwestern University and is an alumna of the National Theater Institute at the Eugene O’Neill Theater Center.

Zoë Kerr (as Naomi) Zoë Kerr began acting professionally in 2011 when she originated the role of Floy Kate Landers in Ronnie Claire Edwards’ The Mystery of Miz Arnette, produced by 1:30 Productions. In 2013, Zoë played the role of Grace Westmoreland in the regional premiere of Del Shores’ Yellow. The play was directed by Shores and produced by Uptown Players. Her performance in Yellow earned Zoë a Column Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress in an Equity Production.

In 2014, The Contemporary Theatre of Dallas cast Zoë in the role of Jennie Mae in their production of John Leonard Jr.'s The Diviners. Shortly after, Zoë was invited to perform as part of the first annual One Minute Play Festival, produced by Kitchen Dog Theater. Zoë finished off 2015 by starring in Upstart Productions' Dry Land and House Party Theatre's Desire Caught By The Tail. She's thrilled to be making her Out Of The Loop debut. 

Carissa Jade Olsen* (as Assistant Stage Manager and Voice, Master Carpenter) Carissa Jade Olsen is a graduate of Baylor University where she earned a BFA in Theatre Performance. Since moving back home to Dallas she has been seen around town in: Nomad Americana (Stormi) at the 2015 Out Of The Loop Festival at WaterTower Theatre, Romeo & Juliet(Juliet) at The Firehouse Theatre, The Lucky Chance (Diana) with Echo Theatre, The Crucible (Mary Warren), and Around the World in 80 Days (Aouda, Others), both at Stage West. A multi-disciplinary theatre artist, Carissa has also had the privilege of working as a stage manager in both New York and Dallas and as a carpenter at Baylor University.

Michael McMillan (as Cole) Michael McMillan is honored to be a part of this production during the Out of the Loop Festival! Michael moved up to the Metroplex three years ago and has been seen in Fellowship!: The Musical Parody of the Fellowship of the Ring at both Circle Theatre and Theatre Three, South Pacific and Annie Get Your Gun at Lyric Stage, A Midsummer Night’s Dream and Much Ado About Nothing at Shakespeare Dallas, and Next To Normal at Onstage in Bedford, among others. Michael graduated with a B.A. in Theatre Arts and Music from Baylor University in December 2012.

Ryan Schaap* (Costume Designer, Lighting Designer, Scenic Designer) Ryan Schaap, Costume, Lighting, and Set Designer, is from Plano, Texas. He received his BFA in Theatre Design and Technology, with an Emphasis in Costume and Lighting Design from Baylor University. Schaap's Costume credits include: Baloonacy (Dallas Children's Theatre), The Droll (Assistant Costume Designer, Undermain Theatre), Lord of the Flies (Wardrobe Supervisor, WaterTower Theatre), Creep(Wardrobe Supervisor, WaterTower Theatre), Nomad Americana (WaterTower Theatre, Out of the Loop Festival), Dead Man's Cell Phone (Baylor University), Far Away (Williamstown Theatre Festival DA Project), Working: The Musical (Mountain View College). Lighting Design: The Arabian Nights (Co-Design, Baylor University), The Aliens (Baylor University), The Taming of the Shrew + Henry VI (Baylor University Workshop). Schaap has received training from Williamstown Theatre Festival (Williamstown, Massachusetts) where he worked on The Bridges of Madison County, and Dallas Children's Theater (Dallas, Texas). Ryan is thrilled to be returning to WaterTower Theatre and the Out of the Loop Festival! 

Kira Rockwell (Playwright) Kira Rockwell is a playwright from Dallas, Texas. Her plays include Nomad Americana, With my Eyes Shut and The Deflated Balloon. She is an alumna of Baylor University where she received her BFA in Theatre Performance. Kira's play Nomad Americana, premiered in the 2015 WaterTower Theatre's Out of The Loop Fringe Festival. Her short play, With My Eyes Shut, was a winner in Little Black Dress INK's Outside the Lines Festival. It received a staged reading in Los Angeles, Alabama, Texas and received a full production in Arizona. In 2014, Kira created and established a writing group called the Waco Writer’s Collective for fellow emerging writers in her community. As a teaching artist, Kira directs and leads a theatre program for students who come from hard places at the Methodist Children’s Home. Recently, she was invited to Southwestern College and Cowley College in Kansas as the guest playwright for their 24 Hour Plays Festival where she wrote The Deflated Balloon. Currently, she is slated to have her play With My Eyes Shut premier in New York with Rehil Productions this spring. Kira resides with her husband in Waco, Texas along with their sweet lab mutt of love, Koda.

*Goat Song Theatre Collective Company Member


The Impact

Goat Song Theatre Collective is thrilled to bring the world premiere of Kira Rockwell’s newest play to the Out of the Loop Festival. 

Goat Song Theatre Collective is interested not only in which stories are being told and how they are being told, but also in who gets to tell them, and we actively seek work that expands the scope of stories seen on stage and diversifying the pool of collaborators who bring those stories to life. Though Rockwell did not set out to write a play about autism, she was inspired by her younger brother who is on the spectrum.  The piece dramatically investigates themes of connection and isolation in modern society. This is exactly the play we were looking for to make our debut.

Goat Song Theatre Collective practices inclusive casting, and originally intended to hire actors who identify on the spectrum to play the roles of Naomi and Cole. However, after reaching out to multiple organizations and advocates for disabilities in the arts, to invite both neurotypical and neuroatypical performers to audition, we were unable to find two performers on the spectrum.

Few plays portray disabled characters at all, let alone as complex individuals with their own stories to tell.  Even when productions include disabled characters, those roles are- more often than not- played by non-disabled actors or actresses. We hope that producing plays like Rockwell's With My Eyes Shut, will start to dismantle pre-packaged and two-dimensional constructs of autism and open constructive dialogue about disability in the arts and open spaces for new voices in the American theatre to be heard.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone will be able to donate financially- but that doesn't mean you can't help!  Share our campaign with others, be a voice on our behalf to ensure our campaign is exposed to as many people as possible.  

And, of course, come to WaterTower's Out of the Loop Festival to see our show! 
Three performances only: 2/28 @5p  |  3/1 @7:30p |  3/5 @8p

Few plays portray disabled characters at all, let alone as complex individuals with their own stories to tell.  Even when productions include disabled characters, those roles are- more often than not- played by non-disabled actors or actresses. We hope that producing plays like Rockwell's With My Eyes Shut, will start to dismantle pre-packaged and two-dimensional constructs of autism and open constructive dialogue about disability in the arts and open spaces for new voices in the American theatre to be heard.


Other Ways You Can Help We understand that not everyone will be able to donate financially- but that doesn't mean you can't help!  Share our campaign with others, be a voice on our behalf to ensure our campaign is exposed to as many people as possible.  
And, of course, come to WaterTower's Out of the Loop Festival to see our show! Three performances only: 2/28 @5p  |  3/1 @7:30p |  3/5 @8p

story:
This is what we're doing

Kaitlin Fox and Ginny Cook are co-producing and [Thread]ing together an evening of dance, music, and film. As two active dance artists in the Chicago community, these ladies are looking to give you their spin on the intersection of music and movement. Through collaboration with musicians Zainghis and Doc iLL of Push Beats, in addition to local filmmakers and visual artists, the evening will seamlessly bring together art in its various forms. 


This is where your money is going

Making art for public consumption costs bucks that kids like us don’t have lying around in the change jar. We’re bringing high quality work to an intimate space for your viewing pleasure. Toss in a dollar, you can feel good about where tonight’s pocket change has landed. 

The making of Fox's FLOAT Along, a dance for camera that will premier during Thread, is also included in this budget goal. 

Breakdown is as follows:

Rehearsal & Performance Space: $1000

Costumes/Props/Production Design: $1000

Performers/Musicians/Film Artists: FREE...because they're awesome. 

Production of dance for camera (lenses, food, transportation, props): $3000


Donations, no matter how small, will be recognized in the program. Every dollar counts. Feel free to email kmfox2@me.com with inquiries regarding photo and video documentation. 


Thread is brought to you by


Choreography: Ginny Cook, Kaitlin Fox, and Dylan Noe

Performance: Ginny Cook, Kaitlin Fox, Adrianna Lombardo, and Dylan Noe

Original Music: Zainghis and Doc iLL

Cinematography and Lighting Design: Nick Shamblott

Contributing Artist: Andy Berlin


Tickets are available at http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/209925.

story:
Funkanometry SF Dance Company (aka Funks SF) is an award-winning, 501(c)(3) nonprofit performing arts organization renowned in the Bay Area for our cutting-edge choreography, stylistic versatility, youth outreach, and professionalism. Every summer we host our annual dance showcase and fundraiser, The Sockhop. The Sockhop is the first showcase of its kind dedicated solely to helping dancers build stronger, more meaningful relationships with each other in the community. We believe that strong, united individual dancers is the foundation for a thriving and sustainable hip hop dance community.

This year will be our 6th year hosting the show. By creating an entire weekend of activities and events, dancers get an opportunity to learn from their peers, share their dance experiences, and ultimately create life-long bonds through their shared passion for hip hop dance. Not only do participants walk away from The Sockhop with newfound friendships, a sense of accomplishment, and the skills and encouragement to become a better and stronger dancer, they leave with the understanding that they have a nationwide network of support for their talent as a dancer.  

Additionally, everyone that is involved with The Sockhop planning are VOLUNTEERS that donate their time to create an amazing event for the community.

THE NEED:

To make the show a reality this year, we need to raise $1200 to go towards venue rental costs. We really rely on the financial support of our community members to keep the show going so that our fellow dancers can remain inspired and motivated to continue creating beautiful art to share.

Funding The Sockhop is not just about putting on another hip hop dance showcase -- it’s about showing support and appreciation for the individual dancers in the community who donate their time to make the dance community great. It’s about celebrating the artists who CREATE beautiful pieces of art that inspire us to be better.

ABOUT THE PIECES:

"Dance, when you're broken open.
Dance, if you've torn the bandage off.
Dance in the middle of the fighting.
Dance in your blood.
Dance when you're perfectly free.”   ― Rumi

Every dancer has at one time been told to “leave your drama at the door and just dance,” but every dancer knows how hard it can be to do this. For our concept piece “Chains and Confinement,” Funkanometry SF will create five mini-vignettes that explore the issues in our lives that bind us, hold us back, hurt us, and confine us through an innovative use of props. We’ll then explore the exact opposite feeling of complete freedom and create pieces that juxtapose both concepts.

The quote above explains our inspiration in wanting to create this piece. It shows the importance of continuing to dance and create through any situation life throws us. Life isn’t always beautiful and perfect; sometimes it’s dark and depressing. It’s important for dancers (especially young dancers still learning to understand and appreciate the art form) to learn how to explore ALL of their emotions and turn them into something beautiful, through dance.

Through a series of short vignettes, we’ll be exploring the ideas of Constraint vs. Freedom:

  • Vignette 1: "The Box", which we’ll dance inside of to represent being confined, or “boxed in” - Choreographed by Rocko Luciano
  • Vignette 2: "Rope", to physically chain our hands together in helplessness - Choreographed by Emerson Aquino and various other choreographers
  • Vignette 3: "Blinded", to represent those times when we’re lost  - Choreographed by Ramsey Magana & Allyson Liu
  • Ending "Freedom" - Led by Emerson Aquino, choreographed by multiple people, including a piece by guest choreographer, Austin Fernandez

The final pieces will be debuted at The Sockhop Dance Showcase on Saturday, July 6, 2013. With your financial support, we can make this show, and our new dance pieces a reality! Please help us spread the word and create a movement to support the dancers in our community!

WEBSITE: www.funkanometry.org/sockhop

FACEBOOK EVENT: www.facebook.com/events/179895522169981

story:
The good ol' fashioned tease of bump 'n' grind burlesque is enjoying a global revival, and the team at Edmonton Burlesque Events thinks its time for Canada's Festival City to add another feather in its cap... so from 17-20 October 2013 we are launching the inaugural Edmonton Burlesque Festival!

 

About the Festival

The Edmonton International Burlesque Festival is set to be an extravaganza celebrating all things burlesque, vaudeville and fabulous. It is aimed at the local, national and international theatre and arts community. The long weekend encompasses ingenues and impresarios, the avante garde and outrageous, in a series of intimate, showcase and feature events including workshops, high teas and riotous after parties.

Getting all our papers and panties in order has taken the timeless dedication of a great team of motivated volunteers who have been working on the project since January, but we need your help to really make this a success!!

 

Your contribution will help us achieve the most essential aims that are driving this festival forward

  • To enable mentoring among burlesque performers

  • To develop connections between the growing Edmonton and Albertan burlesque community with established communities across other provinces of Canada and abroad

  • To provide an avenue connecting burlesque performers throughout Alberta, across Canada and beyond, to celebrate the art form and inspire each other through performance

  • To promote the art and entertainment of burlesque to audiences in Edmonton, Alberta and throughout the province by showcasing first-class burlesque talent on stage.

 

I'll show you mine if you show me yours...

We need over $10,000 to ensure a successful first year - and we've been hard at work securing sponsorships and fundraising toward that goal with local events over the last few months - but we need some help from the greater arts community, so that we can continue to produce an even more outstanding festival in 2014 and every year after!

$3500 flights, accommodation and fees to bring in feature performers from the greater burlesque community (to really wow our local crowd and make this Edmonton festival simply fabulous)

$1000 start up business costs

$800 promotions

$1500 venue costs

Your contribution will be rewarded with something as simple as recognition in our program, through to the one-of-a-kind full burlesque costume donated by one of our board members – plus lots of other titillating perks in between.

 

A Sexy Endeavor with a Serious Mission
Edmonton International Burlesque Festival celebrates the revival of burlesque and seeks to foster awareness in an already arts minded community. Its primary goal is to develop a supportive network linked to performers across Canada through new performance opportunities and audiences.

The team pulling this together are a diverse and passionate group of burlesque performers and supporters, with the collective hands-on experience of running their own successful events, volunteering at other festivals and featuring in productions both local and international.

Even if we don't meet our goal – every little bit helps and this festival will go ahead in a shower of glitter and crystals! Even sharing this page online will help us build awareness and excitement.

story:
SOUND FOOTING Spring 2013 Fundraiser

for Sound Theatre Company

SOUND THEATRE COMPANY presents highly theatrical work inspired by language and music while showcasing professional and emerging talent in the Seattle area.

Since our first production in 2006, we have steadily produced quality, literate work that is accessible to a broad audience, fueled by the passion and contributions of our company artists.

Our "Sound Footing" fundraising campaign aims to establish financial stability for our 2013 season, and to continue creating work that demonstrates the importance and beauty of language and music.

Our 2013 Season

We have announced two works for Sound Theatre Company's 2013 season, both to be performed at the Center Theatre at the Seattle Center Armory:

Dogg's Hamlet/Cahoot's Macbeth by Tom Stoppard, June 6-23, 2013

Tom Stoppard (Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead) uses the Bard's classics to explore the nature of language, censorship and the importance of free expression. In Dogg's Hamlet, English schoolboys who speak the language of "Dogg" encounter a befuddled English-speaking delivery man as they prepare for their school production of Hamlet. In Cahoot's Macbeth, renegade actors in cold-war Czechoslovakia continue their private performance of Macbeth under the eyes of a police inspector who suspects them of subversion against the state. Artistic Director Teresa Thuman directs both plays, in which Stoppard's smart, witty and gleeful word-play illuminates the power language has in our world.  Appropriate for all audiences.

The Wild Party, book, lyrics and music by Andrew Lippa, August 8-25, 2013

Sound Theatre Company presents the Seattle premiere of The Wild Party, with book, music and lyrics by Andrew Lippa, based on the 1928 epic poem by Joseph Moncure March about the excesses of the Jazz Age.  A group of burlesque performers join together for a wild, erotic evening in a Manhattan apartment that will push the limits of their decadent and thrill-seeking high living. Corey McDaniel directs this provocative staging with music direction by Kim Dare, choreography by Jessica Low and features the physical and vocal talents of an ensemble of young professional musical theatre artists. For mature audiences: contains very adult situations.

What We Need and Where it Goes

We need to raise at least $7,500 toward our 2013 goal (ultimately, of $20,000). This sum is in addition to ticket sales, which typically cover only about half of total production expenses. Every amount helps, no matter how small!

Sound Theatre Company produces professional work on very modest budgets. Our largest production expenses are for rental of performance and rehearsal space, royalties, and material for scenery and costumes.

Sound Theatre Company is a 501(c)(3) non-profit, so all of your donations are tax-deductible.

Be a Sound Friend

All contributions of $40 and up make you a  Sound Theatre Company Sound Friend, which entitles you to $5 off of up to two tickets for each show of our 2013 season!
 
Higher donation levels entitle you to complimentary tickets, depending on the amount.
 
As a Sound Theatre Company Sponsor you can sponsor a show or a season and receive special recognition for yourself or your business in our lobby, program and marketing materials!
 

ABOUT SOUND THEATRE COMPANY

SOUND THEATRE COMPANY presents highly theatrical work inspired by language and music while showcasing professional and emerging talent in the Seattle area. Since 2006, from our first production, a site-specific staging of The Tempest performed in the water and on the shore of Lake Sammamish, SOUND THEATRE COMPANY has steadily gained a reputation for quality, literate work that is accessible to a broad audience. We have steadily grown our company of theatre artists and our production schedule to support two to three productions in a year.

TERESA THUMAN (Producing Artistic Director) founded Sound Theatre Company in 2006. Teresa has also directed for Greenstage, SecondStory Repertory, Theater Schmeater, Bainbridge Performing Arts, Seattle Musical Theatre, Driftwood Players, and Shoreline Community College. Teresa previously acted in the dual capacity of Director/Producer for Dead Woman Home, which performed in Seattle, New York City, San Francisco and the Philipines. At the Oregon Shakespeare Festival she served as Assistant Director for The Merchant of Venice and The Merry Wives of Windsor. She has taught at UW School of Drama PATP, Cornish College, Freehold ETI and served eight years as an Artist-in-Residence at PCPA Theatrefest in California, where she taught in the Conservatory and acted in over 30 productions.

 SOUND THEATRE COMPANY has received financial support from the City of Seattle Office of Arts & Cultural Affairs, City of Redmond Arts Commission, King County 4Culture, and Washington State Arts Commission.

Production History

2006 - The Tempest, by Wm. Shakespeare, Lake Sammamish, WA

2007 - The Further Adventures of Anse and Bhule in No-man’s Land, by Tania Myren, Seattle, WA

2008 - Troilus and Cressida, by Wm. Shakespeare, Seattle, WA

2009 - The Last Five Years, by Jason Robert Brown, Bainbridge Island, WA

2009 - Top Girls, by Caryl Churchill, Seattle, WA

2010 - The Belle of Amherst, by William Luce, Seattle, WA

2011 - Pygmalion, by George Bernard Shaw, Seattle, WA

2011 - The Compleat Works of Shakespeare (Abridged), by Jess Borgeson, Adam Long & Daniel Singer, Seattle WA

2012 - The Foreigner, by Larry Shue, Seattle, WA

2012 - The Illusion, adapted by Tony Kushner, Seattle, WA

2012 – Disco Pigs, by Enda Walsh, Seattle, WA

story:
Thank You. 

Obviously I'm asking you for money and the fact that you are still paying attention means a lot to me. 

I have the opportunity to perform my magic show at the 2014 Minnesota Fringe Festival. I'm trying to raise money to pay for the Production Fee, The Pizza Cost Fee for the poor souls who I trick into helping me pull this off, and the Cost of Supplies to fool the rest of you.

Still paying attention? Then maybe you love magic as much as I do and want to put a little bit more of it back into the world.

A Few More Details

  • The MN Fringe requires a production fee of $450 for a regular venue in full by March 14th.
  • I'm more than willing to share my secrets to all of you crazies who are still reading this. 
  • If we don't reach the goal do not worry. I will be paying the fee and presenting the show for all of you in August! 

 :)

Thank you for staying with me so far. If you don't feel like giving please do not worry, I'm still really excited just to tell you about the show! Would you consider telling someone else you know? I'm going to have lots of news popping up on www.thehonestmagician.com so please check in every once in a while to keep tabs on the process.

story:
Boston Community need your help to make their "VISUALIZE!" Show come to life! Our performance will bring movement to themes of light, colors, sight, and focus.

  • Created in June 2011, SKooJ CorE-O wanted to give an opportunity to fuse desired performers and make limitless possibilities. Showing passion, drive, and determination with the yearning to learn and expand in the art of story telling has molded what Boston Community Dance Project speaks. Containing foundational technique, strenuous choreography skills, and overall presentation/character involvement BCDP strives for the whole package. "Power Struggle", "Escape From Malevolence", "Remembrance", "V.O.I.D.", and “Promise” have been established with present contemporary movement, theater attention, and musicality importance in our new works premiering at Mark Morris Dance Group Theater. The Massachusetts Dance Festival, GreenFest Boston,  NYCDance Week, and NYCDanceParade are to name a few performances along with holding "Contemporize" Workshops, and supporting Domestic Violence Awareness, Suicide Prevention Foundations, Hurricane Sandy Relief, and The United Way.. Reaching out to the community with realistic matter and true situations is a mission for BCDP to help spread the positivity and release of dance. We hope to show how therapeutic, refreshing, and elating dance is for all and unite our communities. 

The Impact

Any contribution will assits many branches of this production. Below is an idea of where your donation with go

$10- One costume of five different types for different routine

$25- Printing show flyers and event brochures

$50- travel reinbursement for two dancers

$100 Paying apparel for BCDP shirts, tanks, etc.

$250 Studio rentals for rehearsals

$500  Lighting Cast and Crew Payment

$1000 total payment for guest artist to perform and teach at our Intensive

$1500 Costume reimbursement for all 23 dancers

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Share our campaign with people that might connect or be interested in our movement using the Indie Gogo share tools!
  • Check us out on our Facebook Page https://www.facebook.com/pages/Boston-Community...
  • Buy tickets for our "VISUALIZE!" SHow http://bcdpvisualize.bpt.me/

BCDP hopes that you Follow The Artistry and trust in our vision! Hope to bring our "VISUALIZE!" Show to the next level and we thank you for all the support!
story_txt:
Boston Community need your help to make their "VISUALIZE!" Show come to life! Our performance will bring movement to themes of light, colors, sight, and focus.


Created in June 2011, SKooJ CorE-O wanted to give an opportunity to fuse desired performers and make limitless possibilities. Showing passion, drive, and determination with the yearning to learn and expand in the art of story telling has molded what Boston Community Dance Project speaks. Containing foundational technique, strenuous choreography skills, and overall presentation/character involvement BCDP strives for the whole package. "Power Struggle", "Escape From Malevolence", "Remembrance", "V.O.I.D.", and “Promise” have been established with present contemporary movement, theater attention, and musicality importance in our new works premiering at Mark Morris Dance Group Theater. The Massachusetts Dance Festival, GreenFest Boston,  NYCDance Week, and NYCDanceParade are to name a few performances along with holding "Contemporize" Workshops, and supporting Domestic Violence Awareness, Suicide Prevention Foundations, Hurricane Sandy Relief, and The United Way.. Reaching out to the community with realistic matter and true situations is a mission for BCDP to help spread the positivity and release of dance. We hope to show how therapeutic, refreshing, and elating dance is for all and unite our communities. 




The Impact
Any contribution will assits many branches of this production. Below is an idea of where your donation with go
$10- One costume of five different types for different routine
$25- Printing show flyers and event brochures
$50- travel reinbursement for two dancers
$100 Paying apparel for BCDP shirts, tanks, etc.
$250 Studio rentals for rehearsals
$500  Lighting Cast and Crew Payment
$1000 total payment for guest artist to perform and teach at our Intensive
$1500 Costume reimbursement for all 23 dancers

Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
Make it real for people and build trust.



Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Share our campaign with people that might connect or be interested in our movement using the Indie Gogo share tools!
Check us out on our Facebook Page https://www.facebook.com/pages/Boston-Community...

Buy tickets for our "VISUALIZE!" SHow http://bcdpvisualize.bpt.me/



BCDP hopes that you Follow The Artistry and trust in our vision! Hope to bring our "VISUALIZE!" Show to the next level and we thank you for all the support!

story:
Between Us Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Between Us Productions must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
Parables for the One Percent is a satirical comedy that explores what we have never heard; the interior monologues of the richest people alive today. It's safe to laugh, but the facts are nothing but dire. For the first time, the richest in our world have bought a commodity we can't take back: our futures.

We are offering a number of rewards to show our appreciation for your support. Theatre is a collaborative art and we want to foster a community of supported artists and enthusiastic audience members. Please show your support and be a part of something magical!

Between Us Productions is committed to bringing daring and compelling theatre to our audiences and pushing our boundaries as artists. Likewise, it is important to us to support artists who share our commitment to performing relevant work.

Please visit our facebook (http://www.facebook.com/BetweenUsProductions), our website (http://betweenusproductions.wix.com/betweenusprod), our blog (http://betweenusprod.blogspot.com/) and follow us on twitter (http://twitter.com/betweenusprod). 

Please check out our video. It has clips from performances, pictures and interviews with all of us!


Parables for the One Percent

Written by Karl Custer

Directed by Samantha Lee Manas

Produced by Jasmine Brown and Graydon Gund


Starring:

Stephanie Alvarez as Jackie

Casey Bartolucci as Pharaoh

Tierney Nolen as Jacqueline

Anna Stefanic as Anne

Ari Vigoda as Slave

David Weinheimer as Robert


Costume Design by Carolann Volatrel

Lighting Design by Lauren Bremmen

January 8-12 at 

The Studio Theater at Theater Row
