story:
Our Story

Rosie Thorn is a character that was born out the devised theatre piece 'The Powder Room' based on Carol-Ann Duffy's poem 'Warming the Pearls'. The company that I was involved in at the time took this play to Edinburgh Fringe Festival in 2006. 

 

Since then the character of Rosie has evolved from a girl into a grown up 1950's housewife with aspirations to perfection and tendencies towards the macabre. I have performed Rosie on the London cabaret circuit before writing a full-length script that follows her antics in the Village of Featherington-On-The-Wold. 

 

After performing the show at a comedy festival and receiving very positive feedback I decided to take the show to Edinburgh Fringe Festival, with aspirations of it being taken on tour. I have put together a very professional and competent team, a marketing manager, PR agent and technician that all believe in the show and it's potential. We have a great Central venue in Edinburgh which is vital for bringing in audience and press. 

 

 

The Impact

The idea behind the Rosie Thorn campaign is that the show will make an impact in Edinburgh, gaining covering in both local and national media, including press, television and radio. 

 

Managers and bookers will see the show and the Rosie team will push towards being booked firstly for a national tour in the UK, with a view to it being taken to the U.S. 

 

If the full amount is not raised then taking Rosie to Edinburgh will still go ahead, but it will have to be done on a much smaller budget. This would mean that eye catching 'press calls' such as Rosie on a big cupake would not be possible. It is important that as a small team we are creative and think about ways to stand out from all the other performers at the festival. The competition is high as Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the largest arts festival in the world.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Altogether we are looking for a total figure of  £15,000  this figure will allow us to make a good impact.

 

We are investigating other routes of sponsorship in addition to Indiegogo, such as corporate sponsors with a vested interest in the project.

 

Financial Breakdown:

Venue = £2,400

Edfringe brochure = £300

Travel costs = £500

Accommodation = £3,200

Disposable props = £300

Props = £500

Marketing Support = £2,000

PPL Licence = £100

Posters and Flyers = £2,000

Expenses = £800

Printing Costs = £500

PR Costs = £2,500

 

As previously stated without funding it would not be possible to have a PR Agent and all the things that go with that, I would also would not be able to cover accommodation costs for the team. I would have to find a way to fund all the other elements.

 

Donations £1-£100

You will get a mention on Mrs. Rosie Thorn's Twitter, Facebook and Blog.

Regular updates on the Rosie's progress.

 

Donations £100-£500

You will get a mention on Mrs. Rosie Thorn's Twitter, Facebook and Blog.

FREE tickets to the pre-Edinburgh shows in London.

Regular updates on the Rosie's progress.

 

Donations £500-£1000

You will get a mention on Mrs. Rosie Thorn's Twitter, Facebook and Blog.

FREE tickets to the pre-Edinburgh shows in London.

Regular updates on the Rosie's progress.

You will get a mention on the flyers, of which at least 10,000 will be printed and continually distributed throughout the festival.

 

Donations £1000+

You will get a mention on Mrs. Rosie Thorn's Twitter, Facebook and Blog.

10 FREE tickets to the show in Edinburgh.

Regular updates on the Rosie's progress.

You will get a mention on the flyers, of which at least 10,000 will be printed and continually distributed throughout the festival.

Cupcakes delivered by Rosie Thorn within London. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help to get the word out about Mrs. Rosie Thorn, add her as a friend on Facebook, follow her on Twitter and on her blog @ www.mrs-rosie-thorn.com.

 

In addition if you know anyone in the industry who may be interested in the character for T.V, theatre or radio please do send them in the right direction. 

 

Dates of the pre-Edinburgh Shows – All shows start at 8pm

 

Rosie Thorn, Butter Would Not Melt
Saturday 21st May
The Archway Theatre
The Drive
Horley
RH6 7NQ
01293 784 398
Closest station is Horley
Tickets: FREE


Rosie Thorn, Butter Would Not Melt
Thursday 9th June
Battersea Barge
Tideway Walk
Nine Elms Lane,
London 
SW8 59Z
020 7498 0004
Nearest Tube is Vauxhall
Tickets: FREE


Rosie Thorn, Butter Would Not Melt
Wednesday 22nd June
Scream Lounge
20 South End 
Croydon

020 8667 0155
Nearest train station East Croydon about 15 minutes walk.
Tickets: FREE 


Rosie Thorn, Butter Would Not Melt
Thursday 7th July
The Taverstock Room
The Bedford
77 Bedford Hill
City of London, 
Greater London 
SW12 9HD
020 8682 8940
Closest station is Balham
Tickets: FREE

story:
PLEASE NOTE: Our online donation campaign has come to an end, but our fundraising efforts are still going strong! If you would like to contribute, please make out a check to:

Mind the Gap Theatre
535 W 23rd St, S11G
New York, NY 10011

*Please send checks to the attention of Paula D'Alessandris and write "MERMAID" on the memo line. Thank you for your continued support!*

The Tale of our Tail

Mind The Gap Theatre and Early Bird Theatricals will present Jessica Fleitman’s award winning comedy The Average-Sized Mermaid (2008 Corwin Award) in August 2011 in The New York International Fringe Festival. The production will be directed by Mind The Gap’s Artistic Director, Paula D’Alessandris (The Cleric at 59E59; In Under The Blue Sky at The Kraine, In The Pipeline at Manhattan Theatre Source) and will feature Dawn McGee*, Vinnie Penna*, David J. Goldberg, Erika Myers, Shannon Munley & Daniel Cibener.

*Appearing courtesy of the Actors’ Equity Association.

 

In The Average-Sized Mermaid, Miriam Moselle magically transforms into a mermaid and unexpectedly finds herself the figurehead of a feminist movement. But when she begins to fall for an unconventional prince charming, she soon learns that you need to be careful what you fish for…

The Impact

Let's face it: we could all use a laugh these days. That's what we're aiming to do: bring a fun, intelligent, un-pretentious, heart-warming, sexy, hilarious, old-fashioned screwball romantic comedy to the New York International Fringe Festival (but, you know, with a tail and an appearance by a drag queen). We just want to tell what we believe to be a great story with the best cast and crew possible in the best way possible. But we need your help!


What We Need & WHAT YOU GET!

The truth of the matter is, this production will either sink or swim based on your donations. Any contribution at any level counts! $40 pays for space for one complete three-hour rehearsal. Your donation of $175 means we can rehearse for a week! $200 covers the cost of printing postcards to market the show. $500 gets us costumes, including a fin-tastic, built-from-scratch mermaid tail! And so on...

 

Please note: All contributions to the FringeNYC production of The Average-Sized Mermaid are tax-deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law. Holy MACKEREL! How flipping cool is that?

 

All donations will be acknowledged on our Mer-Blog for all the world to see, but check out our MER-PERKS:
 

  • $25: FIN-TASTIC FRIENDS receive our oFISHial "permanently-out-there-in-the-world-of-cyberspace" thank you on our website + our exclusive and succinct MERbacker updates!
    •  
  • $40: COOL CRUSTACEANS get everything $25 gets + an oFISHial thank you IN PRINT in our program, which you'll see when you claim your one (1) free ticket to the show!
    •  
  • $100: DOLPH-WINNERS get everything $40 gets + one additional (2 total) free tickets to the show + a fashionably trend-setting, ecologically sensible, limited edition MERtote!

 

  • $175: SUPPORTIVE SHARKS get everything $100 gets + an ORIGINAL "2 Minutes or Under" personalized audition monologue written by playwright Jessica Fleitman suited to your acting strengths and interests, or give as a gift to the starving actor/actress that you love!

 

  • $275: BIG TUNAS get everything $175 gets + two additional tickets to the show (4 total) + a (1) one hour monologue coaching session with Mind The Gap Theatre’s Artistic Director, Paula D'Alessandris for you, or as a gift to the starving actor/actress that you love! 

 

  • $500: ANGELFISH get everything $275 gets + a FULL EVALUATION of your play or musical, or give as a gift to the struggling writer(s) that you love, by New York theatre industry professional, Robin Rothstein!

 

  • $1,000: RULERS OF ATLANTIS get everything $500 gets + A PRODUCER CREDIT ON THE PRODUCTION, including a full biography on our website under "Creative Team" and in our show's program for all to see!

 

ANNNNND … THE HIGHEST BACKER gets all the items included in the category within which s/he contributed + WILL HAVE HIS/HER NAME WRITTEN INTO “THE AVERAGE-SIZED MERMAID” AND WILL BE HEARD BY THE THRONGING MASSES ATTENDING OUR PRODUCTION! Don't miss your chance to be part of New York theatre history!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about the show, and please follow our mer-blog (avgmermaid.blogspot.com) for pictures, updates, and special offers! And please do come and see the show when it dives into the FringeNYC this August!

 

Thank you for your support! It is appreciated more than you know!

$500: ANGELFISH get everything $275 gets + a FULL EVALUATION of your play or musical, or give as a gift to the struggling writer(s) that you love, by New York theatre industry professional, Robin Rothstein!
 

$1,000: RULERS OF ATLANTIS get everything $500 gets + A PRODUCER CREDIT ON THE PRODUCTION, including a full biography on our website under "Creative Team" and in our show's program for all to see! 
ANNNNND … THE HIGHEST BACKER gets all the items included in the category within which s/he contributed + WILL HAVE HIS/HER NAME WRITTEN INTO “THE AVERAGE-SIZED MERMAID” AND WILL BE HEARD BY THE THRONGING MASSES ATTENDING OUR PRODUCTION! Don't miss your chance to be part of New York theatre history!

Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word about the show, and please follow our mer-blog (avgmermaid.blogspot.com) for pictures, updates, and special offers! And please do come and see the show when it dives into the FringeNYC this August!
 
Thank you for your support! It is appreciated more than you know!

story:
If you know me (hi Mom!), you know I've been working hard these past two years and accomplished some great stuff (if I do say so myself)...

  • I've choreographed two stage works and am about to finish my third.
  • I've performed my stage work in festivals in Santa Barbara, Pasadena, and Chicago. 
  • I created CRIT, a series of free informal showings of new works and works-in-progress by local performing artists followed by a critique by the audience, so far sponsoring performances by eleven Santa Barbara area performance artists.
  • I created my first site-specific dance for the Museum of Contemporary Art Santa Barbara's Shift, Stretch, Expand: Everyday Transformations exhibition.
  • I collaborated with artists Shannon Willis and Marco Pinter on a multi-media site specific work for the LightWorks Isla Vista Festival.
  • I was honored to receive the first annual Excellence In Choreography award for emerging choreographer from the Santa Barbara Independent.

You can check out more about my work and what I've been doing on my website at www.wesliechingdance.com

Cool! So what's next?

My first evening-length performance! I'll be showing my previously choreographed stage works You (Or Someone Like You) and We Are Made Of Stars along with the premiere of part one of my new work, The Entirety Of Us. I'll also be hosting friends and fellow dance artists Jessica Kondrath and Robin Bisio as they share some of their new work.

Nice Wes...so where do I come in?

To make this show a reality, I need to raise...

$2,500!

(dun, dun, dun)

Here's what I'll use it for:

  • $1000 - Rental of Center Stage Theater on October 1, 2016 
  • $750 - Payment to five dancers for this one-night performance
  • $500 - Costumes and set pieces for my dances
  • $250 - Miscellaneous production expenses such as posters and programs.

That's the nitty gritty friends. Thanks for reading this far. 

If you have the inclination and the ability to help THANK YOU SO MUCH! 

You can chose your giving level (and perk!) in the boxes to the right. Your donation will be processed by my fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas, a 501(c)3 non-profit organization, and you will receive a receipt for your tax-deductible donation (less the value of any perks). You must submit your address to receive your receipt.

If you would like to support me without giving your address or to donate with no perks for a tax-deductible receipt for the full amount of the donation, please visit the SUPPORT page of my website at www.wesliechingdance.com/support or email me at info@wesliechingdance.com.

Oh yeah, and if you'd like to learn a little more about why I'm asking for help, please read on...

First things first,

I have a lot of gratitude for the circumstances of my life. I've spent a good portion of it thus far immersed in the world of dance- as a student, performer, teacher, and producer. That I have the luxury of spending my time making art is not lost on me. For those of us that find our meaning in life through art, as creators and/or appreciators, it is a sacred and life-affirming endeavor.   I am so thankful for all that I have.

That said,

here's a little conundrum: How does one establish oneself an artist? I'm sure there are lots of answers, but...

One obvious answer that comes to mind is this: make "good art". Ok, and what do you need to make good art? Well, certainly...

  • talent,
  • inspiration,
  • dedication, and 
  • a lot of hard work (the verb, not the noun)

are necessary. And, what else? For a choreographer, some more concrete necessities for making good dance are...

  • a studio in which to make said dance,
  • skilled dancers to bring the choreography to life,
  • music, costumes, lighting, and sets to support and enhance the work; and
  • a performance space in which to show it (after all, dance is a performing art)!

That settled, another question: what does it take to get rehearsal space; skilled dancers; music, costumes, lighting and sets; and a performance space? Yup, you guess it...

  • funding (ie. MONEY!) 

Ok, we're making progress now. Next question: as a choreographer, how do you get funding? Why through, among other things...

  • grants,
  • commissions, and
  • ticket sales.

Yes, yes, yes, and I think we're almost done here! And, how do you get grants and commissions? How do you sell tickets for performances? Easy...

  • (HUSTLE...and...)
  • make good art.

Wait a sec...isn't that kind of where we started?

Ok, ok, I'm sorry-

I'll admit that was pedantic. We're at Indiegogo after all. We know what this is about. You're here to support artists by giving them money. But, to take it a step further, I would say that by donating to artists through crowd funding campaigns, you might help them to make the leap beyond the work/money/work merry-go-round.

Did you know that many non-profit organizations prefer to give grants to artists who have already  received over $1,000 in community support (read: donations) from people other than the artist's immediate family?

Perhaps your contribution will be the boost that gets them the resources they need to make the kind of work that gets them to the next level, to that magical unicorn status of working artist. 

I'm proud of what I've accomplished thus far, but with funds I raise through this campaign I hope to:

    • Produce a professional-level performance of exciting and engaging dance!
    • Leverage this performance into opportunities to perform at dance festivals throughout the United States and build my choreography and performance portfolio.
    • Leverage my portfolio to obtain grants and commissions.
    • Use those grants and commissions to put on more great performances and sell some tickets.
    • Keep the cycle going!
    • (fingers crossed ;)

    Good job, you read the whole thing! Gold star for you and thanks for listening to me as I explain my thought process behind this big, scary thing that I'm doing. And again, if you have the inclination and the ability to help, THANK YOU SO MUCH!

    With much love, respect, and gratitude...

    Weslie

    Weslie Ching Dance is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Weslie Ching Dance must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
story_txt:
If you know me (hi Mom!), you know I've been working hard these past two years and accomplished some great stuff (if I do say so myself)...

I've choreographed two stage works and am about to finish my third.
I've performed my stage work in festivals in Santa Barbara, Pasadena, and Chicago. 
I created CRIT, a series of free informal showings of new works and works-in-progress by local performing artists followed by a critique by the audience, so far sponsoring performances by eleven Santa Barbara area performance artists.
I created my first site-specific dance for the Museum of Contemporary Art Santa Barbara's Shift, Stretch, Expand: Everyday Transformations exhibition.
I collaborated with artists Shannon Willis and Marco Pinter on a multi-media site specific work for the LightWorks Isla Vista Festival.
I was honored to receive the first annual Excellence In Choreography award for emerging choreographer from the Santa Barbara Independent.

You can check out more about my work and what I've been doing on my website at www.wesliechingdance.com
Cool! So what's next?
My first evening-length performance! I'll be showing my previously choreographed stage works You (Or Someone Like You) and We Are Made Of Stars along with the premiere of part one of my new work, The Entirety Of Us. I'll also be hosting friends and fellow dance artists Jessica Kondrath and Robin Bisio as they share some of their new work.
Nice Wes...so where do I come in?
To make this show a reality, I need to raise...
$2,500!
(dun, dun, dun)
Here's what I'll use it for:

$1000 - Rental of Center Stage Theater on October 1, 2016 
$750 - Payment to five dancers for this one-night performance
$500 - Costumes and set pieces for my dances
$250 - Miscellaneous production expenses such as posters and programs.

That's the nitty gritty friends. Thanks for reading this far. 
If you have the inclination and the ability to help THANK YOU SO MUCH! 
You can chose your giving level (and perk!) in the boxes to the right. Your donation will be processed by my fiscal sponsor Fractured Atlas, a 501(c)3 non-profit organization, and you will receive a receipt for your tax-deductible donation (less the value of any perks). You must submit your address to receive your receipt.
If you would like to support me without giving your address or to donate with no perks for a tax-deductible receipt for the full amount of the donation, please visit the SUPPORT page of my website at www.wesliechingdance.com/support or email me at info@wesliechingdance.com.
Oh yeah, and if you'd like to learn a little more about why I'm asking for help, please read on...
First things first,
I have a lot of gratitude for the circumstances of my life. I've spent a good portion of it thus far immersed in the world of dance- as a student, performer, teacher, and producer. That I have the luxury of spending my time making art is not lost on me. For those of us that find our meaning in life through art, as creators and/or appreciators, it is a sacred and life-affirming endeavor.   I am so thankful for all that I have.

That said,
here's a little conundrum: How does one establish oneself an artist? I'm sure there are lots of answers, but...
One obvious answer that comes to mind is this: make "good art". Ok, and what do you need to make good art? Well, certainly...

talent,
inspiration,
dedication, and 
a lot of hard work (the verb, not the noun)

are necessary. And, what else? For a choreographer, some more concrete necessities for making good dance are...

a studio in which to make said dance,
skilled dancers to bring the choreography to life,
music, costumes, lighting, and sets to support and enhance the work; and
a performance space in which to show it (after all, dance is a performing art)!

That settled, another question: what does it take to get rehearsal space; skilled dancers; music, costumes, lighting and sets; and a performance space? Yup, you guess it...
funding (ie. MONEY!) 
Ok, we're making progress now. Next question: as a choreographer, how do you get funding? Why through, among other things...

grants,
commissions, and
ticket sales.

Yes, yes, yes, and I think we're almost done here! And, how do you get grants and commissions? How do you sell tickets for performances? Easy...

(HUSTLE...and...)
make good art.

Wait a sec...isn't that kind of where we started?

Ok, ok, I'm sorry-
I'll admit that was pedantic. We're at Indiegogo after all. We know what this is about. You're here to support artists by giving them money. But, to take it a step further, I would say that by donating to artists through crowd funding campaigns, you might help them to make the leap beyond the work/money/work merry-go-round.
Did you know that many non-profit organizations prefer to give grants to artists who have already  received over $1,000 in community support (read: donations) from people other than the artist's immediate family?
Perhaps your contribution will be the boost that gets them the resources they need to make the kind of work that gets them to the next level, to that magical unicorn status of working artist. 

I'm proud of what I've accomplished thus far, but with funds I raise through this campaign I hope to:


Produce a professional-level performance of exciting and engaging dance!
Leverage this performance into opportunities to perform at dance festivals throughout the United States and build my choreography and performance portfolio.
Leverage my portfolio to obtain grants and commissions.
Use those grants and commissions to put on more great performances and sell some tickets.
Keep the cycle going!
(fingers crossed ;)
Good job, you read the whole thing! Gold star for you and thanks for listening to me as I explain my thought process behind this big, scary thing that I'm doing. And again, if you have the inclination and the ability to help, THANK YOU SO MUCH!With much love, respect, and gratitude...WeslieWeslie Ching Dance is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Weslie Ching Dance must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
On Monday, May 14th, the rehearsal space we shared with well-loved Seattle band The Bad Things burned to the ground destroying all the equipment inside. The other bands lost pretty much everything they had, while we were much luckier losing only our collection of microhones, cords and stands.

This equipment is desperately needed for us to perform our shows at the Can Can on May 24th and June 28th. Anything our friends and family can do to help us out would be greatly appreciated!

Any amount will help us achieve this goal, and if by some miracle we raise more than we need to replace our equipment, the extra funds will be invested in creating some merchandise, building our Halloween Show, recording, etc.

 

Normally bands offer some great rewards of CD's or t-shirts, but unfortunatley we don't have those things yet so we have had to be creative.

Thank you very much in advance!

story:
SUMMARY

This is a student run event. We have been working tirelessly all year putting together the costumes for shows as well as our own individual projects and this is our opportunity to showcase what we have achieved and promote ourselves and our talents to industry professionals and also our friends and family. This even and in particular our Grad Show exhibition are our contribution to the University's Arts Festival - Platform 4.

 

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Staging an event and putting together gallery exhibitions is an expensive business, here's what your money will go towards.

  • Buying materials for the exhibition. To display our work in all it's glory we will need to purchase boards and card to mount designs on to, frames to put work in the performance spaces and also labels and printing to credit individuals and explain the context of works.

  • Printing. We will need to market the event using posters and flyers which can be expensive to print. Also our exhibition yearbook containing photos and biographies of what we have been up to this year and over the course of our time at university.

  • Paying technical staff. The performance needs to be lit and have music/sound to exhibit our costumes in a true theatre setting so we will require technical staff to do this.

  • Hiring additional equipment. We want to hire projectors to inform the audience about what is on the runway and who's work it is, in previous years this has been a very successful element of the show however it is also one of the biggest expense. We may need to hire additional lights and other technical equipment.

This event is coordinated by us the students however we can only achieve so much without additional technical staff and equipment. Please donate and spread the word to help us to make Costume Showcase 2017 the biggest and best it's ever been!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't donate please share this link to help reach those who can!
  • Come along to the show @ Summerhall, Edinburgh on May 19th, performances are 3pm and 7pm, tickets are available from https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/queen-margaret-university-costume-showcase-tickets-31966266965

On Behalf of all the students here on the costume course THANK YOU! If you have any questions please email Siobhan at - 13000785@qmu.ac.uk

story:
(Mental Health: The Facts & Hard Truths)

Northern Ireland has the highest levels of mental illness in the UK, more than any other region, with a reported 25% higher overall prevalence compared to England. 1 in 3 people here will suffer from mental health illnesses compared to 1 in 4 in the rest of the UK. Mental Illness is the biggest cause of disability in Northern Ireland yet out of a £4.9bn budget; only £225m is spent on mental health here.  Studies have shown that 75% of mental illness problems begin before the age of 18, 50% take root before turning 15 and in recent years up to 10% of school children will be diagnosed with a mental health illness - in a class of 30, that’s 3 children suffering.  Statistics show that the UK and Ireland’s mental health problems are rising and developing at a younger age.  In all of those cases, only 25% of young people are receiving treatment and 75% of people are not receiving any treatment at all. In the UK and Northern Ireland suicide is the biggest killer of young people.  We need to start talking about mental health, we need to create safe spaces for people to be informed and comforted.

(What is SHARKTANK & why should YOU crowdfund US?)

SHARKTANK is a daring and innovative devised performance piece about being a creative in Northern Ireland and the impact that can have on your mental health. It is an empowering piece inspired directly from the cast’s personal experiences in the performing arts community.

SHARKTANK is cathartic, irreverent and self-deprecating. It is an entertaining piece unmasking the “conventions” of the theatre world, which can hinder our ability to put our hand up and say, ‘I feel like I’m being swallowed up’. We don’t want to feel discouraged about our industry - we want to change it. No fancy lighting states, no elaborate stage - just seven individuals sharing their experiences.

SHARKTANK is a melting pot of performance styles; we are a mix of dancers, clowns, performers, actors and musicians. We are experimenting with a combination of art forms to deliver the most authentic and meaningful performance possible.

Performing at the Stockholm fringe is an incredible opportunity; it is one of the leading fringe festivals in the world, producing an exhilarating programme of risk takers across an abundance of art-forms.  We are one of only a few Irish acts to have ever been invited. By bringing SHARKTANK to Stockholm, we are bringing our conversation about mental health to an international audience. By showcasing Irish art on a world stage, we hope to raise the profile of mental health issues and with enough help and support, bring SHARKTANK home and tour the production, and share it with you.

We believe that SHARKTANK needs to be seen. We are creating a better way of communicating with other industry professionals, creatives and those who dedicate their lives to creating art. We want to champion their stories so that anyone who has experienced mental health issues can both join the conversation, recognise that they are not alone, understand that the conversation is happening, and that we want to listen and do something about it.

SHARTANK is a completely non-funded production. The lack of a functioning government in Northern Ireland and the severity of arts funding cuts have made it incredibly difficult for us to reach our goal of performing together in Stockholm.

 

 

(What do SHARKTANK need money for?)

We are incredibly grateful for any contribution. Here’s what your money will be going towards:

  • Props
  • Food
  • Return flights
  • Accommodation
  • Luggage
  • Transport

If you are unable to contribute financially, please follow our journey and support the SHARKTANK team by sharing our story across social media. If you are in the position to donate, we have a range of perks you can receive, details of which can be found on our crowd funder.

SHARKTANK is bringing awareness, starting a discussion and opening people up to the truth about mental health in Northern Ireland. We want to break down the barriers and let people know that it’s ok to not be ok. Artists supporting artists, people supporting people and now, more than ever, we need your help. We need to start talking about mental health.

The SHARKTANK performers and production team is comprised of Ro Owens, Amanda Doherty, Rob Crawford, Aaron Hickland, Emily McDonagh, Noel Harron, Emily Foran and Niall McAleer.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read.

story:
ByTheHand's The Jekyll & Hyde Case

 ByTheHand was founded on a shared belief that an open and collaborative environment breeds creativity. Open to everyone with a passion for theatre - regardless of history or experience - it is built on the passion and hard work of the people involved.

Our new project The Jekyll & Hyde Case is a community based project, which brings together like-minded individual from different backgrounds across the city of York: University and College students, veterans of the community-theatre world, newbies to the arts, local residents and young professionals. 

Part of the 2014 York Festival of Ideas, it is an exciting way for people to showcase talent on all levels, and this year we are even more excited to be working with new, original writing - giving a student the opportunity to have their work performed on a nationally talked about arena.                    



We, the Creative Team made up of ByTheHand veterans Sophie Hackett (Producer), Ollie Mills (Director) and Emily Humphrys (Associate Producer), know that hard work and dedication alone can not make shows like this happen, and that is where we need you!

How you can help

We are aiming to raise £600 to help cover 

  • Location fees  (Hiring and business rates - £350)
  • Expensive lighting and sound equipment (total £375)
  • Printing Costs (£200)
  • Seating (total £250)
  • Costume (total £200)

A part of our funding has been raising already: ticket sales from our last show Anne Boleyn (which received 5* in the local press, check out our page here), personal funding from the Creative Team, and contributions from the cast, but we just need that last little bit.

The Perks

As a THANK YOU we have a number of things we would like to offer, including free programmes, become a Friend to the Production, free tickets to the show itself, and for five contributors a Co-Producer credit. 

Every little helps here, so even if we don't reach our goal we are that much closer to providing York with the best production we can!

The Impact

The Festival of Ideas was created to showcase York's culture, talent and passion; something The Jekyll & Hyde Case will undoubtedly deliver.

Last year's ByTheHand production 'Anne Boleyn' set in King's Manor, an Eighteenth Century Manor House, reintroduced the city to the treasure that it holds just a stone's throw from the Minster, and for the cast and production crew it was valuable experience that was used in securing Drama School auditions and work placements in large, established theatre companies in London that summer. We hope The Jekyll & Hyde Case, set in a forgotten city-centre warehouse, will encourage people to look beyond the surface of their city and rediscover its secrets. 'Anne Boleyn' received 5* in the (link), and we hope to replicate that success for the Festival this year - promoting York, its residents, its students and its phenomenal talent!

Get involved!

We are always looking for spare hands, so if you have an interest in production or front of house and you will be in York in June, let us know. We are always excited to meet other passionate people.

Help us spread the word about the show; scream and shout on Facebook and Twitter, check out our sites below, and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools. 

 www.facebook.com/jekyllhydeyork

www.twitter.com/jekyllhydeyork

www.jekyllhydeyork.wordpress.com

Lastly, but most importantly, from all of us at The Jekyll & Hyde Case 'THANK YOU' for your support

story:
ClownSnotBombs Circus: The Spaghetti Tour

ClownSnotBombs is a non-profit community circus troupe that believes joy and laughter are fundamental human right. A company of six multi-talented physical theater artists, circus performers, and musicians, we are dedicated to creating theater and bringing joy to audiences young and old. We are a fiscally sponsored project of Living Dream Arts a 501(c)3 non-profit organization.

We are Fundraising for the following:

  •     Northern California and Oregon Tour 2014! We will be performing in 7 cities with 10 shows and 4 workshops.
  •     We are recording an album of all original music from our show "A Spaghetti Western"
  •     Basic operating costs for our 2014 season (transportation, parking, rental costs, props)
  •     Any additional funds raised will go directly toward creating all new show for 2015 called "Snake Oil"

What We Need & What You Get

We are fundraising for $5000 to pay for our summer tour expenses, record our first album, and our basic operating costs for this year. All that for only $5000? We make your money count! Any additional funds raised will help us to perform more shows and also to create an all new show for 2015.

With your support, we will raise funds toward our summer tour and our 2014 season. Our tour is already booked and we need funds NOW. Funds that go directly costs of paying for travel and food with our gear and 6 performers for 17 days. 

The album is being recorded as you read this and the costs associated are very high. Once the album is printed, it will be sold at our shows creating an ongoing source of revenue. And you can help make this happen!We have some great perks! Our featured perk is of course our all new album The Spaghetti Album. Other great perks include T-Shirts, Hoodies, Tote bags, stickers, patches, and more! 

The Impact

Short and sweet: your money will benefit the kids and the community. And who doesn’t love that? Here is how your money helps:

ClownSnotBombs has been involved in East Bay communities for over ten years. We believe there is great need for art in our society to enrich our quality of life and revitalize communities. Presenting our art to the general public is important to us; we keep our shows friendly to all, ticket prices affordable, and also offer many free shows in order to reach a larger audience and keep our shows accessible.

But what about the kids? I’m glad you asked! In the East Bay ClownSnotBombs has led youth after-school and summer programs since 2009. We have also hosted a FREE weekly circus skill-share for all ages since 2002. That is over a decade of community focused work.

Our contributions to the community don’t end there. Founded in 2006 ClownSnotBombs continues to tour and perform throughout the Bay Area, California, and beyond. YOUR funding will help us to continue to provide these exceptional activities to our community and the kids.

In 2012 we were awarded a CA$H grant administered by Theater Bay Area to create a new work called “A Spaghetti Western,” a contemporary ensemble-based show directed by Faeble Kievman. That income paid for the creation of our show. THIS is the show we are taking out on the road: the show your money is supporting!

Can't contribute but want to help?

Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Share our campaign with your friends and family on IndieGoGo, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.
Volunteer at one of our events!
Donate an in-kind donation of any type!

ClownSnotBombs Circus: The Spaghetti TourClownSnotBombs is a non-profit community circus troupe that believes joy and laughter are fundamental human right. A company of six multi-talented physical theater artists, circus performers, and musicians, we are dedicated to creating theater and bringing joy to audiences young and old. We are a fiscally sponsored project of Living Dream Arts a 501(c)3 non-profit organization.We are Fundraising for the following:
    Northern California and Oregon Tour 2014! We will be performing in 7 cities with 10 shows and 4 workshops.
    We are recording an album of all original music from our show "A Spaghetti Western"
    Basic operating costs for our 2014 season (transportation, parking, rental costs, props)
    Any additional funds raised will go directly toward creating all new show for 2015 called "Snake Oil"
What We Need & What You GetWe are fundraising for $5000 to pay for our summer tour expenses, record our first album, and our basic operating costs for this year. All that for only $5000? We make your money count! Any additional funds raised will help us to perform more shows and also to create an all new show for 2015.With your support, we will raise funds toward our summer tour and our 2014 season. Our tour is already booked and we need funds NOW. Funds that go directly costs of paying for travel and food with our gear and 6 performers for 17 days. The album is being recorded as you read this and the costs associated are very high. Once the album is printed, it will be sold at our shows creating an ongoing source of revenue. And you can help make this happen!We have some great perks! Our featured perk is of course our all new album The Spaghetti Album. Other great perks include T-Shirts, Hoodies, Tote bags, stickers, patches, and more! The ImpactShort and sweet: your money will benefit the kids and the community. And who doesn’t love that? Here is how your money helps:ClownSnotBombs has been involved in East Bay communities for over ten years. We believe there is great need for art in our society to enrich our quality of life and revitalize communities. Presenting our art to the general public is important to us; we keep our shows friendly to all, ticket prices affordable, and also offer many free shows in order to reach a larger audience and keep our shows accessible.But what about the kids? I’m glad you asked! In the East Bay ClownSnotBombs has led youth after-school and summer programs since 2009. We have also hosted a FREE weekly circus skill-share for all ages since 2002. That is over a decade of community focused work.Our contributions to the community don’t end there. Founded in 2006 ClownSnotBombs continues to tour and perform throughout the Bay Area, California, and beyond. YOUR funding will help us to continue to provide these exceptional activities to our community and the kids.In 2012 we were awarded a CA$H grant administered by Theater Bay Area to create a new work called “A Spaghetti Western,” a contemporary ensemble-based show directed by Faeble Kievman. That income paid for the creation of our show. THIS is the show we are taking out on the road: the show your money is supporting! Can't contribute but want to help?Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Share our campaign with your friends and family on IndieGoGo, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.Volunteer at one of our events!Donate an in-kind donation of any type!

story:
About Kemiyondo!

Ugandan based actress and playwright Kemiyondo Coutinho has a focus on theatre for social change. She wrote her first one- woman play "Jabulile!" in 2007 and went on to take the play to the fringe of Grahamstown National Festival in South Africa twice (2007 & 2010). The play also went on to do performances in New York, Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Canada.

She continued to pursue her writing and focus on female empowerment and went on to write her most recent one- woman show, Kawuna..youre it! The play premiered at the Gender Studies Symposium in 2012 and has recently been performed at The Sky Festival at the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco.  The play was also chosen to be a part of a New York Global Spotlight Reading with Hybrid Works.  Now the play has an EXCITING opportunity to be a part of a festival in South Africa. 

What We Need

We need to put a show up and get it across the ocean!
Your funds will go into all areas of the performance costs (light, sound, design) and then help us take the performance to South Africa!

The Impact

Rather than recite statistics, Kawuna...you're it! exposes the stories behind the statistics giving a deeper understanding of the factors surrounding HIV and the stigma it presents. With HIV flourishing within all levels of the social hierarchy and African women being at the bottom of the social ladder, the play gives voice to the silenced women affected by this disease and their hope for the future. The three stories told in Kawuna speak of a child left behind because of HIV, an ex-rebel soldier who contracted HIV as a result of war, and an elite woman who contracts HIV within her marriage. The play includes raw footage from the interviews, which gives a direct address from the women of Uganda to its audience. 

 Kawuna..you’re it presents a dynamic opportunity to explore the impact HIV/ AIDs has had on women in Africa and particularly Uganda. It presents an opportunity for the audience to investigate the secrecy surrounding HIV/AIDs brought on by stigma. The play explores what it means to be a woman as well as deal with what it means to be HIV positive.  By having this play be a part of this festival, we can give voice to the narratives behind the numbers and have audiences emerge from the theater with a stronger understanding of the HIV experience, and a more personal connection to the fight against the spread of the virus.


Other Ways You Can Help

Share this page with anyone who may be interested in helping us get this show on the road!

story:
What is Polybe + Seats?

Polybe + Seats is a Brooklyn-based company that has been making theater together since 2001. We take inspiration from Gertrude Stein’s writing for and about the theater, and our name comes from one of her plays. Our most recent productions have been A History of Launching Ships (Somewhat After Washington Irving) by Avi Glickstein at BLDG 92 at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and Alice, or the Scottish Gravediggers by René-Charles Guilbert de Pixérécourt at the Old Stone House of Brooklyn. The members of our company are Jessica Silsby Brater, Catherine Wallach, Miriam Felton-Dansky, Ari Vigoda, Stacey McMath, Avi Glickstein, Elaine O’Brien, Natalie Robin, Sarah Badiyah Sakaan and Lindsay Torrey.


What is Anna Asli Suriyah (I Come from Syria)?

"Habibti, I feel I need to be there."

In August, Polybe + Seats will produce a new play conceived by company member Sarah Badiyah Sakaan with artistic director Jessica Silsby Brater at Beit Jeddo Hookah Lounge in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. This is going to be an immersive night of theater, blending real-life moments with fantastical and folktale elements. Beit Jeddo (which means "Grandfather's House") will be transformed into a Syrian banquet hall, with the action moving from Aleppo to a refugee camp on the Turkish border to the U.S. and back. Our multi-national, multi-lingual cast presents a show that highlights the difficult choices Syrian and Syrian-American people must make as they grapple with the current crisis, and celebrates the drive to stay connected over great distances and barriers.

“The inspiration for creating this piece,” says Sarah, “is the fact that I’m in this conversation about what’s going on in Syria with my family, and I can’t escape it when I’m with them - but I am usually by myself in Brooklyn, and I’m able to give myself a little bit of space. With my family, we’ll be having coffee and just casually talking and then something drops in that is really devastating and really current, and everything changes. I realized that as a theater artist I have an opportunity to tell a story that’s not being told, of people who are actually experiencing this thing from the inside out.

Creating this show with my theater company is a celebration of the power and the freedom I have to tell this story. Instead of denying what’s going on, or disengaging from the conversation, I consider it my responsibility to make this play as an American and as the daughter of an immigrant who left his family to gain access to freedoms he couldn’t have in Syria.”

This piece had its first public showing as a solo work-in-progress this past November at Brooklyn Winery - maybe some of you were there! Since then, Sarah and Jessica have been working with a talented team of actors and designers, as well as producer Katie Naka, to shape Sarah’s passionate feelings about the current conflict in Syria into our 13th production.

“Collaborating with Sarah on this production is thrilling,” says Jessica. “Her vision combines personal experience and family history with traditional Arabic storytelling, music and ritual to bring an international humanitarian crisis to our attention. Our fantastic production team is making work that is moving, funny, surprising and exciting. We look forward to welcoming audiences!”

"Inshallah, badain, in a little while, it will be over, yianni, in a couple of months. You will see."


What we need

We are proud to say that this project has already received support from the Brooklyn Arts Council and A.R.T./New York’s Nancy Quinn Fund. We expect that a large portion of the rest of our production budget will come from ticket sales, but there is a gap of $5,500 that we need your support to close. The funds we raise through this campaign will go primarily toward paying stipends to the talented performers and designers who are working with us and toward buying materials for our designers to create a world for the play inside Beit Jeddo. Other production expenses include professional graphic design, insurance, rehearsal space rental, and marketing materials.

We are offering not only ticket discounts and VIP packages as perks for campaign contributors, but also unique perks reflecting the wide range of talents of our company members, including a homemade Syrian dinner party; professional editing of your literary, dramatic, or personal writing; private yoga lessons; a social media audit for your business or personal brand; and more.


The team

Conceived by Sarah Badiyah Sakaan with Jessica Silsby Brater

Written by Sarah Badiyah Sakaan with the company

Directed by Jessica Silsby Brater

Produced by Katie Naka and Polybe + Seats

Featuring Ayse Eldek, Tom Giordano, Nuah Oryzel, Sarah Badiyah Sakaan & Pascale Seigneurie

Set and Object Designer: Daniel Soule

Lighting Designer: Natalie Robin

Costume Designers: Karen Boyer and Bevan Dunbar

Sound Design and Musical Composition: Soraya Odishoo

Choreographic Consultant and Movement Coach: Lindsay Torrey

Stage Manager and Assistant Director: Naomi Boyce

Assistant Stage Manager: Emily Schwerdtfeger


How can you help?

Even if you can’t contribute (and even $1 helps, really), we hope you will be able to come see our show in August! Tickets are on sale now through SmartTix for $18. Opening night will be August 9th, and the show will run Saturdays through Tuesdays at 7pm until August 26th.

Please also help spread the word! You can share this campaign on Facebook, tweet about us, Google+ us, Instagram us, or email your friends the link to this campaign with the handy links located above this text. Your support will help us make this show a success.

If you would like to support us regularly, you can create a recurring monthly donation through Fractured Atlas here. If you would prefer to support us by mailing a check, please visit this section of our website for information. Or, if you work for a company that has a matching gifts program, email us at info@polybeandseats.org before you contribute about making your gift double.

FAQ:

1. Can I contribute from outside the United States? Yes, visit our page on Fractured Atlas to make a tax-deductible contribution.

2. Oh no, I missed the campaign and now it is closed! Can I still support your play? Yes! You can make a tax-deductible contribution through Fractured Atlas and we will still thank you in our program and on our website.

Please also look to these cultural associations for news and volunteer opportunities: 

NAAP (Network of Arab Americans Professionals) 

AAANY (Arab American Association of New York)

story:
Much Ado About Cucumbers & Cigars

SARAH WEBER GALLO (Choreographer/Director) is originally from Indianapolis, and is currently dancing in her 12th season as a company member of the Metropolitan Opera Ballet, where she has been featured in productions helmed by an array of world-renowned directors and choreographers, including: Fiona Shaw, Julie Taymor, Steven Wadsworth, Mary Zimmerman, Robert Lepage, Andre Serban, Adrian Noble, Benjamin Millipied, Graciella Danielle, Doug Varone, Mark Dendy, Ben Wright, and Christopher Wheeldon.  Additionally, Sarah has danced for Donald Byrd/The Group, NeoLabos Dancetheatre, Sean Curran Company, The Radio City Rockettes, and Margo Sappington’s American Dance Machine for the 21st Century.  She has enjoyed a long and fruitful collaboration with dance maker Elke Rindfleisch, for whom she has served as assistant choreographer/co-creator of numerous dance/theater works performed in venues ranging from rooftops in Brooklyn to Das Pumpwerks in Berlin to Jacob’s Pillow.  Her original choreography has been shown in both concert and theatrical settings at The Ohio Theatre, Gina Gibney, Movement Research, LaMama, Greenspace, Dancemakers Milwaukee, and Indy Convergence.  Sarah holds a B.A. in Psychology from Goucher College, and is an M.F.A. candidate in dance at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee’s Peck School of the Arts, where her recent collaborative choreography with Kate Martel and Whitney Jacobs, Pigeon Congress, will represent UWM at the 2014 American College Dance Festival.

The Project

Much Ado About Cucumbers & Cigars interweaves the narratives of two real women – The Beautiful Cigar Girl and Cucumber Girl – whose stories bare remarkable parallels.  The Beautiful Cigar Girl washed up dead at the mouth of a fresh-water cave in Hoboken, NJ, in 1841, the brutally murdered victim of a botched abortion attempt.  The story of her mysterious death prompted spectacular news reporting during the dawn of the penny press, ultimately resulting in police reform and the criminalization of abortion in New York.  Cucumber Girl is a contemporary young woman, almost certainly a student at Hoboken High School, who is both object and subject of a spate of vulgar and highly sexualized graffiti in the local playgrounds.  The lives of these two young women, spanning the better part of two centuries, illustrates the relentlessness of the commodification of the female body. 

A propulsive rock sound score centered in the Riot Grrrl punk movement provides the musical backbone of the piece, and the narratives are illuminated through spoken and written text.  By juxtaposing empowered female performers with stories of the lives of two real-but-absent women, Much Ado About Cucumbers & Cigars attempts to encourage a little more riotousness toward the purpose of de-objectification of the female body.

Much Ado About Cucumbers & Cigars is important to me, because I am motivated
by a desire to place myself and, more importantly, my young daughter outside of
the flat-lined continuum I continue to encounter in today’s post-feminist
world.

What We Need

Our total budget:  $4,500

Your support will help me realize this production by financing the technical and design elements, which are integral to the psychological environment of the show. 
More importantly, your support will help me compensate the artists, without whom none of this would be possible (or, I could have done a solo show, but the company of these artists makes me so much better).

My work is about presence, about laying bare the people behind the performance.  This requires a great personal investment from the performers.  They don’t just learn steps; they bring their entire selves into the room.  Their generosity is palpable. 

The Creative Team

Choreographer/Director:  Sarah Weber Gallo

Producer:  Joseph Gallo

Graphic/Sound Design:  Michael Blaskewicz

Lighting Design: Laura Cornish and Matt Fick

Costume Design:  Joy Havens

Video:  Marco Vidal

Performers:  Joy Havens, Katherine Hozier, Sam Meredith, Jen Ring, Jennifer Sydor, Michelle Vargo, Sarah Weber Gallo

The Impact

I care about this project because I remember well what it felt like to be a young woman in the world.  And I remember that I couldn’t quite make sense of my emerging womanhood after a girlhood fed by fairytales – Grimm though they may have been.  And I see that young women today are faced with a relentless commodification of their emerging sexual identities.  And I have a young daughter.

So this dance picks away at how young women are to own their power – sexual or otherwise.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help spread the word! You can easily share a link to this page with friends and fellow dance-lovers from your Facebook/Twitter accounts or with a personal email.  And don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools! 

Much Ado About Cucumbers & Cigars

October 17 & 18 @ 8 pm

Presented by Mile Square Theatre in Hoboken, NJ

Tickets go on sale soon!

And thanks in advance for all your support...

story:
To The Grind

In a community that is being continually expanded with new modes of "communicating," from Grindr to Scruff to Jackd to Mister to Manhunt to A4A etc., how do we develop our skills of communicating vocally?  What happens to our gay voices when technology starts to take over?

My name is Adriano Cabral.  I am a third year MFA Theatre Performance student at Arizona State University training as an actor and Voice Teacher.  This project I seek to create will explore how members of the gay community develop their voices under the influence of rising technological developments.  I seek to performatively investigate the concept of "the gay voice" vocally as well as metaphorically.  

To The Grind will put the voice of Gay Identity on the stage.  Overall, I seek to create a discourse in the gay community that brings us closer together and reminds us to remain corporeally present in a digital age.  

Your assistance will help send me to the Purnati Center for the Performing Arts in Bali, Indonesia for an intensive where I will study Fitzmaurice Voicework, Grotowski, Michael Chekhov, Kecak Voicework, Gamelan, Balinese Dance, and Balinese Maskwork in order to hone my craft for effectively creating To The Grind.

You will help me create a theatrical event that will awaken a greater awareness of how we communicate in the gay community.

 

What are we getting ourselves into?

The Tuition for the Bali Intensive is $2200

The average flight to Bali is $1500

The time and focus needed to develop a theatrical project is priceless.

Your donation will help me pay the necessary fees for my training and will create peace of mind as I venture off to create this new theatrical event.  In the event that I do not reach my entire goal, the money will still go towards paying off the Bali Tuition.

For those of you wishing to make large donations, I have a few perks available.

For a $5 donation, I will send you a Personalized Thank you e-mail.

For a $10 donation, I will send you a Personalized Thank you e-greeting card.

For a $20 donation, I will send you a Personalized Thank You Postcard from Bali, Indonesia.

For a $100 donation, I will send you a Personalized Thank You Postcard and Souvenir from Bali, Indonesia.

For a $200 donation, I will send you a Personalized Thank You Postcard, Souvenir from Bali, Indonesia, and a Producer credit on the project as well as a DVD of To The Grind. 

 

The Impact

I believe that the main reason behind Gay Teen Suicide, Hatemongering, Adverse effects due to unsafe Sex, and other negative ailments on the Gay Community are due to lack of communication.  We need to develop our voices, speak up, and be heard.  Only then can we start destroying the walls that prevent us from living equally.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to make a donation today, that doesn't mean you can't help.  Make some noise about this campaign.  Use the Indiegogo share tools.  Share this on Facebook.  +1 on Google Plus.  Tweet it, shout it, pin it.  Do whatever you can to exercise your voice and start spreading the word.

 

Thank you all for your time.  You all have my deepest gratitude!
story_txt:
To The Grind
In a community that is being continually expanded with new modes of "communicating," from Grindr to Scruff to Jackd to Mister to Manhunt to A4A etc., how do we develop our skills of communicating vocally?  What happens to our gay voices when technology starts to take over?
My name is Adriano Cabral.  I am a third year MFA Theatre Performance student at Arizona State University training as an actor and Voice Teacher.  This project I seek to create will explore how members of the gay community develop their voices under the influence of rising technological developments.  I seek to performatively investigate the concept of "the gay voice" vocally as well as metaphorically.  
To The Grind will put the voice of Gay Identity on the stage.  Overall, I seek to create a discourse in the gay community that brings us closer together and reminds us to remain corporeally present in a digital age.  
Your assistance will help send me to the Purnati Center for the Performing Arts in Bali, Indonesia for an intensive where I will study Fitzmaurice Voicework, Grotowski, Michael Chekhov, Kecak Voicework, Gamelan, Balinese Dance, and Balinese Maskwork in order to hone my craft for effectively creating To The Grind.
You will help me create a theatrical event that will awaken a greater awareness of how we communicate in the gay community.
 


What are we getting ourselves into?
The Tuition for the Bali Intensive is $2200
The average flight to Bali is $1500
The time and focus needed to develop a theatrical project is priceless.
Your donation will help me pay the necessary fees for my training and will create peace of mind as I venture off to create this new theatrical event.  In the event that I do not reach my entire goal, the money will still go towards paying off the Bali Tuition.
For those of you wishing to make large donations, I have a few perks available.
For a $5 donation, I will send you a Personalized Thank you e-mail.
For a $10 donation, I will send you a Personalized Thank you e-greeting card.
For a $20 donation, I will send you a Personalized Thank You Postcard from Bali, Indonesia.
For a $100 donation, I will send you a Personalized Thank You Postcard and Souvenir from Bali, Indonesia.
For a $200 donation, I will send you a Personalized Thank You Postcard, Souvenir from Bali, Indonesia, and a Producer credit on the project as well as a DVD of To The Grind. 
 


The Impact
I believe that the main reason behind Gay Teen Suicide, Hatemongering, Adverse effects due to unsafe Sex, and other negative ailments on the Gay Community are due to lack of communication.  We need to develop our voices, speak up, and be heard.  Only then can we start destroying the walls that prevent us from living equally.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you aren't able to make a donation today, that doesn't mean you can't help.  Make some noise about this campaign.  Use the Indiegogo share tools.  Share this on Facebook.  +1 on Google Plus.  Tweet it, shout it, pin it.  Do whatever you can to exercise your voice and start spreading the word.
 
Thank you all for your time.  You all have my deepest gratitude!

story:
The PlayGround Festival of New Works (http://playground-sf.org/festival) is the largest celebration of Bay Area playwrights, showcasing more than a dozen of the best new short and full-length plays by local writers. More than a hundred leading local directors, actors and designers will participate in the staging of these works. To successfully mount this year's festival and develop all of these amazing new works, we need to raise $1,500 by Saturday, May 10, 2014. Funds raised go directly to support Bay Area artists. Please help if you can and spread the word! And we hope you'll join us for some of the more than 40 performances/readings/discussions taking place at Thick House over the next month!

Contributors of $25 or more will receive a shout-out on the PlayGround Facebook page and contributors of $50 or more will receive a 2-for-1 voucher good for any Best of PlayGround or Sleeping Cutie performance. Contributors of $100 or more receive a pair of complimentary tickets to one of the four public staged readings (May 17-18 and May 24-25) taking place during the festival. Contributors of $250 receive an additional pair of tickets to one of the readings and acknowledgment at the reading. For the complete list of readings, visit http://playground-sf.org/festival/readings.shtml.

For the past twenty years, PlayGround has been investing in the Bay Area's most promising new playwrights and their work for the stage (and screen). PlayGround alumni represent some of the most distinguished new playwrights coming out of the Bay Area, including Peter Sinn Nachtrieb, Lauren Yee, Aaron Loeb, Erin Bregman and Garret Jon Groenveld, among others. And all of them got their start at the PlayGround Festival! Please support our efforts and help us launch tomorrow's great playwrights today! For more information, visit http://playground-sf.org or call (415) 992-6677. Thank you!

story:
Hi, my name is King David, I am the father to “MAXIMILIAN.” “MAXIMILIAN” is an extremely accomplished, talented and gifted young dancer. At the age of ten he auditioned for, and was accepted into, the renown JOFFREY BALLET SCHOOL, (by famed ballerina Irene Hogarth-Cimino) He began his studies in the Young Dancer Program’s “summer intensive”.  There, he studied Ballet Technique for half the day, which was supplemented with classes in Modern, Horton, Flamenco, Broadway, Conditioning & Stretch, and Yoga. He danced 7 hours a day, 5 days a week and excelled. At the end of that life-changing summer and as  a result of the effort, diligence, dedication, sheer athleticism, talent and progression, “MAXIMILIAN was awarded a full scholarship to the prestigious school, by esteemed ballet-mistress, Jo Matos. Since that time, he has performed in three of the JOFFREY BALLET SCHOOL’S productions of, “THE NUTCRACKER SUITE”, and two spring productions, “THE CARNIVAL OF ANIMALS” and most recently “FANTASIA”, in which he danced the role of “THE SORCERER’S APPRENTICE. “MAXIMILIAN” has also been able to maintain a 3.59 GPA while performing, rehearsing and training. He will be profiled in the upcoming November issue of "LATIN TRENDS MAGAZINE". A demanding schedule for anyone. Which brings us to the point of our campaign!

          High-achiever that he is, “MAXIMILIAN” was recently accepted into a prestigious college preparatory school enrolling 200 students (mostly working or aspiring child actors and dancers in grades 6-12).


(For the sake of confidentiality and privacy we cannot divulge the name of the school publicly. However, we will furnish the name in private messages upon request.)


       The school was founded in NYC in 1914 to provide an academic education to young people working on the New York stage, ‘vaudeville’, or ‘on the road’. Today’s students include, dancers, musicians,actors, athletes, and others who require the flexibility to pursue challenging goals, that may sometimes require absence from school for professional or pre-professional reasons. In the past, because of his rigorous and demanding schedule of training and performance, there have been conflicts with previous schools. They failed to not only recognize the substance and importance of what “MAXIMILIAN” was doing; but failed to understand a young artist/athlete who operates on an intensely high level. He even had a teacher disparage his talents by stating that’ “Dancer’s are not athletes!” Imagine.

     This school is not that type of school! They are the complete opposite. They are the type of institution that understands and appreciates the young artist and nurtures him.They allow for flexibility for performance, rehearsals, or auditions, without ever sacrificing academic excellence. It is the perfect school for “MAXIMILIAN” however the tuition is quite steep, and we as a family are unable to afford it.

      The tuition is $36,808 per year (plus fees of approximately $1000), bringing the total to $37,808. So we are asking for your assistance,in helping us to raise 50% of the total tuition, which is, $18,904.  This will insure that “MAXIMILIAN” continiues on his journey to becoming one of the youngest trainees in Joffrey Ballet School history; and your contribution would go a long way to helping him to meet and exceed his goal to be a world-class “ballerino” who performs in the capitals of the world.



       We, his Mom and Dad are looking for contributions of $5.00 to $500.00 in order that “MAXIMILIAN can attend this wonderful school and continue training,dancing and performing with the JOFFREY BALLET SCHOOL.  The tuition is $37,808, We are attempting to raise ½ of that amount, $18,904. We will provide the name of the school and a link to its website upon request. There you can investigate and see not only wonderful history of this school, their rigorous academic curiculum, but also some of the esteemed alumni who have matriculated there.



WE ARE OFFERING FANTASTIC PERKS FOR THOSE WHO CONTRIBUTE TO THE CAMPAIGN…”MAXIMILIAN DANCE!”


FOR CONTRIBUTORS OF …


$5.00 / receive a signed thank-you card from MAXIMILIAN w/the “MAXIMILIAN DANCE!” logo

$25.00/ receive a signed thank-you card, plus a “MAXIMILIAN DANCE!” t-shirt

$100.00/ receive a signed thank-you card, a “MAXIMILIAN DANCE!” t-shirt and,1 free ticket to  the Joffrey Ballet School’s performance of the “NUTCRACKER SUITE” or the “Spring Performance

$250.00/ receive a signed thank-youcard, a “MAXIMILIAN DANCE!” t-shirt, 1 free ticket to  the Joffrey Ballet School performance of the “NUTCRACKER SUITE”, or the spring performance, plus a DVD of that performance

$500.00/ receive all of the above plus 1 free ticket to both , “THE NUTCRACKER SUITE”, & “the Spring Performance”



 Your assistance in this campaign will aid “MAXIMILIAN”  in continuing on his journey to dance, and become one of the greatest male dancers of all time! One of his goals is to dance all of the great male roles in ballet, like his two idols, MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV and CARLOS ACOSTA! He also desires to “break down the walls”, between the disciplines of dance. For just as much as he is a fan of the the two afforementined stars, “MAXIMILIAN” also appreciates the artistry of,  “the NICHOLAS BROTHERS”, “FRED ASTAIRE”, & “GENE KELLY”!


 Because of his love and dedication to dance Mario has been bullied at school by not only students but teachers and administrators as well. He has withstood cyber-bullies, schoolyard bullies, stalkers, martinet teachers, and untold attempts at intimidation. He has withstood all these attempts and has continued to be dedicated to his dream of dance, and the rigorous training which that entails. He has  excelled and flourished despite the obstacles in his path. So we ask for your assistance, so that his dream continues to thrive and grow, so that he can fulfil his destiny to be…

 “MAXIMILIAN!...the Worlds Greatest Dancer!”

story:
It's the 25th Atlantic Fringe Festival 

Atlantic Fringe is the largest theatre festival in Atlantic Canada. For twenty-five years the festival has brought affordable, innovative live theatre to Halifax. This year we feature over 300 performances of 50 shows (!) from across Canada. It's a very important annual event for theatre artists and audiences. 

but HRM cut our grant :(

This year, despite it being our 25th silver anniversary edition, Halifax Regional Municipality cut our annual grant by 40% from last year (and the reason cited for the funding cut was "new committee"). That's no way to celebrate 25 years of fostering and presenting unique, daring and fabulous theatre to Halifax audiences. Boo! 

We're trying to raise $6000 to complete the budget

It costs a lot to put on a theatre festival! Fringe already stretches every penny-- that's the nature of independent fringe theatre. Your money will help us rent the theatre venues, equip them with lights and technicians, put roofs over artists' heads while they are in Halifax, and put on the shows! 

FYI at Fringe, 100% of box office sales go directly to the artists, so even though our festival has grown wildly and is more and more successful every year, we don't keep any of the money from ticket sales. It all goes to artists. That's why we rely on the grants. And now, on you. 

The Show Must Go On! 

Look, we've been Fringing for a quarter century and this is no time to stop! People love the Fringe. The Fringe Festival is one of the most exciting events in Halifax each year. When faced with a sudden cut in funding, we knew the show must go on. And we knew we could ask for help. Fringe is a very beloved institution and we know Halifax loves the Fringe as much as Fringe loves Halifax. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Donating money helps us meet our budget, but Fringe is also a great volunteer opportunity. We need volunteer ushers and box office managers. Look for our Atlantic Fringe Festival Volunteers Facebook page and join it! And of course share our website www.atlanticfringe.ca on social media. And if you'd like to make a more substantial tax deductible financial donation, you can call Atlantic Fringe at 902-422-7604 to arrange it.

story:
ABOUT CULTURE PROJECT

“Culture Project has been hailed as New York City’s premiere political and social performing arts organization, illuminating and championing the most pressing human rights issues of our time” – The Huffington Post

Founded in 1996 by artistic director Allan Buchman, Culture Project purposes to inspire audiences into dialogue and action regarding issues of social justice and human morality. In the past decade, we have grown from a small theater impacting 12,000 patrons annually to a small theater impacting over 150,000 patrons annually. Over the years, Culture Project has consistently created theater that emphasizes social and political issues designed to inform and inspire contemporary audiences. We believe that theatre is an effective agent of social change and we are dedicated to fostering the creative growth of artists. An alternative to news coverage, Culture Project produces raw, impassioned and political works of theatre intended to ignite conversation and incite political action. 

Culture Project was first propelled into national prominence by its acclaimed production of The Exonerated, which focused attention on six wrongfully imprisoned exonerates- detained for decades, then released without any recognition of wrongdoing. Culture Project has also premiered celebrated shows such as Sarah Jones’ Bridge & Tunnel co-produced by Meryl Streep, Guantanamo: Honor Bound to Defend Freedom, Lawrence Wright’s My Trip To Al-Qaeda,Tings Dey Happen, the Lucille Lortel award-winning world premiere of George Packer’s Betrayed, and James X, directed by Gabriel Byrne.

WHY CULTURE PROJECT IS PRODUCING NIRBHAYA:

We are honored to present the New York premiere of NIRBHAYA, written and directed by internationally acclaimed writer director Yaël Farber, in collaboration with an extraordinary cast and creative team from India. Culture Project is dedicated to amplifying marginalized voices to be heard, which is why we are so passionate about mounting this production. By fostering innovative collaboration between human rights organizations and artists, we aim, with this production, to inspire and impact public dialogue and policy, encouraging democratic participation in one of the most urgent matters of our time. NIRBHAYA bares witness to the extraordinary capacity of the human spirit for survival, redemption and change. It is an unforgettable work that moves and inspires audiences with the sheer capacity of the human spirit to rise, to bare witness, to survive and turn the tide. 

WHAT IS NIRBHAYA?

On the night of December 16th, 2012, a young woman boarded a bus in urban Delhi heading for home and was savagely gang raped. She eventually died due to the injuries she suffered. Despite her severe injuries, during her last two weeks, she found the strength to testify against her attackers, and ensured the perpetrators were brought to justice. In a society that often blames the victim for their own sexual assault, she used her dying days to demand accountability. Legally prevented from revealing the young woman’s real name, the press named her “Nirbhaya” (fearless one).

In response, the streets of India rose in protest against a system indifferent to and often critical of survivors of sexual assault. The Indian government attempted to quiet this response with riot police, water cannons and arrests - but the protesters defied intimidation. This response was mirrored across the world; Nirbhaya's death was a tipping point. The time for change had come. 


It was in this volatile aftermath that an impassioned Indian actress, Poorna Jagannathan, reached out to internationally acclaimed playwright and director Yaël Farber to create NIRBHAYA, an evening of theatre that tears away the shame that keeps survivors silent. In NIRBHAYA the play, the rape and death of Jyoti Singh Pandey (“Nirbhaya”) serves as the catalyst for each performer to bravely come forward and break their silence by recounting their own intimate and personal experiences of sexual and gender-based violence. The onstage act of breaking the silence inspires us, the audience and witnesses, to do the same.

NIRBHAYA’s vision is to do nothing less than CHANGE THE WORLD by ending the silence on sexual violence and creating a fear-free society.

The New York run of NIRBHAYA is scheduled for 28 performances beginning April 16 through May 17.

Learn more about the Culture Project production here.

For updates on the production, follow us onTwitter andFacebook.

WHAT WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTION DO?

The $50,000 we raise will be used to get the NIRBHAYA trailer broadcasted on local cable. Our aim is to reach as many people as possible, but as a nonprofit theatre we have fewer resources and a limited reach. The most effective way for us to advertise the production is on TV- by doing so, we can mobilize American audiences to stand with NIRBHAYA. 

Our ultimate ambition is to galvanize a broad base of support, with thousands of people pledging their support of our goal to change the world and break the cone of silence around sexual violence. 



WHY NOW?

"A compelling depiction of an awful truth…. Farber’s message is clear; this is a collective problem and we – men and women – must speak out. ‘I know my silence is part of what that dark night brought’ says one actor. Silently, some women in the audience nod” –The Independent ☆☆☆☆☆

“At a time when rape threats have become casual social media currency, it’s intensely sobering to have a play like this that reminds us so viscerally of the real horrors of sexual violence” – Time Out ☆☆☆☆

"One of the most powerful and urgent pieces of human rights theatre ever made." - The Herald

Now, more than ever, we are compelled to act in the name of NIRBHAYA. We must stand together to break this silence and empower those affected by gender-based violence to speak out worldwide.

OK, I MADE A PLEDGE. WHAT ELSE CAN I DO TO HELP?

You can SPREAD THE WORD! Tell a friend about the project via email, share it on Facebook, Tweet about it. Anything you can do to spread the word about NIRBHAYA and this campaign is extraordinarily helpful!

By fostering innovative collaboration between human rights organizations and artists, we aim, with this production, to inspire and impact public dialogue and policy, encouraging democratic participation in one of the most urgent matters of our time. NIRBHAYA bares witness to the extraordinary capacity of the human spirit for survival, redemption and change. It is an unforgettable work that moves and inspires audiences with the sheer capacity of the human spirit to rise, to bare witness, to survive and turn the tide. WHAT IS NIRBHAYA?


On the night of December 16th, 2012, a young woman boarded a bus in urban Delhi heading for home and was savagely gang raped. She eventually died due to the injuries she suffered. Despite her severe injuries, during her last two weeks, she found the strength to testify against her attackers, and ensured the perpetrators were brought to justice. In a society that often blames the victim for their own sexual assault, she used her dying days to demand accountability. Legally prevented from revealing the young woman’s real name, the press named her “Nirbhaya” (fearless one).


In response, the streets of India rose in protest against a system indifferent to and often critical of survivors of sexual assault. The Indian government attempted to quiet this response with riot police, water cannons and arrests - but the protesters defied intimidation. This response was mirrored across the world; Nirbhaya's death was a tipping point. The time for change had come. 






It was in this volatile aftermath that an impassioned Indian actress, Poorna Jagannathan, reached out to internationally acclaimed playwright and director Yaël Farber to create NIRBHAYA, an evening of theatre that tears away the shame that keeps survivors silent. In NIRBHAYA the play, the rape and death of Jyoti Singh Pandey (“Nirbhaya”) serves as the catalyst for each performer to bravely come forward and break their silence by recounting their own intimate and personal experiences of sexual and gender-based violence. The onstage act of breaking the silence inspires us, the audience and witnesses, to do the same.
NIRBHAYA’s vision is to do nothing less than CHANGE THE WORLD by ending the silence on sexual violence and creating a fear-free society.
The New York run of NIRBHAYA is scheduled for 28 performances beginning April 16 through May 17.

WHAT WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTION DO?

The $50,000 we raise will be used to get the NIRBHAYA trailer
broadcasted on local cable. Our aim is to reach as many people as possible, but
as a nonprofit theatre we have fewer resources and a limited reach. The most
effective way for us to advertise the production is on TV- by doing so, we can
mobilize American audiences to stand with NIRBHAYA. 
Our ultimate ambition is to galvanize a broad base of support, with
thousands of people pledging their support of our goal to change the world and
break the cone of silence around sexual violence.

in the audience nod” –The Independent ☆☆☆☆☆

Now, more than ever, we are compelled to act in the name of NIRBHAYA. We must stand together to break this silence and empower those affected by gender-based violence to speak out worldwide.

OK, I MADE A PLEDGE. WHAT ELSE CAN I DO TO HELP?
You can SPREAD THE WORD! Tell a friend about the project via email, share it on Facebook, Tweet about it. Anything you can do to spread the word about NIRBHAYA and this campaign is extraordinarily helpful!
